The major market averages held firm despite political furor over President Trump's abrupt firing of FBI Director James Comey, a Macy's (M)-led retail meltdown, bad news from Walt Disney and a Snap crash. On the upside, Nvidia (NVDA), OLED play Coherent (COHR) and new IPO Trade Desk (TTD) were big winners.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.3% for the week, hitting a new record high Wednesday as Apple (AAPL) and Netflix (NFLX) were among the big-cap techs setting all-time bests. The Dow industrials sank 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Higher oil prices lifted energy stocks, while bad news from Macy's, J.C. Penney (JCP) and several other retailers sent the broader sector tumbling. Snap fell close to its IPO price as Facebook (FB) competition takes its toll. But Nvidia skyrocketed to record highs on huge demand for its chips for graphics, artificial intelligence and more.Delivering its first earnings report since coming public, Snapchat-operator Snap missed on the top and bottom line. Snap said average revenue per user rose 181%, to 90 cents, but fell from $1.05 in the prior quarter. User growth was weaker than expected, with Facebook successfully cloning Snapchat's most popular features. Shares plunged more than 21% on Thursday to a post-IPO trading low, though they did rise 6% on Friday.3 top-rated IPOs also reported earnings. Digital ad platform Trade Desk (TTD) spiked Friday morning on better-than-expected earnings and revenue. Chip-equipment play Ichor (ICHR) reported results in line with bullish preliminary figures, but gave weak guidance. IT services firm Presidio (PSDO) fell after its results.RELATED:Snap Laughs Off Facebook Competition As Stock Plunges On Earnings MissGraphics chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) earnings rose 85% and sales surged 48% to $1.94 billion, beating views and helped by strong demand for processors for cloud computing data centers. Nvidia shares shot up 23% in the two days after the late Tuesday report. Microchip Technology (MCHP) and MaxLinear (MXL) also rallied on better-than-expected quarterly results.RELATED:Nvidia Surges 23% In Two Days On Earnings, GPU ConferenceWalt Disney (DIS) was forced to defend ESPN again as the premium sports cable network's subscriber losses accelerated slightly from the prior quarter; the timing of the call, not long after ESPN laid off about 100 mostly high-profile employees, put the channel back in the spotlight and CEO Bob Iger back in the hot seat. Results were mixed as revenue growth of 3% to $13.34 billion missed estimates and profit gains of 10% to $1.50 a share topped. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) turned in mixed results, topping on profit views, but cable ad revenue was weak. Ad revenue softness and subscriber declines have put media stocks under scrutiny lately.RELATED:21st Century Fox's Weak Cable Ad Revenue Follows Disney's ESPN WoesMacy's (M) led retailers after reporting weak quarterly results, as the department store operator is trying a variety of initiatives, hoping to find a solution to the long-time decline in brick-and-mortar retailer. Macy's sold off 17% on Thursday, then continued falling Friday, hitting its worst levels since 2011. Nordstrom (JWN) tumbled on disappointing same-store sales, while Kohl's (KSS) sold off mixed results. J.C. Penney (JCP) crashed to a record low Friday on its weak comps while Dillard's (DDS) also plunged. Many retailers are trying an array of things — from better e-commerce services to new beauty offerings to stores-within-stores — to prop up sales as more people buy things online or at discounters.RELATED:J.C. Penney Threatens All-Time Low On Weak Sales As Retail Woes ContinueMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkOPEC production fell in April thanks to decline in output from Libya, Iraq and Iran. But Saudi Arabia's production increased by nearly 50,000 barrels per day, according to OPEC's report. The increases come as OPEC and its allies debate extending the current production deal. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said an extension would reduce supply even further in the second half of the year. But U.S. shale is curbing the effectiveness of the cuts. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration said U.S. stockpiles fell by 5.2 million barrels last week, a larger-than-expected drop. On Tuesday, the EIA raised its full-year U.S. oil production forecast for 2018 to 9.96 million barrels per day. U.S. crude futures rallied after tumbling 6.3% in the prior week.EOG Resources (EOG) said it could hit its targeted 18% production increase and operate with in cash flow if oil averages $47 per barrel. It plans to operate three more rigs than previously expected, but keep capital spending at $3.7 billion to $4.1 billion. EOG, sometimes called the "Apple (AAPL) of oil," touted its Big Data and proprietary mobile apps in helping cut costs while new wells in the Permian basin "shattered" industry records for early production. Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) raised its 2017 production outlook and Sanchez Energy (SN) said current Q2 production levels are already 46% higher than Q1 levels. Oasis Petroleum (OAS) said Q1 production soared 25.6%.Coherent (COHR) earned $2.91 a share, up 180%, in its fiscal Q2. Revenue rose 112% to $422.8 million. Shares skyrocketed to a new high. Coherent makes laser parts used in making OLED displays for TVs and increasingly smartphones. CEO John Ambroseo sees "unprecedented demand" across many of the company's verticals.E-commerce giant JD.com (JD), one of China's top performing internet companies, reported first-quarter results that topped estimates and guided second-quarter revenue above views, a week before rival Alibaba (BABA) reports. China online auto site Bitauto (BITA) reported first-quarter earnings that fell short of views, but a competing online auto website, Autohome (ATHM), topped expectations. China social networking company YY (YY) also beat the consensus estimate.Marriott (MAR) reported first-quarter earnings that topped estimates and gave a rosier outlook for revPAR — or revenue per available room — a reflection of postelection optimism. Several hotel operators have delivered strong earnings and big stock gains. Travel-information websites Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), however, reported results that missed views.The video game publisher earned 85 cents a share excluding items, up 69% year over year, far above views, as sales grew 18% to $1.09 billion. Electronic Arts (EA) was helped by continued strong sales of its World War I shooter game "Battlefield 1" and growth in pro soccer game "FIFA 17." An industrywide shift to higher-margin digital game downloads boosted profit. EA shares soared to record highs.Online home furnishings retailer Wayfair (W) reported first-quarter results that topped analyst estimates and sent shares to all-time highs, putting the squeeze on short sellers in the process. A large amount of Wayfair shares are sold short, equivalent to almost 17 days' worth of trading.Target (TGT) is pilot-testing a next-day home-delivery service for "essentials" such as detergent and coffee in the Minneapolis area. The Target Restock service will be available to REDcard users for an unspecified flat fee as the big-box retailer seeks to catch up with Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT) moves in the delivery space. Amazon, for its part, cut its free-shipping minimum to $25 from $35, after trimming that from $49 earlier this year in reaction to Wal-Mart.M.D.C. Holdings (MDC) earned 43 cents a share, up 126% vs. a year earlier. Revenue swelled nearly 43% to $581.71 million vs. estimates of $509.9 million. LGI Homes (LGIH) earned 52 cents a share vs. 57 cents a year earlier. Revenue edged up 0.9% to $162.9 million. Shares of MDC rocketed 11% Tuesday to the highest in nearly four years. LGI Homes shot up 13.2%. Larger peers such as Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and KB Home (KBH) also rallied after the sector had turned spotty in recent weeks.Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) agreed to buy Tribune Media (TRCO) for $3.9 billion, or $43.50 a share, creating a TV station powerhouse after the FCC lifted ownership caps. Sinclair Broadcast, which will also assume $2.7 billion in debt, fell 5.55% for the week. Tribune Media, which had been rallying on buyout buzz, rose 2.7%.Coach (COH) will buy struggling handbag rival Kate Spade (KATE), to boost its appeal with younger women. Coach will pay $2.4 billion, or $18.50 a share, less than some had speculated.Yelp (YELP) crashed 18.4% Wednesday after the local search-and-reviews site reported weak revenue and gave guidance that was far below analyst estimates.

Many of the major homebuilding stocks are basing or exploring new highs as the first-quarter reporting season gathers momentum, and as the market rolls through a heavy two-week stretch of real estate sector economic news. D.R. Horton (DHI) reports its fiscal second-quarter results Thursday morning, and on Tuesday afternoon the homebuilder was trading just above a 34.15 buy point in a…

XD.R. Horton (DHI), the largest U.S. homebuilder by volume, beat fiscal Q2 estimates and raised its full-year revenue guidance Thursday. Shares opened higher, retaking a buy point, but soon reversed lower.Estimates: EPS is seen increasing 13% to 59 cents, with revenue up 11.7% to $3.09 billion.Results: EPS of 60 cents on homebuilding revenue of $3.2 billion. Orders increased 14% to 13,991 homes worth $4.2 billion. The cancellation rate edged up to 20% from 19%."The spring selling season is going well, as the value of our net sales orders increased by 52% sequentially from the December quarter and 17% from the March quarter last year," Chairman Donald Horton said in a statement. "These results reflect the strength of our experienced operational teams, diverse product offerings through our family of brands and good market conditions across our broad national footprint."Outlook: Full-year revenue raised to $13.6 billion to $14 billion — the midpoint slightly below consensus for $13.84 billion — up from the prior year outlook for $13.4 billion to $13.8 billion.Stock: Shares quickly rose to 34.34 on the stock market today, retaking a 34.15 buy point, but closed down 2.5% to 33.10. Fellow homebuilder Lennar (LEN), near a buy point of 53.89, fell 1.35% to 51.89. Toll Bros. (TOL), Pulte Group (PHM) and KB Home (KBH) are all above buy range, but fell 1.8%, 3.5% and 1.1%, respectively.Homebuilder stocks took off immediately after last year's presidential election and again at the start of this year, and builder sentiment soared.Steady economic growth and improving wages have bolstered the outlook. But homebuilding companies continue to face labor shortages as the housing bust last decade sent skilled workers to other fields.In March, housing starts declined 6.8% to a annualized rate of 1.22 million units, the Commerce Department said on Tuesday, as severe weather in the Midwest weighed on activity and followed an unseasonably warm February that inflated activity.

XThe stock market remained in rally mode on Thursday with the Nasdaq leading the way, rising 0.7% vs. the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average's gains of more than 0.6%. Volume rose modestly on the NYSE, but edged lower on the Nasdaq vs. the same time Wednesday. Among the Dow industrials, American Express (AXP) boosted the blue-chip index with a near 5% jump after reporting its Q1 earnings late Wednesday. The credit card company cleared both earnings and sales estimates, causing shares to surge back above the 50-day line. The two energy components in the Dow Jones industrials, Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), followed up with 1% advances apiece as crude oil prices rebounded 0.1% after Wednesday's 3% fall.Among other companies reporting earnings, D.R. Horton (DHI) traded down over 2.3% despite beating fiscal Q2 estimates and raising its full-year revenue guidance early Thursday. D.R. Horton broke out of a cup with handle with a 34.16 entry on Monday, but is now trading below that point. Other homebuilders followed suit. Pulte Group (PHM) reversed from highs to move down 1.7%, while Toll Brothers (TOL) dropped almost 1%.Qualcomm (QCOM) fell 0.6% after reporting its Q2 fiscal results late Wednesday. The wireless chip maker reported better-than-expected sales and earnings, but guided analysts lower for the current quarter. The bearish guidance caused a number of price-target cuts from analysts. Shares are down 20% year-to-date. Starbucks (SBUX) jumped out of a flat base with a 59.64 entry in the stock market today. The coffee maker was upgraded to buy from hold at Stifel. Stifel expects the company to report strong same-store sales growth in the coming quarters. Starbucks debuted a new 'Unicorn' Frappuccino to mixed reviews, but it may be the beginning of further creative beverage offerings. Shares moved up 1.3%Among other breakouts, Primerica (PRI) surpassed its 84.25 flat-base buy point as shares moved up 1.9%. Volume is light, but trending above average, for now. The longtime Leaderboard member has showed strong relative strength vs. the general market for the past month as its relative strength line reaches a new high today. Among leading growth stocks, Cyprus-based payment processor Qiwi (QIWI) paced the advancers with a 3.4% rise, while regional bank Citizens Financial (CFG) rallied 2.9% higher. E-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA) broke into new highs with a 2.1% gain, while Dave & Buster's (PLAY) is adding momentum, up 2.7%, to a flat-base breakout from February. Shares are now up over 7% from its 58.35 entry.Downside performers were limited, but TAL Education (TAL) fell 0.5%, while recent breakout and new Leaderboard name Dycom (DY) fell 0.4%.RELATED:Starbucks Breaks Out To 1-Year High As 'Unicorn' Tastes Like VictoryD.R. Horton Reverses From Buy Point Despite Strong Earnings, Guidance2 Dow Earnings Due But This Top Stock Is On Breakout Watch: Investing Action PlanWhere Is The Stock Market Headed? Stocks opened higher Thursday as earnings reports countered some weak early economic data.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 climbed 0.2% as the Nasdaq led with a 0.4% increase.The Dow industrials headed into Thursday's session playing catch-up, down 0.2% for the week and looking at a possible third straight weekly decline. The Nasdaq held a 1% gain for the week, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%, but only the Nasdaq has regained support at its 50-day moving average.A barrage of top-drawer quarterly reports stirred Thursday's premarket session. American Express (AXP) climbed 4%, Qualcomm (QCOM) added 0.1% after earnings reports late Wednesday. E-commerce giant eBay (EBAY) shed 3% following its report and gapped below the 50-day moving average, a bearish move.Verizon (VZ) retreated 2% and Nucor (NUE) jumped nearly 4% after reporting first-quarter results Thursday morning.Railroad CSX (CSX) jumped 7% at the open and momentarily climbed above the 50.41 buy point of a flat base. A 38% leap in first-quarter earnings and a 10% revenue gain topped analyst expectations, despite restructuring charges that increased expenses 13%. Export demand helped lift revenue from coal 3% for the quarter.Heavyweight homebuilder D.R.Horton (DHI) climbed 0.3% after reporting positive fiscal second-quarter results. Earnings rose 15% and revenue climbed 17% — both narrowly above expectations. Net sales orders and backlogs increased, but so did the rate of cancellations among new home orders, to 20% from 19% a year ago.  Horton shares are trying to clear a 34.15 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Sherwin Williams (SHW) broke out of a flat base as it jumped past a 316.76 buy point.  348% leap in first-quarter earnings soared past analyst expectations and a 7% revenue gain also topped views.Foot Locker (FL) rose 3% after updating its first-quarter earnings guidance to below analyst forecasts. Shares are forming a cup-with-handle base.United Rentals (URI) fell 4% at the open after reporting a strong first-quarter sales and earnings beat, but which included a 1.4% decline in rental rates. Management's full-year revenue guidance did not meet the consensus expectation. United has been in a flat consolidation, fighting to regain support at its 10-week moving average since March.Applications for first-time unemployment claims jumped to 244,000 in the week ended April 15, up from 234,000 claims in the prior week, the Labor Department reported.  Economist consensus had projected a smaller increase, to 242,000 new claims.Manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region slowed sharply in April, sending the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey to 22, vs. a 32.8 reading for March. The index has been positive for nine months, and remains at relatively high levels, the report said.The Conference Board's leading indicators index arrives at 10 a.m. ET.The euro rallied vs. the dollar, the yen and the pound. Meanwhile, France's CAC 40 in Paris outpaced Europe's other benchmarks, with banks leading the advance. The first round of the French presidential election, which will also gauge voters' desire to remain in or exit the European Union, is scheduled for Sunday. The CAC 40 traded up 0.8% in afternoon action, while Frankfurt's DAX turned negative and the FTSE 100 in London slipped 0.1%.Asia's markets moved generally higher, rebounding from three days of losses as tensions involving North Korea appeared to lessen. Hong Kong led, surging 1%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 eased a fraction.RELATED:2 Dow Earnings Due, Top Stock Is On Breakout Watch: Investing Action Plan

Major averages reversed higher after a soft start Wednesday, as the release of the minutes from the mid-June Federal Reserve meeting came and went without much fanfare.Biotechs like Celgene (CELG) and Incyte (INCY) buoyed the Nasdaq 100. Facebook (FB) also outperformed. Facebook rose 2.4% to 116.70, closing above its 50-day line for the first time since June 10.After falling 0.8% early, the Nasdaq ended with a gain of 0.8%. The S&P 500 added 0.5%, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in slightly higher than Tuesday's levels. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners on both exchanges by less than 2-to-1.Dow leaders included Merck (MRK), Home Depot (HD) and Cisco Systems (CSCO). Merck rose 2%, Home Depot 1.7% and Cisco 1.4%.After touching an intraday low of $45.92 a barrel, benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil added nearly 2% to $47.43 a barrel. The 10-year Treasury yield was mostly unchanged, around 1.37%.The minutes from the June 15 Fed meeting were released at 2 p.m. ET. Before the Brexit vote, the Fed had signaled a couple of rate hikes before the end of the year, but that all changed after the U.K. decided to exit the European Union. Currently, futures traders see little chance of a rate hike this year. The 10-year Treasury yield was recently at 1.39%, up 2 basis points, after hitting an all-time low Tuesday.In the stock market today, Edwards Lifesciences (EW) was a strong performer in the IBD 5o screen of leading growth stocks. Edwards Lifesciences reclaimed its 50-day moving average, rising nearly 4% in above-average volume. Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) also did well, rising 3% in strong turnover. It's still in buy range from an early flat-base entry of 32.20.D.R. Horton is among a select group of leaders in IBD's home-building group. See who the others are with IBD Stock Checkup.

Shares of PulteGroup (PHM) jumped Tuesday, leading homebuilder stocks higher, on reports that activist investor Elliott Management has taken a more than 4% stake in the company.Elliott informed PulteGroup that it had taken the position in the company, the homebuilder told Bloomberg in an emailed statement.A stake of more than 4% but less than 5% exempts Elliott from mandatory reporting requirements.The move comes after PulteGroup was criticized by co-founder and top shareholder Bill Pulte earlier this year. CEO Richard Dugas later announced his resignation, saying he planned to stay on in the position until next year.PulteGroup shares jumped 4.1% to 19.37 by the close in the stock market today. Among other top homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2.1%, Lennar (LEN) and Toll Bros. (TOL) both climbed 2.5% and NVR (NVR) rose 0.4%.It wasn't immediately known what changes, if any, that Elliott will push for at the company, which has seen an exodus of top executives.

A slew of data out Thursday generally signaled that the U.S. economy once again is rebounding in the second quarter after an anemic start to the year. It also bolsters the case for Federal Reserve hawks to raise interest rates in June or July.Durable goods orders spiked 3.4% in April, the Commerce Department said Thursday, much better than forecasts, though business investment fell to a five-year low. Meanwhile, weekly jobless claims fell more than expected, the Labor Department said. And pending home sales spiked 5.1% to a 10-year high.Economists had expected durable goods orders would show a rise of 0.3%, while March's gain was revised up 1.1 points to 1.9%. New orders for civilian aircraft from Boeing (BA) and others shot up 64.9%.Orders for big ticket, long-lasting goods excluding transportation rose 0.4%, matching views. But Commerce revised down ex transportation orders going back to 2014.Capital goods orders excluding aircraft and defense fell 0.8% in April. The core capital goods orders measure, a proxy for business investment plans, has fallen for the last three months and five of the last six. Along with downward revisions going back to 2014, the core capital goods orders level was the lowest since April 2011.A weaker dollar in April -- somewhat reversed in May amid higher Fed rate hike odds -- makes U.S. exports more competitive. Meanwhile, rising oil prices should stabilize capital spending in the energy sector.Separately, jobless claims fell 10,000 to 268,000 in the week ended May 21. Analysts had expected 275,000. Filings for jobless benefits are near historical lows, but had been creeping higher. The 4-week moving average rose by 2,750 to 278,500.The Pending Home Sales Index shot up 5.1% in April to the highest level since February 2006, the National Association of Realtors said. Economists expected a 0.8% rise in the gauge of existing-home contract signings. The index suggests actual existing-home sales closings should rise in May or June.Homebuilders D.R. Horton (DHI) rose fractionally while Lennar (LEN) edged down on the stock market today. Boeing rose less than 1%.Next week may be decisive for a Federal Reserve rate hike in June. We'll get the May ISM manufacturing index, May U.S. auto sales and the May employment report.

Homebuilder stocks like LGI Homes (LGIH),  D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR) are showing signs of a rebound after new-home sales rose to their highest level in eight years in April. But here's another top-rated stock that could get a boost from a stronger housing market: Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS). Through its portfolio of companies, Fortune Brands offers cabinetry, plumbing, door and security products.…

A surprise jump in home sales contracts signed in April, reported Thursday, comes just as several key homebuilder stocks are trading near new potential buy points within their respective bases. The report, from the National Association of Realtors, showed a 5.1% jump in pending home sales. That pushed pending sales to their highest level since 2006, and was nearly three times the…

While the rise in new-home sales in April to the highest level in eight years has homebuilders stocks like DR Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and NVR (NVR) showing signs of a rebound, Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS) is another name that stands to benefit from a stronger housing market. Watch Related Video On Fortune Brands Based in Deerfield,…

Sales of new homes hit a four-year high last month, and luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. (TOL) said Tuesday the foundation for continued growth is in place, though questions remain about millennials' future buying habits.The Commerce Department said April new-home sales skyrocketed 16.6% to an annualized rate of 619,000, the highest since January 2008. Wall Street was looking for a small increase to 523,000 units."We continue to believe the drivers are in place to sustain the current housing market's slow but steady growth," Toll Bros. Chairman Robert Toll said in a statement."Interest rates remain low, the job picture continues to improve, home equity values are rising, supply remains constrained and the industry is still not building enough homes to meet the demand that current demographics imply are needed."Toll Bros. shares closed up 8.7% in the stock market today, gapping above their 50-day average. Among other homebuilders, NVR (NVR) rose 3%. D.R. Horton (DHI) added 4.2%, Lennar (LEN) rose 3.9%, and PulteGroup (PHM) climbed 5.1%.Toll Bros., which sells to more affluent buyers, said adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings climbed 39% to 51 cents a share, beating analyst estimates by 6 cents. Revenue grew 31% to $1.12 billion, well above analyst views for $1.04 billion.The homebuilder expects full-year revenue of $4.76 billion-$5.36 billion, with the midpoint of the range above views for $5.01 billion. Toll Bros. also expects to deliver 5,800-6,300 new homes for the year, with an average value of $820,000-$850,000.Meanwhile, the Commerce Department said the average home price climbed 6% to $379,800.Stifel Chief Economist Lindsey Piegza said the price increase may be too big for some consumers to swallow. "If the price of new homes continues to go up, it will make it more difficult for the average potential homeowner to buy."Piegza noted sales are still well below pre-recession highs. In April 2005, there were 1.26 million new homes sold, nearly double the figure this year, according to Commerce figures.Other analysts see strong results ahead."Today's numbers were eye-popping growth," said Lawrence Yun, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. "There is still plenty of momentum to go forward."But new questions arose about whether millennials will buy homes at the same rate as earlier generations did. Piegza said they prefer to rent and may stay out of the home-buying market in the near term.And a new Pew Research Center study out Tuesday found that Americans 18 to 34 years old in 2014 were more likely to be live with their parents than in their own household with a spouse or partner. Pew said that is the first time that's happened in the modern era.But Robert Toll remained upbeat about the key demographic group, saying on a conference call that “as millennials mature, studies indicate their appetite for housing is consistent with past generations.”Meanwhile, paint and coatings company Valspar (VAL), which is being bought by Sherwin-Williams (SHW) for $11.3 billion, also said Tuesday that adjusted fiscal Q2 earnings rose 9.9% to $1.22 a share, 4 cents below forecasts. Revenue slid 2.1% to $1.056 billion, lighter than the expected $1.122 billion.

Stocks jumped Tuesday, with the Nasdaq posting its biggest gain in nearly three months, after a big increase in existing-home sales suggested that the economy may be able to weather higher interest rates.The Nasdaq rallied 2%, the S&P 500 rose 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2%. All three indexes climbed back above their converging 200-day and 50-day moving averages, a bullish indicator for the health of the overall market. In another good sign, volume rose across the board compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Machinery, auto parts and consumer-related stocks paced the gains in the stock market today, while miners underperformed as gold prices dropped.Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 3% and cleared a 98.10 buy point. Its relative strength line is hitting new highs, which is a bullish indicator, but volume on the breakout was weak.How does Adobe Systems stack up against its rivals in the desktop software industry? Find out at IBD's Stock Checkup.Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) rose 2%, climbing above a 66.34 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in heavy volume.Homebuilders fared well after sales of existing homes soared 16% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 619,000 units, the highest since January 2008.Pulte Group (PHM) rose 5%, retaking its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Lennar (LEN) rose nearly 4% and D.R. Horton (DHI) added more than 4%, retaking its 50-day moving average as it works on a cup-with handle base with a 32.61 buy point.All but one of the IBD 50 stocks rose, led by NetEase (NTES), which jumped 6%. The Chinese online gaming stock is climbing the right side of a cup-type base with a possible 186.55 buy point.Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) was the only decliner, ending down a fraction after erasing an early gain of about 1%. The pet food maker is having trouble clearing a 26.08 cup-with-handle buy point.

April sales of existing homes rose 1.7% to a 5.45 million annualized pace, the National Association of Realtors said Friday. That topped forecasts for 5.4 million, while March was revised slightly higher.Existing-home sales rose 6% vs. a year earlier. The median home price was $232,500, up 5% vs. March and 6.3% vs. a year earlier.The number of existing homes for sales spiked 9.2% to 2.14 million units as the spring selling season gets underway. That translates to 4.7 months' worth of supply at the current sales pace.Shares of homebuilders generally rallied as the major averages rallied on the stock market today. D.R. Horton (DHI), KB Home (KBH) and Lennar (LEN) all rose more than 1% in morning trade.On Tuesday, the Commerce Department said housing starts rose 6.6% to a 1.172 million annualized rate, beating forecasts. But starts fell 1.7% vs. a year earlier.On Monday, the National Association of Home Builders reported that its homebuilder sentiment index was unchanged in May at 58 vs. views  for 59. Readings over 50 signal optimism.

Bears and bulls alike showed patience late Thursday afternoon as the stock indexes stayed close to the break-even level. The market is likely waiting for the second take on first quarter GDP, which will be released Friday before the opening bell.The Nasdaq inched up 0.3% Thursday, the S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally lower. The Dow Jones utility average led the upside with a 0.9% pop. Volume was running lower on both major exchanges.GDP has been revised upward in each of the previous three quarters' second takes. In the first Q1 estimate, GDP came in at a weak 0.5%. The Street's consensus view expects the percentage to be adjusted upward to a still-sluggish 0.9%. The range of estimates ran from 0.5% to 1.1%.On Thursday, blue chips were mostly down. Of the 30 stocks in the Dow, only one attracted higher volume. Apple (AAPL) cranked up volume more than 40% above the usual pace, gaining 1.1% to 100.69. The stock is headed toward its fifth daily gain in a row and was testing its 100 price level. Apple has wiped out most of the losses tied to its April earnings report. The stock chart, though, still looks ugly.A report from Morgan Stanley says Apple is spending heavily on auto technologies' research and development. Apple’s R&D spending rose 30% in Q1 to $2.51 billion. This kind of investment could bring Apple back into the growth camp. Some market analysts say that Apple is now more of a conservative stock than a growth stock.How many failing red marks does Apple get in IBD Stock Checkup?Economic news was generally bullish Thursday. Durable goods orders in April bulldozed past the Street's estimate. April's increase was 3.4% vs. views for 0.3%. The March percentage was revised upward from 0.8% to 1.9%. Meanwhile, first-time jobless claims came in lower than expected.Pending home sales for April boomed 5.1% vs. views for 0.8%. The home sales number reached the highest level in 10 years. The reaction, however, among housing stocks was subdued. For example, D.R. Horton (DHI) was flat as the market headed into its final hour of trade.The one negative note came from the Kansas City Fed's manufacturing gauge. The needle pointed to minus 5 in May vs. minus 4 in April. Manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of GDP, has been a sore point in the U.S. economy.Breakouts Thursday included Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR). Dollar General rose 5% intraday while Dollar Tree shot up 13.5%, both on earnings reports.

Stocks jumped Tuesday, with the Nasdaq posting its biggest gain in nearly three months, after strong new-home sales suggested that the economy may be able to withstand higher interest rates.The Nasdaq rallied 2%, the S&P 500 rose 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2%. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq are now both above their 200-day and 50-day moving averages, a bullish indicator for the health of the overall market. In another good sign, volume rose across the board compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) was up 9% in post-session trading after announcing that it will spin off its enterprise services unit and merge it with Computer Sciences (CSC), which soared 23% after hours."The 'spin-merger' of HPE's Enterprise Services unit with CSC is the right next step for HPE and our customers," Meg Whitman, CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise, said in a statement. HP Enterprise is itself a spinoff from the former Hewlett-Packard. The announcement came as both companies prepared to release quarterly earnings late Tuesday.Meanwhile, machinery, auto parts and consumer-related stocks paced the gains in the stock market today, while miners underperformed as gold prices dropped.Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 3% and cleared a 98.10 buy point. Its relative strength line is hitting new highs, which is a bullish indicator, but volume on the breakout was weak.How does Adobe Systems stack up against its rivals in the desktop software industry? Find out at IBD’s Stock Checkup.Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) rose 2%, climbing above a 66.34 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in heavy volume.Homebuilders fared well after sales of new homes soared 16% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 619,000 units, the highest since January 2008.Pulte Group (PHM) rose 5%, retaking its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Lennar (LEN) rose nearly 4% and D.R. Horton (DHI) added more than 4%, retaking its 50-day moving average as it works on a cup-with handle base with a 32.61 buy point.All but one of the IBD 50 stocks rose, led by NetEase (NTES), which jumped 6%. The Chinese online gaming stock is climbing the right side of a cup-type base with a possible 186.55 buy point.Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) was the only decliner, ending down a fraction after erasing an early gain of about 1%. The pet food maker is having trouble clearing a 26.08 cup-with-handle buy point.Guess (GES), Costco (COST), Williams-Sonoma (WSM) and PVH (PVH) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.

The Nasdaq took a stab Tuesday at its best gain in more than two months as the stock market approached the day's last hour of trade.Blue chips lagged with a 1.2% gain for the Dow industrials, while the S&P 500 stepped up 1.3%. The Nasdaq and the small cap Russell 2000 led with pops of 1.9% and 2%, respectively. Volume was higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq, compared to the previous session.Technicals are improving in the stock market. The Nasdaq retook its 50-day and 200-day lines Tuesday. The S&P 500 also reclaimed its 50-day line (after climbing above the 200-day line in March). Recently, the Nasdaq's 50-day line crossed back above its 200-day line, which is a positive development.The Dow industrials were up almost without exception Tuesday afternoon, with 29 of the 30 stocks rising, including Visa (V), which added 2.8%, its biggest percentage gain since early March. Visa's volume, though, was below average Tuesday. Boeing (BA) was the Dow's only loser, down 0.6% in strong volume.Is Visa's stock overdrawn with selling, or is the stock ready to charge higher? See IBD Stock Checkup.Top-rated stocks featured many breakouts and new highs. Stocks breaking out included TurboTax provider Intuit (INTU), chip designer Ceva (CEVA), joint replacement maker Zimmer Biomet (ZBH), telecom software developer BroadSoft (BSFT), water heater maker A.O. Smith (AOS) and financial data and analytics provider S&P Global (SPGI). S&P Global was formerly known as McGraw Hill Financial.New highs included designer of organic LED devices Universal Display (OLED), chip designer Nvidia (NVDA), software developer Cadence Design Systems (CDNS), Broadridge Financial Solutions (BR) and chip designer MaxLinear (MXL).Economic reports released Tuesday offered grist for the bears and bulls alike.For the bears: The Richmond Federal Reserve's manufacturing index for May was weaker than expected. Wall Street had projected a reading of 8, but the figure came in at -1, a sign of contraction. In April, the reading was 14. Manufacturing weakness has been a concern in recent months. U.S. manufacturing accounts for about 12% of GDP.For the bulls: New-home sales in April trounced expectations. The Street's consensus estimate was 523,000, but the economy posted 619,000 -- a stunning 18% beat and the highest level in more than eight years. The figure easily topped the entire range of estimates, which ran from a low of 510,000 to a high of 530,000.Homebuilder stocks rose in response, with gains mostly in the 3% to 5% range, but many of the stocks remain far off their highs. Toll Brothers (TOL) jumped more than 8% Tuesday on a strong quarterly report, but the stock was still about 30% below its August peak.Two homebuilder stocks have better-looking charts than most in their group. D.R. Horton (DHI) is 8% off its high, and NVR (NVR) is only 5% off its high.

LGI Homes (LGIH), an IBD 50 stock that's near a buy point, reported accelerating growth in April, driving its stock higher early Thursday.That and an upbeat earnings report from housing products installer Installed Building Products (IBP) pointed to continuing strong housing sector growth.IBD's Take: How does Installed Building Products stack up vs. rivals? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupWoodlands, Texas-based LGI Homes said April home closings soared 27.7% to 341 homes, up from 267 in the same month a year earlier. The entry-level and single-family homebuilder ended the first four months of 2016 with 1,185 home closings, a 26.3% jump from the same period in 2015.The homebuilder is also in the IBD Sector Leaders group, and its stock is working on a 3-1/2-month cup-with-handle base with a 29.87 buy point. It rose as much as 3% intraday before closing up 1.6% at 27.98 on the stock market today.LGI is due to report first-quarter results next Tuesday. Analysts' consensus is for earnings per share minus one-time items to jump 58% to 52 cents on a 39% hike in revenue to $167.6 million. The company is growing rapidly beyond its Lone Star state home base, and investors will key in on Q2 prospects as it expands into Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and other states.Meanwhile, Installed Building Products, which installs garage doors, rain gutters, shower doors and the like for homebuilders, reported Q1 earnings early Thursday that crushed estimates.Installed Building Products earned 19 cents a share -- 21 cents excluding various items -- vs. 5 cents in the same quarter last year. Either way, it's explosive growth and far above views for 11 cents.Revenue climbed nearly 48% to $191.7 million, well above Wall Street's expectation for $174 million and the fourth straight quarter of accelerating growth.Installed Building Products shares shot up 11.6% to 29.67, hitting a record 31.06 intraday. That pushes the stock well above a prior 25.80 buy point from a double-bottom base. But the stock on Thursday cleared another entry area at 28.28.Another installer, TopBuild (BLD), rose 3.2% to 32.18, briefly topping a 32.39 buy point. TopBuild, which came public in July 2015, will report earnings on May 11.Among other large, top-rated homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and NVR (NVR) all fell fractionally.

Pending-home sales rose more than expected in March, the National Association of Realtors said Wednesday.The pending-home sales index climbed 1.4% to 110.5, a 10-month high. Economists had expected a 0.5% increase, though February was revised down slightly.The pending-home sales index tracks existing-home contract signings. It gives a good indication of what actual existing-home sales closings -- which is what the monthly existing home sales data track -- will be in the following month or two."This spring's surprisingly low mortgage rates are easing some of the affordability pressures potential buyers are experiencing and are taking away some of the sting from home prices that are still rising too fast and above wage growth," said Lawrence Yun, NAR chief economist, in a statement.But Yun noted that pending sales have fallen four of the last five months, amid rapid price appreciation in that part of the country. Pending-home sales in the West fell to their lowest level since July 2014.Meanwhile, mortgage applications fell 4.1% in the week ended April 22, the Mortgage Bankers Association said. Purchase applications slid 2.4% and refinancing activity 5%, as the 30-year Treasury yield rose 2 basis  points to 3.85%.Wednesday's reports cap a flurry of mixed housing data.Shares of D.R. Horton rose fractionally on the stock market today. NVR stock dipped.

The stock market held its gains in afternoon trading Monday, as the Nasdaq made a favorable move on its chart.The Nasdaq rose 0.6% and was inching back above its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq 100 looked better as it jumped 0.6% and separated itself a bit above its own 50-day line. The index of the 100 largest nonfinancial Nasdaq listings never went below the 50-day average last week.Netflix (NFLX), one of the largest Nasdaq components, was up 3% in the highest volume on Stocks On The Move. The video streaming company announces results after the close today.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were also up 0.6% each, although both remained below their 50-day averages, meaning there's still reason to be suspicious about a rebound in the market.Volume was tracking lower, which was a surprise given that the prior session's trading slowed ahead of the three-day weekend. Also curious was the fact that only a few stocks were up in heavy volume.Homebuilders continued to provide some interesting charts. D.R. Horton (DHI) was trying to break out past the 34.15 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. But both the price and volume activity was insufficient to view today's move as a rush of institutional buying. The relative strength line is not near a new high, which is another damper on the potential entry.Homebuilders have shot up to the top 10 of IBD's 197 industry rankings from below 50 six weeks ago. William Lyon Homes (WLH) and CalAtlantic Group (CAA) also are forming cup-with-handle bases and could be researched further.Health care stocks were mixed as pharmaceuticals and hospitals tumbled for a variety of reasons.HCA Holdings (HCA) slid 3% in about double its usual volume, breaking below the 50-day moving average. The hospital operator gave preliminary first-quarter results today, reporting sales of $10.623 billion, up 4% from a year ago. Earnings per share rose 2% to $1.74. The numbers were below expectations.IBD's hospital industry group was the worst performing in today's market. HCA is 6% below its 52-week high, but others are more than 20% below it.Baxter International (BAX) fell 1% in active trading but remained in a price advance that has taken the stock to record highs. Reports said the U.S. Justice Department is investigating sales practices of intravenous saline, including those sold by Baxter.Abiomed (ABMD), which makes the Impella heart pump, gapped down to a loss of 3.5% in big volume. The stock, which has been forming a base, fell to its 50-day line. There was no news on the wires.Among pharmaceuticals, Eli Lilly (LLY) and Incyte (INCY) plunged below their 50-day lines in heavy volume after the FDA declined to approve their rheumatoid arthritis drug, saying more clinical trials are necessary.RELATED:Eli Lilly, Incyte Stocks Break Key Levels After FDA Drug SetbackNetflix Earnings After The Close: What To Expect

New-home sales rose to an annual rate of 512,000 last month the Commerce Department said Wednesday, signaling a steady if unspectacular pace for housing activity.Economists had expected 510,000 in February. January sales were revised up to 502,000 from 494,000, but are still down 6.1% vs. a year earlier.The median sales price in February was $301,400, up 2.6% vs. a year earlier after declining in the prior two months. The number of homes for sale was the highest since October 2009, while homes underway hit the highest since the end of 2008.That suggests homebuilders are growing a little less cautious about ramping up construction. They've also had trouble finding qualified workers and securing attractive lots. KB Home (KBH) reports quarterly earnings after the market close.KB Home shares fell 1.8% near midday on the stock market today. Lennar (LEN) sank 0.6% and D.R. Horton (DHI) 0.8%. LGI Homes (LGIH) lost 2.1% and Pulte Group (PHM) 1%.Regionally, new-home sales surged 35.8% after tumbling 32.7% in January. Sales fell in the other three regions last month.

Housing starts fell more than expected in January, slipping 3.8% to an annualized 1.099 million, the Commerce Department said. While the East Coast storm known as "Snowzilla" was expected to slow things down, starts dipped in every region.Housing permits, an indication of future building activity, dipped 0.2% to 1.202 million, still coming in just ahead of expectations.Producer prices unexpectedly rose, while core PPI was the strongest since October 2014.Meanwhile, investors digested a speech from Boston Federal Reserve President Eric Rosengren late Tuesday signaling a break from the Fed's plan to gradually hike rates in anticipation that inflation will firm. He's not so sure and wants to wait until it's clear that inflation is trending higher.Industrial production rebounded much more strongly than expected in January, the Federal Reserve reported, a positive sign about activity at the nation's factories, utilities and mines. Factory activity was led auto production as General Motors (GM) and Ford Motor (F) and others continue to report strong sales.This afternoon, the Fed will release minutes from its January policy meeting, to offer more insight into how worried policymakers were about financial market turmoil and sluggish economic data.Single-family home construction starts fell 3.9% in January to an annualized 731,000, still up 3.5% from a year ago. Multi-family starts fell 2.5% on the month and were down 3.8% on the year.Home builder sentiment slipped to a nine-month low, but they still remain pretty upbeat despite lower customer traffic, the National Association of Home Builders reported on Tuesday.Home builders such as D.R. Horton (DHI) are targeting first-time homebuyers, who account for more than 40% of recent sales.Building permits were up 13.5% from a year ago in January. Single-family permits slipped 1.6% in January, but were still 9.6% above year-ago levels.While starts are down, housing completions climbed to an annualized 1.057 million, the most since November 2008. So in the short run, homebuilders are adding homes to the market and providing plenty of jobs.Separately, mortgage applications rose 8.2% in the week ended Feb. 12 after a 9.3% spike in the prior week, the Mortgage Bankers Association said. Refinancing activity shot up 16% after the prior week's 15.8% as mortgage rates fell for a sixth straight week. The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped 8 basis points to 3.83%, the lowest since last April. However, lower rates aren't fueling housing demand. The purchase applications index, which has been running at multi-year highs, fell 3.7% to a six-week low.The Boston Fed president signaled that the so-called doves are not so sure more rate hikes will be needed. Rosengren called for a "unhurried . . . more gradual approach" to normalizing rates in response to slow exports and financial market volatility. Alluding to the junk bond market, he noted firms are already facing higher borrowing costs. Rosengren is a voting Fed policymaker this year.Industrial production rose a stronger-than-expected 0.9% in January, the Federal Reserve said. The gain was led by a 5.4% jump in utilities output, thanks to a shift from unseasonably warm weather, after three months of declines. But manufacturing output unexpectedly rose 0.5% after falling the two prior months.Mining output -- including oil drilling -- was flat last month and down 9.8% vs. a year earlier.However, overall and manufacturing figures were revised to show slightly bigger declines in both November and December.The factory output increase was split between nondurables, such as food, and durables. While production of electrical equipment and appliances fell, that was more than offset by a boost in auto production.The vehicle production gain came amid a better-than-expected month for U.S. auto sales, led by General Motors, Ford and other automakers. GM and Ford shares rose about 1% soon after the opening bell on the stock market today, but have been weak amid troubles in various regions overseas and concerns that U.S. auto sales have peaked.Capacity utilization rose to 77.1% from 76.4%. Factory capacity utilization rose to 76.1% from 75.8%, but is still even with where it was a year ago.Several other reports, including the Institute for Supply Management, showed manufacturing retreating in January. On Tuesday, the New York Fed's Empire State manufacturing index signaled factories are still in a deep contraction this month.The producer price index rose 0.1% in January, the Labor Department said. Excluding food and energy, the PPI rose 0.4%, the most since October 2014. Wall Street had expected a 0.2% drop for the PPI and a 0.1% dip for the core PPI.Overall prices rose due to a 0.7% gain in services costs offsetting a 0.5% drop in goods prices.Year over year, PPI fell 0.2%, core PPI rose 0.6% and services prices advanced 0.9%.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) pops as the stock market closes higher for the fourth straight week. But breakouts remains hesitant. Stocks strengthened and were near session highs in late-afternoon trading Tuesday, helped by comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen that were perceived as dovish once again by Wall Street.Chip-equipment stocks helped lift the Nasdaq to a 1.5% gain. Small caps also did well, with the Russell 2000 up 1.7%. The S&P 500 added 0.8%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%.Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels. Money flowed into bonds, as the 10-year Treasury yield tumbled 7 basis points to 1.82%.In a speech to the Economic Club of New York, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said that it is appropriate for U.S. central bankers to “proceed cautiously” in raising interest rates.Big gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included chip-equipment firm Lam Research (LRCX). It surged past an 80.53 cup-with-handle buy point, rising 3% to 81.77. The stock is well within buy range.In economic news, consumer confidence came in better than expected, according to the latest data from the Conference Board. The index rose to 96.2 from a prior reading of 92.2. Economists expected a smaller increase to 94. Meanwhile, the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Index for January showed home prices rising 5.7% from a year earlier, mostly in line with expectations.IBD's homebuilding group outperformed, rising about 2.5%. Lennar (LEN) popped 3% after reporting solid earnings before the open. D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR) extended gains by more than 3% each after recent breakouts.In the stock market today, buyers were in Dave & Busters (PLAY) ahead of its earnings report, due after the close. Shares rose 4%. After a 32% pullback, the stock is only 7% off its 52-week high. The consensus estimate calls for profit of 43 cents a share, up 23% from a year before. Sales are seen rising 11% to $229.4 million.The IBD 50 outperformed nicely, with about 10 names up 2% or more. TAL Education (XRS), Broadsoft (BSFT), Prestige Brands (PBH) and Leaderboard name Edwards Lifesciences (EW) all showed gains of 3% or more.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for May delivery slumped nearly 3% to $38.25 a barrel.
