Stocks were higher but falling off opening highs going into the lunch hour Wednesday as an analyst upgrade propelled Google above a key support level.The Nasdaq advanced 1.4% and the S&P 500 rose 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.4% in the stock market today. Volume was running heavier on the NYSE and lighter on the Nasdaq, compared with the same time Tuesday.The Shanghai Composite fell 1.3% overnight. For the week so far, it's down 16.6%. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 4.6% on Tuesday.In a speech and Q&A Wednesday, New York Fed's William Dudley said the case for a September interest rate increase was "less compelling" because of a slowdown in China, falling commodity prices and gyrations in the financial markets.Among IBD 50 stocks, 39 were higher and 11 were lower. Google (GOOGL) was the top performer on the elite list, up more than 3%. Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to conviction buy from neutral and boosted its price target to 800 from 660. It trades near 632. The move put Google back above its 10-week moving average.The analysts said Google is "in the early stages of a multiyear cycle to expand margins, which will drive earnings outperformance and multiple expansion."Universal Insurance (UVE) was the worst performer, down 6%. It was losing support at its 200-day moving average in above-average volume.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2%. It's found support at its 200-day line and trying to steady itself after a wild ride Monday that saw the stock range 36% from low to high. It still trades below its 50-day line.Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 1% in above-average volume as it struggled for support at its 50-day line and was trading near a 28.80 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Before the open, durable goods orders beat expectations, giving stock index futures a quick boost.

Apple's (AAPL) stock price moved higher Monday after the iPhone maker's price target was hiked, while CyberArk (CYBR) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) were upgraded.Canaccord Genuity maintained its buy rating on Apple and raised its price target to 160 from 155. Apple shares closed up 1.55% to 115.21 on the stock market today.CyberArk shares gapped up 3.8% to 49.46 after it was upgraded to buy at Deutsche Bank. The cybersecurity software developer focuses on advanced cyberthreats such as those that use insider privileges to attack enterprises.Shares of athletic wear maker Lululemon Athletica rose 2% to 53.98 after it was upgraded to overweight at Morgan Stanley and given a 68 price target. Lululemon stock sank 19% over a two-session period earlier this month after it offered disappointing guidance.Google (GOOGL) shares climbed 0.9% to 666.98 after its price target was raised to 847 from 720 by JMP Securities, which reiterated its market outperform rating on the stock.Another tech giant, Intel (INTC), had its price target lowered to 31 from 32 at Mizuho, but still saw its shares rise 0.5% Monday.PayPal (PYPL) rose 4% after it was upgraded to hold from buy with a 40 price target at Stifel Nicolaus.Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) was downgraded to sector perform from outperform at RBC Capital Markets and had its price target lowered to 100 from 107. Its stock price fell 3.4%.Last week, the brewing giant said it plans to make an offer for rival SABMiller.Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) was downgraded to hold from buy at Deutsche Bank. Shares lost 2.9%.Big pharma firm Eli Lilly (LLY) was maintained at neutral by JPMorgan and given a 90 price target. In July, JPMorgan gave the stock an 80 price target. Eli Lilly's stock price lost 1% Monday.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) was maintained at neutral by Nomura Securities and given a 40 price target, which is below most recent analyst PTs. Shares dipped 1.3% Monday.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter @IBD_VCariaga.

It's a good thing when bad news doesn't have much of an effect on stocks. That's exactly what's happening with homebuilders. So far this week, homebuilders have digested some negative housing market data. On Monday, the Commerce Department said new-home sales tumbled 11.5% in September to an annual rate of 468,000 units. That badly missed estimates for 549,000 units. Sales…

Major averages lost ground Thursday and tech stocks lagged, but the losses weren't ominous with less than two hours remaining in the session.The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Wednesday's levels in the stock market today.In economic news, the first look at Q3 GDP showed growth of 1.5%, a tad below the consensus estimate of 1.7% and a sharp slowdown from 3.9% growth in Q2. Meanwhile, weekly jobless claims fell more than expected and pending-home sales for September missed badly.Top-rated homebuilders slumped on the weak housing data. D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH) showed losses ranging from 4 to 5%.In the health care space, Allergan (AGN) jumped 6.5% after the drugmaker confirmed that it's in early talks with Pfizer (PFE) about a merger. Shares of Pfizer fell 3%.Ellie Mae (ELLI) was a big winner inside the IBD 50 . Shares jumped 5% after the company reported strong earnings late Wednesday. Shares are up 11% so far this week. Ellie Mae is back above its 10-week moving average as it approaches its all-time high of 82.92 .On the downside, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) crashed 20% after the chip designer reported a sharp deceleration in Q3 earnings growth and flat sales.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) was another casualty, cratering 20%. Late Wednesday, it reported Q3 EPS of $1 a share, 29 cents below the consensus estimate. Revenue also missed.Starbucks (SBUX) lost 2% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Former leaders Baidu (BIDU) and LinkedIn (LNKD) are also set to report.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Stocks staged a late rally Thursday but still ended modestly lower amid weaker-than-expected economic data. The Nasdaq fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%, and the S&P 500 eased a fraction. Volume fell 13% on the NYSE and 10% on the Nasdaq compared to Wednesday, according to preliminary data.

In economic news, Q3 GDP expanded at a 1.5% annual rate, below Wall Street estimates for a 1.7% gain and well below Q2's 3.9% increase. Weekly jobless claims fell more than expected and pending-home sales for September were much weaker than expected.
Top-rated homebuilders slumped on the weak housing data. D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH) each fell about 4%.
Tech stocks led the declines in the stock market today.

F5 Networks (FFIV) plunged 9% after BMO Capital Markets and RBC Capital Markets downgraded the stock when the network applications and cybersecurity company's quarterly revenue and guidance missed analysts' expectations. The stock hit its lowest level in more than a year intraday Thursday and is 19% off its 52-week high.

LinkedIn (LNKD) soared after the close on a strong Q3 earnings report. The stock has been languishing, ending the regular session 21% off its 52-week high. Also, its 200-day line has been above its 50-day line since June, an added sign of weakness.

Starbucks (SBUX) was down in post-session trading following its quarterly earnings report. Profit for the latest quarter rose 16% to 43 cents, matching Wall Street estimates. Revenue rose 18% to $4.9 billion, beating views. But the coffee seller's outlook for the current quarter was weaker than expected.
The stock ended 6% above a 59.06 buy point Thursday, just out of buying range.

SolarCity (SCTY) plunged in post-session trade after the solar panel installer's Q3 results disappointed investors. Earlier, rival SunPower (SPWR) gapped up and soared 11% after a much better than expected Q3 report.
CVS (CVS), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and Mylan (MYL) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Friday.

Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) has built the right side of a base ahead of an earnings report due Monday morning. The stock stopped just short of a 54.53 intraday high made on June 8, just as the base's left side was beginning to be built. The stock has made a big move in the past few weeks and could use…
Mortgage applications surged 12% in the latest week, the latest in a series of choppy weeks as lenders and borrowers grapple with new disclosure rules.

The big jump in the Mortgage Bankers Association's Oct. 16 weekly index reading followed a 28% plunge the prior week, which followed a 26% jump the week before that. MBA said it expects volume to "remain volatile over the next few weeks."

Still, the trend is generally up for mortgage applications. The MBA's purchase index stands 9% higher than the same week a year ago. Even though analysts have predicted the end of the refinancing boom, interest rates ticked 4 basis points lower during the week, helping the MBA's refinance index jump 9% during the week. At 3.95%, the average 30-year fixed-year rate was the lowest since May.

Higher volume for mortgages adds to other data pointing to a strengthening housing market. Homebuilder sentiment is at a 10-year high, housing starts are near multiyear bests and builders like Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) have seen double-digit order growth this year. On Thursday the National Association of Realtors is expected to report an increase in sales of existing homes.

The added interest is helping buoy stocks like builder D.R. Horton (DHI) and housing analytics provider CoreLogic (CLGX). After strong gains Tuesday, Lennar and D.R. Horton shares were little changed Wednesday morning, while KB Home fell 0.4%. CoreLogic, which reports quarterly results after the close, fell 0.5%.Mortgage applications surged 12% in the latest week, the latest in a series of choppy weeks as lenders and borrowers grapple with new disclosure rules.The big jump in the Mortgage Bankers Association's Oct. 16 weekly index reading followed a 28% plunge the prior week, which followed a 26% jump the week before that. Stock indexes posted losses Tuesday as the Nasdaq ran into resistance at its 200-day line. The Nasdaq lost 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each trimmed 0.1%.
Volume in the stock market today was somewhat higher than Monday's meek pace. Technically, the action met the definition of distribution in the Nasdaq, but the signal was rather weak.

The 200-day line repelled the Nasdaq for a second straight day. The Nasdaq is testing the 200-day line after retaking the 50-day line Thursday. If the Nasdaq turns the 200-day line into support, the next test would be the 5,000 level which the Nasdaq lost in August.
Among IBD's 197 industry groups, the day's worst performing groups included the struggling medical stocks. A former leader, the medical sector now rates No. 21 of 33 sectors in Tuesday's IBD.

Top gainers among industry groups Tuesday included gold miners, oil and homebuilders. The latter was helped by a report on September housing starts. The total came 5% higher than the Street's consensus estimate and higher than any estimate in the entire range.
However, most of the gain was in starts for apartments and condominiums. Multifamily units rose 18%. Single-family homes rose 0.3%.

Little wonder that 22 of the 25 stocks in the Building-Residential/Commercial industry group moved in volume 20% to 70% below average. Still, most housing stocks Tuesday delivered price gains of 2% to 3%.
D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose more than 2% and regained their 50-day lines in below-average volume.
The housing sector has one built-in advantage over many other sectors in this market. Homebuilders don't have to worry too much about the economic slowdown in China.

After the close, Discover Financial Services (DFS) reported Q3 results. Earnings topped views by 5 cents a share, or roughly 4%, while revenue was 1% shy of the Street's consensus estimate. The stock lost 0.5% in the regular session but rose 1.4% after hours.

Starts in the closely watched single-family sector rose 0.3% and were up 12% vs. a year ago, the 6th…

Stocks ended lower in light volume Monday on concerns that the Federal Reserve appears poised to raise interest rates as early as next month. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 1%. Volume fell 14% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.Traders increased their bets that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates following Friday's strong jobs report. That could saddle consumers with higher borrowing costs and boost the dollar, which could slow the U.S. economy.Leisure and discretionary consumer stocks were hit hardest in the stock market todayOnline travel broker Priceline.com (PCLN) plunged nearly 10% after a weak Q4 outlook overshadowed a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report.The stock sank below a 1394.10 buy point of a cup-type base and sliced through its 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, gambling stocks fell on expectations of weakness in the Chinese gambling enclave of Macau, the world's top gaming destination. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell more than 8%. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) sank 6% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slipped 2%.On the upside, IBD 50 stock LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 2% as it continues to climb the right side of a deep, cup-type base with a 276.28 buy point.D.R. Horton (DHI), Luxoft (LXFT), Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) and Amdocs (DOX) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data scheduled for Tuesday include import and export prices for October and wholesale inventories for September.

Stocks ended mixed Tuesday in a mostly quiet session, but it was far from quiet when it came to Apple (AAPL) and semiconductor stocks. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow opened lower but ended near session highs as buyers came into the market in afternoon trading. The Nasdaq lost nearly 0.9% early but trimmed losses to 0.2% by the close.…

D.R. Horton (DHI) is settling down and hugging support at its 50-day moving average. It's also forming a potential base. The stock has corrected a little less than 14%, paving the way for a possible flat base. But it needs a little more time, as a flat base takes at least five weeks to form.D.R. Horton has been volatile in recent months. It erased a double-digit gain from a breakout past a 28.80 buy point in a cup-with-handle base in August. A second try above the 28.80 trigger resulted in the same fate in late September.Since the stock rose less than 20% from the 28.80 buy point, a new base from here would be the second part of a base-on-base pattern.The stock holds an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of D+, which is not inspiring. But the rating is at least stabilizing. What is inspiring is that overall fund ownership continued to improve in the third quarter; 964 mutual funds owned shares, up from 852 three periods before that.The highly rated Fidelity Contrafund took a position in the latest reported quarter.Fort Worth, Texas-based D.R. Horton is the nation's biggest homebuilder. According to the National Association of Homebuilders, the company sold 30,455 homes in 2014. This compared to about 21,000 homes for Lennar (LEN) and nearly 17,200 for Pulte (PHM).D.R. Horton builds homes under its namesake brand, as well as Express Homes and Emerald Homes labels.The firm's earnings grew 5% to 88% in the latest four quarters. Over the same period, sales rose 33% to 38%.The company has boosted its top line by double digits for 16 straight quarters.An improving job market and low interest rates are a couple of positives for the overall housing market.D.R. Horton is also benefiting from higher average prices.In its fiscal third quarter ended in June, its average sales price was $290,000, up 7% from a year ago.

Alphabet (GOOGL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) weighed on the Nasdaq ahead of their earnings reports, due Thursday after the close. Both names lost around 3%. Earlier today, Amazon announced big hiring plans for the holiday season.
The Dow was resilient in light of weak earnings from IBM (IBM) late Monday. Shares slumped 6% after the company reported its 14th straight quarter of declining year-over-year sales.

Homebuilders did well after September housing-start data came in better than expected. Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) moved back above their 50-day moving averages, rising 2% each.

Shares of General Electric (GE) moved lower Tuesday despite an analyst upgrade, while JetBlue Airways (JBLU) was one of several airlines to receive analyst downgrades ahead of third-quarter earnings reports.

William Blair upgraded General Electric to outperform from market perform with a 32 price target, citing upside potential from its Alstom energy-unit acquisition and data-analytics business, as well as the possibility of shares doubling to 60 by 2020.

GE reports Q3 earnings on Friday. The industrial conglomerate is expected to earn 26 cents a share, down 31.6% from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to slide 20.8% to $28.6 billion.

Also on Tuesday, GE confirmed that it agreed to sell its Commercial Distribution Finance business, its North American Vendor Finance unit and its Corporate Finance business to Wells Fargo (WFC). Terms weren't disclosed, but the assets are worth about $32 billion.
GE shares closed down 0.8% on the stock market today.
Another industrial giant, United Technologies (UTX), fell 1.2% after it was downgraded to sector perform by RBC Capital.
JPMorgan downgraded JetBlue to neutral from overweight but maintained its 27 price target. JetBlue shares gapped down 7.9%.
Meanwhile, American Airlines (AAL) and Alaska Air (ALK) were downgraded to hold by Evercore ISI. American lost 1% Tuesday, while Alaska Air declined 5.2%.
Raymond James downgraded SkyWest (SKYW) to market perform with a 20 price target. SkyWest shares tumbled 7% after surging 11.4% on Monday.

VMware (VMW) was downgraded to market perform by JMP Securities. On Monday, VMware fell 8% on the news that it would remain publicly traded even after majority owner EMC (EMC) is acquired by Dell and other investors. VMware lost an additional 4.1% Tuesday.
Toll Bros. (TOL) fell 1.5% after rising earlier in the day following an upgrade to overweight by Morgan Stanley, which also gave the stock a 44 price target.

Among other homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI) fell 1.65% despite a price target hike to 31 from 28 by Barclays; Meritage (MTH) shares lost 1.4% even though its price target was raised to 44 from 43 by Barclays; and PulteGroup (PHM) fell about 3% after it was downgraded to underweight by Morgan Stanley.Shares of General Electric (GE) moved lower Tuesday despite an analyst upgrade, while JetBlue Airways (JBLU) was one of several airlines to receive analyst downgrades ahead of third-quarter earnings reports.William Blair upgraded General Electric to outperform from market perform with a 32 price target, citing upside potential from its Alstom energy-unit acquisition and data-analytics business, as well as the possibility of shares doubling to 60 by 2020.GE reports Q3 earnings on Friday. Home prices pick up S&P/Case-Shiller's 20-City Home Price Index ticked down 0.1% during June, but rose 5.0% vs. a year ago, the same as an upwardly revised May. The National Index was up 4.5% vs. a year ago in June, stronger than the 4.4% gain in May. Denver, Dallas, and San Francisco remain the hottest cities. New home sales jump…

Stock indexes wandered quietly to little effect Friday, apparently content to avoid more trouble. The Nasdaq added 0.3%, while the S&P 500 inched up 0.1%. Small caps outperformed as the S&P 600 popped 0.6%. The IBD 50, though, dropped 0.3%. Volume fell on both major exchanges. After Monday's wild intraday plunge, which took the Nasdaq 18% off its high, bulls…

With stocks showing a volatility that hasn't been seen in several years and bears saying, "I told you so," investors in need of positive news can look to Ambarella (AMBA), Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Illumina (ILMN), who have seen analysts raise their earnings estimates. Let's take a look: Ambarella Earnings Due Tuesday Ambarella, which reports second-quarter earnings…

Stock indexes cut their losses to normal proportions in afternoon trading Monday. The Nasdaq plunged 8.8% at the open and then patched over all but 0.4%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed their losses to 1% and 0.8%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today was heavy.Action was wild even among blue chips. Apple (AAPL), a member of the Dow, dropped 13% and then reversed to a 2% gain. Visa (V), also on the Dow, skidded almost 16% and then whipped north, erasing all but 0.7% of the loss.Starbucks (SBUX) spilled 20% lower in the first minute of trade and then surged to cut the loss to 0.4%. The opening dive took the stock below a 42.20 buy point from a January breakout.Even groups that recently had been showing some strength suffered. The homebuilder group dived 6.6% early and then rebounded to a loss of less than 1%.Several homebuilders triggered the 8% sell rule intraday, but one leader avoided that fate. D.R. Horton (DHI) dropped 4% below a 28.80 buy point and then bounced to 5% above the entry. In the context of the day's extreme action, D.R. Horton looked fairly good.Gold, which often does well when fear is high, swung from a 1% gain to a loss of 0.3%. Traders said that the metal was being tugged between buyers looking for a safe haven and sellers taking profits to offset losses in stocks.

Toll Bros. (TOL) missed quarterly estimates Tuesday but raised its margin guidance and sees more improvement next year. The luxury homebuilder's fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 32% to 36 cents a share. Excluding items, Toll Bros. earned 44 cents a share, according to Thomson Reuters. Analysts expected EPS of 49 cents. Revenue dipped 2.7% to $1.03 billion, below forecasts for $1.056 billion.

The earnings and sales miss came as the average home price delivered fell to $724,000 in Q3 from $732,000 a year earlier amid weaker economic growth earlier this year. Selling, general and administrative costs also rose to 11.3% of revenue from 10.4%, sending gross margin down to 19.8% from 22.7%.

But Toll Bros. expects Q4 margin to be about 26.7% and full-year margin of 26.2%, which is 20 basis points higher than its earlier full-year guidance. The company sees continued margin expansion in 2016.
Shares of Toll Bros. closed down 7.8% on the stock market today amid a broad market reversal.

Other builders fared better, helped by data showing sales of new homes rose 5.4% last month as prices climbed 3%.Lennar (LEN) ended down 3.8%, Pulte Group (PHM) 3.6%, D.R. Horton (DHI) 4.2%, and KB Home (KBH) 2.8%.
"We believe we have significant room for growth and additional profitability in calendar 2016 and beyond," Toll Bros. CEO Douglas Yearley said in a conference call.
He added later, "This housing recovery appears to be built on a very solid foundation."
He also noted that there is pent-up demand among buyers and current industrywide production is improved but still well below the industry norm.
Contracts rose 30% in Q3, with growth continuing to accelerate from 25% in Q2, 24% in Q1 and 16% in Q4 of fiscal 2014. In the first four weeks of August, contracts were up 16%.

At the end of last quarter Toll Bros. had a backlog of $3.69 billion and 4,447 units, up 19% in dollars and 6% in units — the highest backlog for any quarter-end since Q2 2007. Additionally, average price of homes in the backlog was $829,000, up from $737,000 a year earlier.

What's the cardinal rule of real estate? It all comes down to location, location, location. One of the most closely watched national price indexes, S&P/Case-Shiller, ticked down 0.1% in June, but was up 5.0% for the year. That was the same as in May, but just missed expectations of a 5.2% yearly gain. Accelerating prices are great for sellers, but…

The latest housing data out Tuesday provided more evidence that the sector could drive further growth in the U.S., contrasting with stocks, which continued to sell off over fears of a weaker Chinese economy. Sales of new single-family homes in July rose 5.4% vs. June to an annualized pace of 507,000, the Commerce Department said. While it fell short of…

Stocks lost steam late Tuesday, but were still on pace to end a five-day rout. The Nasdaq climbed 2.3% and the S&P 500 was up 1.5%. They had been up as much as 3.6% and 2.9%, respectively, at Tuesday's high. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.7% in the stock market today. Volume was still tracking sharply lower on both major exchanges compared with the same time Monday.Despite the rebound losing steam, some stocks stayed near their session highs.Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP) rallied nearly 7%. The stock had a wild day Monday, where it ended down about 8% after plunging 24%. Still, that drop erased a 22% gain past a 22.10 buy point from a cup base — a sell signal.Cambrex (CBM) climbed 5% and was on pace to snap a five-session slide. It too triggered a sell signal Monday after wiping out a double-digit gain from a breakout past a 41.80 handle buy point.Skechers USA (SKX) rallied 5% after finding support near its 50-day line Monday.On the downside, homebuilders D.R. Horton (DHI) and Taylor Morrison Home (TMHC) lost 1% each after turning tail. But the latter appeared to be finding support at its 200-day line. Earlier, the Commerce Department reported July new-home sales that came in a little shy of expectations.

If investors are looking to the high-end of the housing market for some good news as homebuilder stocks got caught in the market's continued tumble on Monday, they may be disappointed. Luxury homebuilder Toll Brothers (TOL) is expected to report a 7% decline in year-over-year earnings when its reports its July ending third-quarter results Tuesday, to 49 cents per share,…

Major averages rose to session highs Wednesday afternoon after a lackluster start. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%; the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.7% and the Nasdaq gained 0.5%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume levels were tracking higher than Tuesday's levels, and more so on the NYSE in the stock market today.
General Electric (GE), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) outperformed in the Dow.

The latter two were helped by higher oil prices. Crude oil futures jumped $2.54, or 5.7%, to $47.13 a barrel. Earlier today, the Energy Information Administration said crude supplies fell by 2.1 million barrels last week. On Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute said supplies fell by 3.1 million barrels.

Biotechs and homebuilders were weak even as builder confidence reached its highest level in nearly a decade, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo housing market index. But stocks such as LGI Homes (LGIH), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) are not showing sell signals.
Among the day's movers, Fitbit (FIT) jumped 9%, one day after Pacific Crest started coverage of the firm with an overweight rating and a 47 price target.
Molson Coors Brewing (TAP) was the top percentage gainer in the S&P 500, rising nearly 13% on news that Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) has approached U.K.-listed SABMiller about a takeover.

The Fed's decision on interest rates is due Thursday afternoon. Amid a delicate global outlook, an increasing number of economists expect a rate hike, although futures traders are still skeptical. Existing-home sales rose to an 8-year high in July, but millennials were still missing in action as the share of first-time buyers fell to the lowest since January.

Existing-home sales surged to a stronger-than-expected 5.59 million annual rate, up 10.3% vs. a year earlier. Inventories are lean — the current supply is 4.8 months' worth. That's been pushing up prices, though they cooled 1% in July.
However, first-timers fell to 28% of the total in July, the lowest since January. That's down from 30% in June and May's 32%, the strongest since 2012.

Many homebuilders catering to first-time and millennial buyers have fared well, with shares of D.R. Horton (DHI), LGI Homes (LGIH) and Lennar (LEN) hitting longtime or record highs over the past week, though so has luxury builder Toll Bros. (TOL). D.R. Horton, Lennar and Toll Bros. fell 1%-2% Thursday afternoon, though LGI Homes fell 5%.Existing-home sales rose to an 8-year high in July, but millennials were still missing in action as the share of first-time buyers fell to the lowest since January.Existing-home sales surged to a stronger-than-expected 5.59 million annual rate, up 10.3% vs. a year earlier. Major averages were still in the red, but rallied off session lows Wednesday as Wall Street digested the minutes from the July 29 Fed meeting.

The S&P 500 pierced its 200-day moving average, falling 1.3% early, but recovered for a loss of just 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq gave up 0.2% each. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well above Tuesday's levels.

The Fed minutes showed that a September rate hike is still on the table, with broad support for a rate hike soon. As of Tuesday's close, the chances of a rate hike in September were 45%, according to CME Group FedWatch.
Breadth was terrible early as NYSE decliners outnumbered advancers by more than 4-to-1. In late afternoon the trading the ratio was less than 2-to-1 on both exchanges.

Many of the day's worst-performing industry groups in the stock market today hailed from the oil and gas sector as benchmark WTI crude oil lost 5% to 40.58 a barrel. Government data showed an unexpected weekly climb in crude inventories.
Among the day's movers,Target (TGT) reversed in spectacular fashion after Wall Street initially cheered its earnings report. Shares popped 5% early, but fell back to mostly unchanged.
Meanwhile, D.R. Horton (DHI) was trying for its seventh gain in eight session. Shares rose 2%. It's extended after a recent breakout over a 28.80 cup-with-handle buy point.
Ambarella (AMBA) fought back after early weakness, rising 0.3%. Its 10-week moving average had been a support level since a base breakout in March, but not anymore.

WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) finally looks like it's ready to build a new base after a successful breakout in February over a 38.74 buy point. New homes are being built and kitchens are getting remodeled. From a 2009 low, housing starts have been recovering, peaking in July at an annualized 1.161 million units. It's not exactly the boom year of 2005, when housing starts topped 2 million units. Also, building slowed some in August, the most recently reported month. But the recovery has been a…

The market uptrend is still intact, but selling pressure has hit some top stocks in leading industry groups this week. One or two days of selling doesn't mean a leader's run is over, but it's worth paying attention to, especially when it comes soon after a breakout.

In the airline space, a breakout for SkyWest (SKYW) looked great on Monday when shares surged 11% in huge volume. It cleared a base with an 18.05 buy point, but shares fell hard the next day, down 7%, then gained 1% Wednesday — not the type of price action you want to see after a breakout.

Meanwhile, shares of JetBlue (JBLU) slumped 8% in heavy volume Tuesday on disappointing September traffic data. A JPMorgan downgrade didn't help matters. JetBlue extended losses Wednesday, giving up its 50-day moving average.
The news isn't all bad in the group. Delta Air Lines (DAL) is near the top of a long consolidation, and Hawaiian (HA) is holding gains nicely after a recent breakout.
In the tech service group, a recent breakout by Epam Systems (EPAM) looked good for a few days, but shares fell nearly 6% Tuesday in big volume and recovered almost nothing Wednesday.
It's still holding above a 75.93 entry, but big sellers were clearly in the stock Tuesday.
One name acting right in the group is Tyler Technologies (TYL). It's holding comfortably above a 145.84 buy point and starting to show some tight weekly closes, a sign of strength and support.
Elsewhere, top-rated homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) can't get out of its own way. It gave up its 50-day moving average Wednesday, falling nearly 4% in heavy volume.
The breach of the 50-day line comes after the stock round-tripped a double-digit gain from a 28.80 buy point, not once but twice.

Several other builders took hits, including LGI Homes (LGIH), the outright leader in the group. It's still holding above its 50-day moving average, but big sellers have been in the stock the past two sessions. Its two-day decline now stands at 10%.
Separately, retail-related industry groups faced stiff selling pressure Wednesday after September retail sales disappointed.
What was most concerning about the report was that sluggish sales came during the back-to-school shopping period, raising concerns about the holiday shopping season.
The retail sector was also rattled by an earnings warning from industry titan Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).
Late in Wednesday's session, six of the day's worst-10 performing groups hailed from the sector.
Just one group ranked inside the top 40 of IBD's 197 industry group rankings as of Tuesday's close.
The consumer electronics group had been climbing in recent weeks, but it fell more than 3% Wednesday, weighed down by Best Buy's (BBY) 6% drop.

Headed into Wednesday, Best Buy had been working on a cup-with-handle base with a 39.19 buy point.The market uptrend is still intact, but selling pressure has hit some top stocks in leading industry groups this week. Stocks got hammered Monday as big sellers again made their presence felt. The Nasdaq slumped 3%, closing near its session low. It's getting close to the 4500 level, which it has stayed above on a closing basis since late October. Health care stocks, which make up about 16% of the Nasdaq composite, again came under heavy fire. IBD's biotech industry…
Stocks were down sharply but off session lows ahead of Fed minutes from the July meeting, out at 2 p.m. ET.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 shed 0.9% each, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1%. All three indexes are trading below their 50-day moving averages. The Dow has fared worst and is now nearly 6% off its May high. Volume was tracking well above Tuesday's pace on both exchanges.

Leaders up in volume were scarce in the stock market today. Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) continued to follow through on a recent breakout, hitting a new high and adding nearly 2% in active trade. The stock is now extended 12% past a 28.80 buy point it cleared on July 30.

Discount retailer Target (TGT) was lower after reversing an early 5% gain. Before the open Target reported Q2 results that topped expectations, but investor enthusiasm quickly waned. The stock is shaping a potential flat base and has a 73 Composite Rating.

Wal-Mart (WMT), meanwhile, hit a 52-week low in big volume Wednesday. Wal-Mart shares are down more than 20% year to date. On Tuesday ,the Dow component disappointed Wall Street with second-quarter earnings below expectations.
Consumer prices edged up 0.1% in July, slightly below forecasts and down from a 0.3% climb in June.

Nearly all industry groups were lower in early afternoon trading, with energy groups taking particularly hard hits. The consumer price index took a step back in July, rising 0.1%, vs. 0.3% in June. Economists had expected 0.2%. The "core" measure, which strips out food and energy, also rose just 0.1%, down from 0.2% in June. It was up 1.8% vs. a year ago, the same as in June, and not far from the Federal Reserve's 2% target.…

Builders broke ground in July on the most homes since 2007, another sign of the housing market's gathering momentum. That helped boost several homebuilder stocks to longtime highs Tuesday, even as the major market indexes retreated.Starts ran at an annual pace of 1.21 million, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, above forecasts and 0.2% above an upwardly revised June. Even better: Single-family starts leapt 12.8%, also to near 8-year highs.Permits, which foreshadow starts, dived 16%, led by a 60% drop in the Northeast, where a New York tax credit that expired in June had pulled activity dramatically forward in the spring months.A host of other data suggests the housing market may have finally hit its stride and may even be poised to lead the economy."We're seeing the market successfully transition from an investor-driven recovery to one that is being driven by traditional buyers," said Daren Blomquist, vice president for housing data firm RealtyTrac. "That's a very good thing because it's more sustainable for the long term."Cash Is No Longer KingSales of existing homes surged to the fastest pace since 2009 in May, helped by first-time buyers. They represented 32% of purchases in May, the most since 2012 but still solidly below the long-term average of about 40%. June existing-home data will be released Thursday.All-cash sales are also dwindling. Those sales made up 31.9% of the total in May, CoreLogic said, the lowest since July 2008. Cash sales are often considered a proxy for investor, rather than owner-occupied, purchases.Cash buyers are also frequently foreign, Blomquist said, and their presence in the market has helped push up prices. "We're seeing those pull back and that is opening the door for the traditional buyers. But if global influences push more buyers back into U.S. real estate that could put upward pressure on prices."As inventory of both existing and new homes remains tight, prices are likely to keep surging, challenging many traditional buyers, especially first-timers.But as the job market heats up, homeownership is starting to seem more attractive — and more feasible — even for millennials.Homebuilder Stocks RiseShares of homebuilders catering to first-time buyers have done especially well.D.R. Horton (DHI) opened an entry-level division, Express Homes, in early 2014. The firm's stock rose 1.4% to a 9-year high. LGI Homes (LGIH), also targeting the entry level market, edged higher Tuesday after hitting a record high Monday. Shares are up 40% since it reported strong earnings on Aug. 5.Lennar (LEN), which also has significant first-time buyers and multiunit construction, rose 3.1%, hitting an 8-1/2-year high.Even luxury-focused Toll Bros. (TOL) advanced, rising 2.8% to its best level in nearly 10 years.The housing market isn't too affected by China, Greece and other overseas concerns, and as those headwinds have rocked markets in recent weeks, that's reduced mortgage rates. While most analysts expect an initial Federal Reserve rate hike in September, Blomquist believes it will turn out to be a "non-event."All that is making homebuilders seem like a relatively safe-haven growth sector right now.IBD's Building-Residential Commercial group was rated a solid No. 34 out of 197 industries as of Monday's close, up from 98 just six weeks ago.July's hot starts pace was still about 40% lower than it was during the bubble years of 2005-06, and most analysts think that's healthy. Blomquist calls builders "wisely cautious."But a closely watched survey of sentiment from the National Association of Home Builders hit the highest point in a decade in its August read, out Monday.The NAHB's future sales sub-index "has a decent track record of leading starts by about six months or so," ITG Chief Economist Steve Blitz wrote in a client note. "The relationship suggests single-family starts getting up to 800,000 units (annualized) in the next several months."Single-family homes currently account for 65% of total starts, down from 80% before the bubble. As homeownership has tumbled to a 48-year low, apartment building has surged to meet demand for rentals.Blomquist thinks it's OK if inventory stays tighter than in the past. There have been about five months' worth of homes available in 2015, compared to the long-term average of six months.Still, lean supply coupled with strong demand is pushing up prices."The majority of markets are still affordable by historical standards," Blomquist said. "The ones that are unaffordable by historical standards are the big markets with the most jobs. So it is a concern to start to see the affordability equation break down."

A couple of Spotlight stocks are testing support at their 50-day moving averages while another triggered a sell rule Thursday as the market sank. Online postal services retailer Stamps.com (STMP) slipped below its key support line as it works on a flat base-on-base with a buy point at 88.97. The stock has traded mostly sideways after a sharp pullback from a new high on Aug. 19.Stamps' fading relative strength line and D- Accumulation/Distribution indicate weakness. The stock has been volatile lately, rebounding from a failed breakout past a prior 75.30 buy point before again retreating .Stamps soared 28% Aug. 7 after posting a better-than-expected 76% jump in Q2 earnings. Profit and sales growth have accelerated in recent quarters. However, profit growth is expected to slow in the current quarter, rising 25% to 89 cents a share from the same period last year.Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) is getting support at its 50-day line. That technically puts the stock in a secondary buy area, but investors should be cautious, with the market's uptrend currently under pressure.The stock is 6% past a 28.80 cup-with-handle entry, just out of buying range, but it had been up as much as 15%. Those who bought at the July 30 breakout should take care to prevent a nice gain from slipping away.Meanwhile, Paycom Software (PAYC) sliced through its 50-day line in heavy volume Thursday, once again triggering a sell signal by falling 8% below a 39.27 buy point.The producer of cloud-based human resources management software initially cleared the buy point Aug. 17 in heavy volume before rolling over and hitting the 8% sell rule five days later.The stock retook the entry Sept. 15, but that was short-lived as the stock pulled back after a secondary share offering, triggering the 8% sell rule a second time.Paycom has posted strong profit and sales growth in recent quarters, but its technical indicators are bearish.
Stocks crumbled out of the starting gate into quick, broad losses Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.2%, the Nasdaq showed a 1.1% loss and the S&P 500 slipped 1%.
Trade rose sharply in the stock market today, up 14% on the Nasdaq and 36% on the NYSE.

New-home sales jumped in August, the Commerce Department reported, to an annualized rate of 552,000. That was nearly 6% more than July's upwardly revised pace, and well beyond consensus projections for a sales rate of 515,000 units. That was not enough to keep homebuilder stocks from sliding along with the general market. But leader D.R. Horton (DHI) did manage to hold losses to less than 1%.

Caterpillar (CAT) dumped 7% at the start of trade after announcing it would layoff 10,000 workers by the end of 2018 in a restructuring aimed at focusing on data analytics and digital and innovation capabilities. The company plans to consolidate its surface and underground mining equipment operations, plus various sales and support teams across the company. The company aims for $1.5 billion in annual cost savings. Management lowered its full-year 2015 and 2016 revenue guidance. The loss put Caterpillar shares down 9% for the week, to their lowest mark since August 2010.
Related stocks caught in the undertow included United Rentals (URI) and Joy Global (JOY), down 5% each. Diesel maker Cummins (CMI) slipped 3%.
Chipmakers were under pressure, with NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) diving 5% and Analog Devices (ADI) sliding nearly that much.

Taser International (TASR) ripped ahead 5% after announcing a large order by the Memphis, Tenn., police department and following a report in which Sidoti & Co. initiated coverage with a buy rating and a 35 price target. The stock remains below key levels of support and deep in a three-month consolidation.
IBD 50 stocks opened lower, with 3-in-5 of the group dropping more than 1% in early trade.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) took the hardest blow, dropping nearly 5%. The stock is nursing a 12% loss for the week as it nears a test of support at its 40-week moving average.Stocks crumbled out of the starting gate into quick, broad losses Thursday. Stocks rushed south Thursday, pulling down 19 of every 20 industry groups. The Nasdaq suffered a 2.8% dent, while the S&P 500 crumpled 2.1%. The IBD 50 fell 3.1%. Volume rose across the board. The Nasdaq closed at its low for the day, leaving it 6.8% off its July high and marking its sharpest pullback of the year. The S&P…
Home loan applications surged in the most recent week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Its composite index jumped 13.9%, the biggest weekly move since January.

Applications to refinance were up 18% during a week characterized by volatile shifts in rates, thanks to the Federal Reserve meeting. The average 30-year fixed rate was little changed by week's end, but other products, like 15-year fixed and adjustable rate mortgages, saw declines. Refinancing activity has stayed stronger than expected as rates remain low, a boon to consumer discretionary spending.

Purchases leapt 9% during the week, MBA said. Precise year-on-year calculations are difficult because of shifts in the Labor Day holiday timing, but the average index level in September is 23% higher than the same period last year. That tracks with most other data, like sales figures, that show a healing housing market.

Among homebuilder stocks, Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI), Pulte (PHM) and KB Home (KBH) all rose modestly in morning trade in the stock market today. Lennar topped earnings forecasts on Monday. KB Home reports results Thursday.

Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC), the No. 1 mortgage lender in the U.S., was little changed Wednesday morning. Wells Fargo stock has been slumping, partly on the overall market and partly due to the Fed's decision not to raise rates, which likely would have meant wider loan spreads for banks.Home loan applications surged in the most recent week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Scrub the liftoff: The Federal Reserve on Thursday left interest rates near zero, saying 'global economic and financial developments' may curb economic growth and inflation.Fed policymakers stated that "economic activity is expanding at a moderate pace. Household spending and business fixed investment have been increasing moderately, and the housing sector has improved further; however, net exports have been soft. The labor market continued to improve, with solid job gains and declining unemployment. On balance, labor market indicators show that underutilization of labor resources has diminished since early this year."But inflation has been low, in part due to falling energy prices and non-oil imports. And the Fed highlighted overseas concerns."Recent global economic and financial developments may restrain economic activity somewhat and are likely to put further downward pressure on inflation in the near term."Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker dissented from the decision.Meanwhile, officials also signaled a slower rate hike path going forward, with 13 of 17 saying the Fed will be ready to raise rates by year-end, but that's down from 15 in June. Now three want liftoff next year, while one favors acting in 2017. In June, 15 wanted the Fed to boost rates this year and two favored next year.Fed staff released forecasts trimming growth forecasts, while implying that the central bank sees the natural rate of unemployment at 4.8%-4.9%.Fed Chair Janet Yellen, in a post-announcement press conference, conceded that a case could be made to tighten today. She said that an October rate hike is still on the table, saying if that happens, the central bank will call a press conference. Many analysts had speculated that if the Fed didn't hike in September, it would wait until December, the next scheduled meeting and press conference.Stocks were volatile, rallying to session highs about 45 minutes after the announcement and 15 minutes after Yellen's conference began, but by the close the averages had erased those gains, with the S&P 500 and Dow closing modestly lower. The Nasdaq rose 0.1%.Treasury yields fell sharploy. Stocks and bond yields have been rising in recent days in part on anticipation of a no-hike decision.Earlier, new housing data was relatively strong, while another regional manufacturing report showed factories retreating.Housing starts mixed in AugustStarts ran at a 1.126 mil annual pace in Aug., below forecasts of 1.168 mil and down slightly from a downwardly revised 1.161 mil. Permits were stronger than expected, though, running at a 1.17 mil rate, higher than the 1.13 mil in July. That signals a stronger pace of starts may follow, good news for the housing market and for construction jobs.Homebuilder stocks such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) rose 2%-4% Thursday afternoon after the starts data and Fed policy announcement.Jobless claims sink to 2-month lowThere were 264,000 initial jobless claims in the Sept. 12 week, 11,000 below the prior week and forecasts. The 4-week moving average was 272,500, down 3,250. Continuing claims fell 26,000 to 2.237 mil. Claims have trended well below levels normally associated with an economy at full employment.Employment cut 208,000 in benchmark revisionsNonfarm payrolls in March 2015 will be reduced by 208,000 according to preliminary benchmark revisions released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The revisions won't be factored into historical data until they are finalized in early 2016. The report suggests that private payrolls will be cut by 255,000. Professional and business services will be cut by 101,000 jobs while leisure and hospitality will be reduced by 51,000. But construction, transportation/warehouse and government jobs are on track for big upward revisions.Philly Fed index shows manufacturing retreatingThe regional bank's manufacturing survey fell to -6.0 in Sept. from 8.3; economists had expected 6.0. That was the first overall contraction since Feb. '14 and the worst reading since Feb. '13. New orders rose, signaling stronger activity ahead, as did the employment gauge. The future outlook gauge hit its highest point since Jan., at 44. Analysts are watching the manufacturing sector to see if the effect of plunging oil prices on capital spending has diminished. 13.5% of firms expect production to decline by more than 10% in Q3. The New York Fed's Empire State manufacturing index, released earlier this week, held near multi-year lows in September. The current account deficit fell to $109.7 bil in Q2, from $118.3 bil in Q1. Economists had expected a $113.5 bil gap for the broad measure of trade. The lower price of oil weighed on imports while exports were stronger than expected given a strong dollar, a notable concern for both the Fed and multinational corporations. The deficit was equal to 2.5% of GDP in Q2, vs. 2.7% in Q1.U.K. retail sales still strongSales rose 0.2% in Aug., a tick firmer than expected, although the yearly gain of 3.7% was a bit weaker than forecast. Small stores benefitted from a rush to buy school uniforms, and the clothing, textiles and footwear category posted its biggest monthly gain since April. The Bank of England is mulling its first rate hike in 7 years as the economy improves.China wallops Japan's exportsJapanese exports slowed for a second month in Aug., up only 3.1% vs a year ago, vs. forecasts for 4.0%. Exports to China fell 4.6% in Aug. vs. a year ago, the first decline since Feb. The data suggests the Bank of Japan may decide to ease policy further, but also raises broader questions about China's impact on Asia and the entire global economy. Some 41% of U.K. small firms want to leave the European Union, according to a survey from the Federation of Small Businesses. That puts small business at odds with larger corporations, which mostly benefit from stronger ties with Europe. A referendum is expected next year.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 46 were higher and four were lower. The top performer was Paycom Software (PAYC), up 7% on big volume. It broke out of a double-bottom base with a 39.27 buy point.

Builders broke ground on fewer homes than expected in August, but that was offset by a stronger pace of permits. Housing starts ran at a 1.126 million annual pace in August, down from 1.161 million and below forecasts of 1.168 million. That's a long way from the 2 million annual pace it hit during the bubble days, but also much higher than the worst of the downturn. Starts were 17% higher than year-ago levels in August, and the average for the first 8 months of 2015 is 11% higher than the same period last year.

The good news was in permits, which signal how starts will behave later. The annual pace of overall permits in August, 1.17 million, was stronger than expected, and July's figure was revised up. Permits in the key single-family home market keep inching up and in August hit a 7 1/2-year high rate of 699,000.
That tracks with an industry survey out Wednesday that showed confidence among homebuilders like D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and Pulte (PHM) was at a 10-year high.

Shares of D.R. Horton, Lennar and KB Home (KBH) rose modestly Thursday after the starts data and ahead of the Fed policy announcement. But Pulte Group dipped fractionally.Builders broke ground on fewer homes than expected in August, but that was offset by a stronger pace of permits. Still, with the Fed apparently poised to pull the trigger, Schatz cites several…

Recent stock market negativity here and elsewhere will likely have an impact on housing in America, experts say — especially in the pricey end of the sector.Whether that impact is good depends on whether Wall Street's drop leads to a prolonged slump in the stock market or if it produces just a temporary correction.If the latter happens, most real estate investors will likely sit tight and wait for the stock market to rebound, watchers say. This could lead to a slowdown in sales of homes priced $1 million and above.If stock markets in the U.S. and China stay down for an extended period, expect more investors to put their money into comparatively stable real estate investments.Danielle Hale, director of housing statistics at the National Association of Realtors, says a stock market flop "has two different levels."Some prospective real estate buyers "might err on the side of caution," she told IBD. "These buyers tend to leave their current investments alone and avoid any new investments."Others might look to real estate as "a more stable asset," Hale said. "They look to real estate as relatively less volatile than stocks, so they might increase their investments in real estate."FBN Securities analyst Joel Locker offers a similar take."You can probably list examples of both cases," he said. "If the stock market goes down and investors have less discretionary income, some might stay away from real estate. On the other hand, you hear about people in China going into real estate with the stock market down because real estate is a more stable investment right now."Officials at the NAR sound upbeat about near-term growth prospects for the high-end housing market."We had decent buying momentum this summer and we think it will continue, especially as the (U.S.) economy and job markets improve," Hale said.An NAR report on existing-home sales shows that sales of homes priced at $1 million or higher rose 17.5% year over year in July, the most recent month that data are available. The biggest gain, at 27.2%, came in the $750,000 to $1 million category.Sales in the $1 million and up category "have been doing quite well," Hale said. "They're not doing quite as well as in past years as far as the growth rate goes, but they've still grown pretty substantially."Whether that growth rate can sustain itself in the current environment depends in part on how much money foreign investors are willing to spend.These investors are an important element of the market for homes selling for $1 million and higher.In its annual report on foreign homebuyers, released every June, the NAR noted that an estimated 209,000 U.S. homes were sold to foreign buyers during the 12 months ended in March.That represented about 4% of total existing-home sales.The Overseas LookThe total dollar volume for foreign sales, estimated at $104 billion, represented about 8% of total dollar-volume for sales of existing homes.Also, foreign buyers spend a lot more on average than their American counterparts.Foreign buyers paid on average nearly $500,000 for a house vs. the overall U.S. average house price of $256,000.Buyers from China acquired U.S. properties estimated at $28.6 billion in total value during the 12 months ended in March, up from $22 billion in the 12 months prior.That was more than double the $11.2 billion spent by Canadians, who ranked second.How will China's stock market woes affect Chinese investment in U.S. homes?FBN Securities' Locker says there's a "correlation" between global stock markets and investments, and that those investments could slow when stock markets turn sour."You might go buy a second home in New York or Los Angeles when the stock market is going good because you have more discretionary income to spend," Locker said. "When the market falls, that same amount of discretionary income isn't there anymore."Falling stock markets aren't the only current headwinds to foreign investment in U.S. real estate.Foreign investors also face negative currency and home-price trends."For people who are looking at real estate as an income-producing investment, it might not make as much sense now as in past years because of the strong dollar and price appreciation," Hale said.The really high-end real estate market — which typically means homes priced $5 million and up in large gateway cities like New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco — already has seen signs of a slowdown, says Locker.Taking A TollLocker's coverage includes Toll Bros. (TOL), which is most closely associated with luxury homes among publicly traded stocks."Toll has already said the New York luxury market was slowing, and that the higher end of homes $5 million to $7 million and above was soft," Locker said. "If you look at their order numbers, they're not what they used to be."These trends "kind of triggered people thinking, 'Could it be the U.S. dollar strength and less foreign buyers?' " he said.Toll Bros. itself has seen a recent slowdown in business, with two straight quarters of lower year-over-year sales.Last quarter it posted its first earnings decline in two years.Other large U.S. builders that don't focus as much on the high end — including D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and NVR (NVR) — have fared much better lately.Lennar has put together a years-long streak of double-digit sales and earnings growth.NVR has delivered two straight quarters of double-digit gains on the top and bottom lines.D.R. Horton has posted five straight quarters of 28%-or-better sales growth and last quarter logged an 88% gain in EPS.

As apartment rents keep rising, LGI Homes (LGIH) derives more marketing power to turn renters into homeowners. With six straight months of 5% or greater annualized rent growth through July, the national apartment market "could be in its hottest long-term streak since the Great Recession," said market researcher Axiometrics.
July's annual rent growth rate of 5.2% was the highest in four years, Axiometrics notes.
LGI, which is based in the Woodlands, Texas, targets renters for its low-priced, entry-level homes in Texas and seven other states in the Southwest and Southeast.
It sends direct mail to renters in apartment complexes near its new-home communities, explaining how they can afford to own an LGI Home for the same amount or less than their monthly rents.
Instead of advertising the price of a home, LGI often touts homes' monthly payments of $700 to $1,000 a month.
The average price of an LGI home increased 15.8% in the second quarter vs. a year earlier, still a relatively affordable $186,197.

"A big part of their strategy is building a very simple home cost effectively so they can charge a low price for it," said John Burns, CEO of John Burns Real Estate Consulting, a housing-market research firm. "They have standard floor plans they build over and over."
Qualifying Folks With Less

Interested buyers are steered to sales offices in LGI communities, where numbers are crunched to determine if they qualify for a low down payment loan — typically a 3.5% product from the Federal Housing Administration (FHA).
Or for those who qualify, LGI offers "no money down" financing.

"If they qualify (for financing), LGI will literally walk them out to a finished home they can purchase," said Burns, who compares LGI's marketing strategy to a time-share company's. "Most of these people don't even think they can become homeowners because they don't have a lot of savings."

LGI may be one of the smallest of the publicly traded homebuilders among giants such as D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) — which also build for entry-level buyers, among others — but it is one of the fastest growing in terms of percentage gains in home closings.
In the six months ended June 30, it closed on 1,524 homes, up 32.9% from a year ago. The summer months were even stronger. In July, closings jumped 78.7%. In August they climbed just shy of 75%.
The company expects to close 3,000 to 3,300 homes in 2015, up from a previous forecast of 2,800 to 3,200 homes. It closed 2,356 homes in 2014, up 45.7%.
LGI set a new quarterly record for home closings in Q2 — up 29% from a year ago to 853 homes. Revenue jumped 49% to $158.8 million. Earnings climbed 53% to 66 cents per share.
Moreover, management raised earnings guidance for the full year to $2.15-$2.50 per share from $1.85-$2.25 previously. At the mid-point, it would represent growth of 75% over 2014.

"We consistently saw strong and steady traffic, with some of our information centers experiencing standing room only on the weekends," CEO Eric Lipar said in the post-Q2 conference call. (Company executives were unavailable to comment for this article.)
More than 54,000 potential customers inquired about a home, averaging 100 leads per community per week, he added.
Shares Soar Since IPO
LGI started building homes in Texas in 2003. Since it went public in November 2013, shares have appreciated about 154%. They soared 23% on Aug. 5, the day LGI reported Q2 results and raised guidance.

At quarter's end, LGI boasted 45 active communities in eight states, up from 14 communities a year earlier. Besides Texas, LGI is building in Arizona, Florida, Georgia, New Mexico, Colorado, North Carolina and South Carolina.
"They are in areas that are among the fastest-growing economies in the country," Burns said.

They are also in areas where LGI can build homes relatively cheaply compared to other regions of the country, where land is tighter and more costly. "You're not going to find them in California or Massachusetts, for example," Burns said.

LGI says customers continue to flock to its communities in Houston, despite oil-related pressures on the economy there. Four of its top-five selling communities were in Houston. But they are not in the pricey areas, such as the energy corridor on the west side, where many oil executives live, Burns says.
LGI projects in Denver and Charlotte, N.C., new in the last year, were two of the firm's top performers outside of Texas.

LGI plans to sell homes soon in Seattle, which has seen a surge of young tech workers. "But it will be in the distant areas of Seattle, not near downtown (where) the land is too expensive," Burns said.
LGI also plans to expand into Nashville, Jacksonville, Fla.; Raleigh-Durham and Colorado Springs.
"The model is very replicable," Burns said.
Lots Of Lots: 22,200

LGI ended the quarter with roughly 22,200 owned and controlled lots, an inventory it says represents three to five years of supply. In early July it acquired 400 lots in Denver from Jack Fisher Homes.

But since LGI is reliant on low interest rates to keep monthly payments for its target buyers affordable, how would rising interest rates impact its business? Burns says the answer is simple: "If rates go up, they've said they will build smaller homes."
Analysts expect LGI's revenue and earnings growth to slow next year but remain in double digits.

In a research note on LGI after its Q2 report, J.P. Morgan analyst Michael Rehaut pointed to the company's "above average and near industry leading" growth in closings and orders, and gave the stock an overweight rating.

He noted the company's attractive land position, expansion into new markets, strong gross margins and "unique marketing and sales approach."As apartment rents keep rising, LGI Homes (LGIH) derives more marketing power to turn renters into homeowners. With six straight months of 5% or greater annualized rent growth through July, the national apartment market "could be in its hottest long-term streak since the Great Recession," said market researcher Axiometrics.July's annual rent growth rate of 5.2% was the highest in four years, Axiometrics notes.LGI, which is based in the Woodlands, Texas, targets renters for its low-priced, entry-level homes in Texas and seven other states in the Southwest and Southeast.It sends direct mail to renters in apartment complexes near its new-home communities, explaining how they can afford to own an LGI Home for the same amount or less than their monthly rents.Instead of advertising the price of a home, LGI often touts homes' monthly payments of $700 to $1,000 a month.The average price of an LGI home increased 15.8% in the second quarter vs. a year earlier, still a relatively affordable $186,197."A big part of their strategy is building a very simple home cost effectively so they can charge a low price for it," said John Burns, CEO of John Burns Real Estate Consulting, a housing-market research firm. Major averages fell off session highs in late-afternoon trading Wednesday as the two-day Fed meeting got underway. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%, while the Nasdaq rose 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels — more so on the NYSE in the stock market today.

General Electric (GE), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) outperformed in the Dow. The last two did well thanks to a spike in oil prices. Crude oil futures jumped $2.27, or 5.1%, to $46.86 a barrel. Earlier today, the Energy Information Administration said crude supplies fell by 2.1 million barrels last week. On Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute said supplies fell by 3.1 million barrels.

Among the day's movers, Fitbit (FIT) soared nearly 12%, one day after Pacific Crest started coverage of the firm with an overweight rating and a 47 price target. Fitbit is still 29% off its recent high after a sharp pullback.

Inside the IBD 50, NetEase (NTES) and Smith & Wesson (SWHC) were among the top percentage gainers, rising 3% and 2%, respectively. NetEase is still damaged goods as it trades below its 200-day moving average, but Smith & Wesson is trading tightly and holding gains after a recent breakout over a 17.14 buy point.

Biotechs and homebuilders were weak even as builder confidence reached its highest level in nearly a decade, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo housing market index. But stocks such as LGI Homes (LGIH), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) are not showing sell signals.
Intra-Cellular Therapies (ITCI) was a bright spot in the biotech space after the company announced positive late-stage trial results for its schizophrenia drug.

The Fed's decision on interest rates is due Thursday afternoon. Amid a delicate global outlook, an increasing number of economists expect a rate hike, although futures traders are still skeptical. According to CME Group FedWatch, futures traders put the odds of a rate hike at 21%.Major averages fell off session highs in late-afternoon trading Wednesday as the two-day Fed meeting got underway. Few stocks were spared in Wednesday's sell-off, but these five highly rated names managed to hit new highs. D.R. Horton (DHI) added 0.55 to a new nine-year high of 32.21, extending its gains for a third straight session. The stock is now 12% past a 28.80 buy point of a cup with handle. Stocks cut their losses following the release of the Fed minutes Wednesday, but sold off again into the close. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.9%, as Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) weighed. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each gave up 0.8%. Volume was higher across the board, according to preliminary data. That would mean another distribution day for the major indexes.Energy stocks led the decline in the stock market today as crude oil prices slid to new lows. In the much smaller list of advancing industry groups, gold miners, Internet content and building stocks eked out gains.D.R. Horton (DHI) added 2% in heavy trade to a new nine-year high. Shares of the Texas-based homebuilder are now 12% extended from a 38.80 cup-with-handle buy point.Lowe's (LOW) rose 2% in fast turnover for its fifth straight advance. The home improvement chain reported mixed Q2 results, with a profit miss and sales beat. It guided full-year earnings a penny higher than Street forecasts.Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, with 35 decliners and 15 advancers. CyberArk Software (CYBR) led with a 4% pop. Nike (NKE) was one of only two Dow components to close in the black. McDonald's (MCD) (not in the IBD 50) was the other.Thursday's economic data include jobless claims for the week of Aug. 15, July existing-home sales and the Philly Fed business outlook survey for August. The Fed's Narayana Kocherlakota and John Williams are also scheduled to speak.Wednesday's Fed minutes indicated a September rate hike is still on the table.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

In times of global uncertainty, defensive stocks in industries such as utilities and supermarkets are typically considered safer bets. But a few of IBD's top 25 industry groups over the past 8 weeks may be surprising, with some relatively insulated from the negative effects of the global markets, and others even benefiting from the turmoil. Airlines Ranking 11th out of…
Stock futures nosed lower early Wednesday as investors weighed earnings, consumer price data and overseas action, and ahead of this afternoon's Federal Reserve release.

Dow futures slipped 55.3 points below fair market value, off lows but lower over the prior hour. Nasdaq 100 futures were 4.7 points lower. S&P 500 futures were down 4.4 points. Small caps were under pressure, down 6 points.

Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's July 29 meeting, due out at 2 p.m., will be a focal point for the stock market today. It is the last official release of data before the September meeting at which the Fed has broadly suggested it could vote to raise the federal funds target rate. The Fed has not altered the rate, currently 0.25%, since December 2008.

Consumer prices rose 0.1% in July, the Labor Department said, a sixth straight monthly advance, but down from a 0.3% increase in June and below expectations for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.1%, below the 0.2% consensus and June's 0.2% rise. It was the index's second straight year-over-year advance after flat action for the first five months of the year.

U.S. stocks may feel some early pressure European markets, trading lower after Germany's parliament approved the renewed bailout agreement for Greece. The debate rocked markets for months before finally securing Greek support in July and passed muster among eurozone finance ministers Aug. 14.

The German vote frees funds for release to the debt-stressed country later today. Greece owes the European Central Bank a $3.5 billion debt payment on Thursday. The DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris carried losses of more than 1% near midday.

Some China-based stocks trading on U.S. markets took post-earnings report beatings early Wednesday. Canadian Solar (CSIQ) dived 10%, Tarena International (TEDU) folded 12% after reporting second-quarter results late Tuesday. Sina (SINA), which also reported after Tuesday's close, rose a fraction.
Retailers were again busy in premarket action. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) jumped 3% after posting healthy Q2 results. Staples (SPLS) dropped 2%. Lowe's (LOW) stumbled 1%.

Target (TGT) leapt 4% after a 33% jump in earnings and a 3% revenue gain topped analysts' Q2 expectations. The company boosted its full-year earnings outlook — a significant move following Tuesday's downgrade from Wal-Mart (WMT) — and same-store-sales comfortably beat forecasts. Shares rose almost 2% Tuesday, continuing the stock's rebound from support at its 200-day moving average.

Meat processor Hormel Foods (HRL) popped 2% ahead of the open. The Austin, Minn., company's adjusted Q2 earnings narrowly topped consensus views. Revenue dipped 4%, in line with expectations, and management raised its full-year EPS guidance. The stock finished Tuesday just below a Monday high after clearing a shallow, months-long consolidation.
Homebuilders were trading mixed in premarket action after a strong session on Tuesday. Toll Bros. (TOL) was down nearly 2%, while Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) dipped a fraction each.
Thinly traded MI Homes (MHO) spiked 10% in premarket trade. The Columbus, Ohio-based builder ended Tuesday almost 3% past a 25.71 buy point after a breakout from a flat base on Monday.

Overseas, Asian markets were all over the map on Wednesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 taking a 1.6% loss, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.3%, the Shanghai Composite up 1.2% and the Shenzhen Composite posting a 2.2% gain. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets dived 3% in early trade.

The dollar slipped vs. the euro and the yen. Commodities were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate oil down a bit less than 1% and Europe's Brent crude effectively flat. Gold rose a half-percent to $1,121 an ounce.
