Housing starts surge 20% Housing starts came in at an annual pace of 1.135 mil in April, the highest in more than 7 years and easily beating expectations. That followed a slightly upwardly revised March. Permits were also rosier than expected, at a 1.143 mil pace that was also the best in years. Homebuilder stocks, including Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM),…

The sentiment index from the National Association of Home Builders shed 2 points in May to touch 54. Analysts had expected a 1-point uptick to 57. That's 9 points above the level a year ago, NAHB pointed out; it's also the fourth monthly decline in 2015.Builders were more upbeat about the outlook for the next 6 months in May than about current conditions; the 6-month outlook gauge was 64, while the current conditions index was 59. Respondents have held tenaciously to bullish views, even as the housing rebound has failed to launch throughout the near-6 year recovery and in May alluded to "pent-up demand moving forward."But their perception of buyer traffic stumbled again in May. Traffic had been approaching the neutral 50 line late last year but in May sank deeper into contraction at 39.Still, Q1 was solid for many builders. Meritage (MTH) forecast a 25%-30% jump in revenue in 2015, and D.R. Horton (DHI) reported better-than-expected earnings, though some pressure on margins as its sales have been skewed toward entry-level homes. D.R. Horton, Meritage and Lennar (LEN) shares rose Monday.

The housing recovery appears to be moving from the slow lane to a somewhat faster lane as existing-home sales rise and builders step up new-home starts. Builders broke ground on more new homes in April — 20% more than in March, the fastest growth pace in more than seven years, portending potentially higher future sales for the likes of Lennar[ticker…

Housing surprised to the upside for a change — and in a big way. April starts surged more than 20% to the highest since November 2007, and permits leapt 10% to the fastest since 2008. Both single-family and multifamily starts jumped by double-digits in the month, but single-family starts are up 15% vs. a year ago.Starts in the weather-battered Northeast offered some proof of the temporary factors that have been wreaking havoc with economic data in past months. They tumbled 57% from January to February, then rebounded 115% in March and 86% in April.Homebuilders have had a mixed spring. D.R. Horton (DHI) said orders jumped by nearly a third in Q1, but that margins could be pressured as entry-level homes make up a greater share of the total. Meritage (MTH) is forecasting revenue that's higher by as much as 25-20% in 2015, but PulteGroup (PHM) saw profit drop 26% in Q1. Builder confidence took a step back in April, the National Association of Home Builders said Monday, but sentiment remains relatively high, with builders particularly bullish about the next 6 months.Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup, KB Home (KBH), Meritage and D.R. Horton (DHI) rallied in the stock market today, but came off earlier highs as the market reversed.
Stocks surrendered thin gains and slipped lower early Tuesday as investors contended with a rising dollar, sliding oil prices and mixed quarterly reports.
The Nasdaq was down 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 dipped 0.1% each.
Volume swept higher, with Nasdaq trade rising 23% and NYSE volume up 18% vs. action at the same time Monday.

The Nasdaq drifted up to just below its April 27 high in the stock market today before pulling back to a flat stance. Oil prices dived nearly 2%. Gold trimmed more than 1%. Comments from European Central Bank officials that offered a clearer view into more-aggressive-than-expected ECB bond buying sent the euro sharply lower vs. the dollar. Eurozone markets soared, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1.8% in afternoon trade. China's mainland markets also posted a very positive session, buoyed by the government's market reform plan. The Deutsche X-Trackers Harvest CSI 300 Fund (ASHR) surged more than 4%.

April housing starts jumped to an annualized rate of 1.135 million, up 20% from the Commerce Department's revised March estimate. It was the highest mark in more than seven years and the biggest percent gain since 1991, the department said. Lennar (LEN), DR Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) all gained more than 1%.

Wal-Mart (WMT) gave the market wobbly knees, sliding more than 3% after both revenue and earnings missed analysts' first-quarter consensus projections. Sam's Club sales were weaker than expected, and currency exchange rates had some negative effect. Q2 earnings guidance was at the low end of analyst projections. The gap-down loss erased a three-session advance.

TJX (TJX) jumped nearly 3% in early trade, stepping to the front of the S&P 500 index. The owner of the Marshalls, Homegoods and TJ Maxx chains reported stronger-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. Management issued Q2 earnings guidance below analyst forecasts. The gap-up gain hoisted shares to within 3% of a 71.13 buy point in an eight-week flat base.

On the IBD 50 list, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) muscled up more than 2% in very strong trade. The Woburn, Mass.-based chipmaker cleared a 102.87 buy point on Monday. It is still in buying range, not quite 3% above that pivot.

Pending home sales in January were a sigh of relief for a real estate market that's seen a lot of false starts in the aftermath of the housing bubble and recession.The National Association of Realtors' index rose 1.7%, enough to push it to an 18-month high. January also marked the fifth-straight month of annual increases, each one stronger than the last. In January, that was 8.4% above year-ago levels. All-cash purchases are easing and the job market is strengthening, making for a healthier market overall, NAR said.While real estate is still a local story, only one region, the Midwest, saw a monthly decline in January, and all had annual increases. The South remains the strongest market and also had the biggest monthly jump, 3.2%. The Northeast remains the weakest, but eked out a 0.1% gain in January.Pending home sales reflect contract signings for existing home sales. The index offers an indication of actual existing home sales that close in February or March.Shares of homebuildersToll Bros. (TOL), Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH), D.R. Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM) rose modestly in Friday afternoon trading.

Stocks struggled Friday, sliding in sawtooth fashion to end with significant losses. The Nasdaq, IBD 50 and S&P 500 suffered dents of 0.5%, 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume rose across the board. The action was sufficiently negative to slap a distribution day on the Nasdaq and the S&P 500. It was the first such day for either index in three…

Stocks were mixed heading into the final hour of trading Tuesday. Volume continued to track heavier across the board. The Dow Jones industrial average held on to a 0.1% gain, while the Nasdaq lost 0.1% and the S&P 500 dipped a fraction.

In economic news, April housing starts surged from March and topped consensus estimates. Homebuilders responded positively. Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR) added more than 1% each as they work on the right side of new base patterns.
Oil and gas groups were weak in the stock market today as crude plunged nearly 4%.
Among leading stocks, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) added to Monday's breakout with a 2% gain. Shares are still in buy range past a 102.87 flat-base buy point.
Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) also added to a recent breakout past 55.48. Shares surged more than 3% but are still in range past the entry.

On the downside, Urban Outfitters (URBN) trimmed an 18% loss to 15%. Late Monday, the apparel retailer delivered disappointing Q1 earnings and sales. Oppenheimer, Piper Jaffray and JPMorgan all downgraded the stock Tuesday.

Data disclosed last week indicated the housing recovery is on track. That may lift homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), which leads off a busy week in which five homebuilders are slated to report quarterly performance.Homebuilders are trying to rebound after earnings and revenue growth weakened in the back half of 2014 amid market uncertainty.D.R. Horton, which bills itself as "America's Builder" and is the largest in the group by annual revenue, will release first-quarter financial results Monday before the market opens.The consensus of analysts is for a 2-cent drop in earnings per share to 34 cents. Investors hope Horton can reverse that to a beat after missing analysts' EPS estimates the prior two quarters.Revenue is projected to rise 27.2% to $2.075 billion.D.R. Horton stock is bouncing back from a failed breakout with a 26.04 buy point. It's trading below its 50-day but finding support at its 200-day line. Horton closed down 2.5% Friday to 23.10.PulteGroup (PHM) is set to announce Q4 earnings Thursday before the market opens.Wall Street expects the builder of single-family homes, condos, townhouses and duplexes to report a 17-cent drop in EPS to 40 cents. Investors will be looking for a repeat of the prior quarter's results when Pulte reported better than expected EPS.Revenue is projected to grow 6.5% to $1.76 billion.Pulte shares moved sideways for most of 2014, trading in a narrow range. Like Horton, it tried to break out early this year but retreated and was trading back in the range Friday. It closed Friday off 1% to 20.69.Smaller peers MDC Holdings (MDC), Ryland (RYL) and Beazer Homes (BZH) will also report results, opening a window onto housing prospects this year.MDC is scheduled to release Q4 earnings Wednesday. Ryland will announce Q4 Thursday, and Beazer is on tap to release fiscal Q1 earnings Friday.Bullish signs are popping up for homebuilders. The Census Bureau said last week that December housing starts beat estimates, rising 4.4% to an annualized 1.098 million units and lifting 2014 to the strongest overall year since 2007.Single-family home permits rose 4.5% in December to an annual rate of 667,000, the strongest monthly gain of 2014.In another sign the housing recovery is on track, the share of homeowners whose loans are underwater fell to the lowest point since the number peaked in the second quarter 2012, according to housing market tracker RealtyTrac.However, Lennar (LEN), which builds single-family homes in 17 states, on Jan. 15 reported higher earnings per share, but revenue growth fell short of estimates. And Lennar said it expects lower profit margins this year amid rising costs.KB Home (KBH) also reported a revenue gain on Jan. 13, but EPS fell 9.7% and was half what Wall Street expected.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Lennar added to the homebuilding gloom Thursday as it became the latest company to warn on lower margins amid rising costs and bigger promotions — despite other trends that point to more housing demand. The Miami-based builder sees gross margins on home sales dipping this year to 24% from 25.4% in 2014. The warning comes even as Lennar (LEN) remains…
The data show that a bunch of your neighbors may have spent their New Year's downtime plotting how to save money on their house. Now's an even better time to resolve to do the same, and here's why.
Applications to refinance home mortgages vaulted 66% in the week that ended last Friday, Jan. 9, as mortgage rates were on their way down to lows not seen since mid-2013.

After ending 2014 at 3.87%, the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 3.73% in the week that ended Thursday, Jan. 8, right when applications were surging. And in the week ended Thursday, Jan. 15, rates fell even further — to 3.66%.

The last time you could get that good a deal on your mortgage was the week of May 23, 2013, when the going average was 3.59%, according to Freddie Mac's (FMCC) survey. About four years ago, in early 2011, the average was around 5%.
Rates dropped, economists note, as the price of oil sank and as long-term Treasury yields fell in a flight to safety tied to world economic concerns.
Whether it makes sense to refinance now depends on many factors, including how long you plan to stay in your home and how long it will take to pay off the closing costs on a new loan.

Plenty of people started out the year as homebuyers, not just as refinancers. In the Mortgage Bankers Association's analysis, a purchase-mortgage applications index rose 24% for the week that ended Jan. 9.

Nevertheless, builder Lennar's (LEN) stock sank Thursday as it gave quarterly results and forecast less pricing power in 2015. That could be good for new-home buyers, however. KB Home (KBH) also dropped after earlier in the week reporting quarterly results that included a warning about its profit margins. Other builders falling in the market Thursday included D.R. Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM).

If location (location, location) is indeed the key to success in real estate, then homebuilders with operations in Seattle, Salt Lake City, Nashville, Tenn., Atlanta and Boston should see good times in 2015.

Those are among cities cited by economists as having the best housing market gains this year based on job growth, housing demand, home price strength and other factors. Others frequently mentioned are Dallas, Denver, San Jose, Calif., Charlotte, N.C., and Raleigh, N.C.

Although recent quarterly reports from builders have disappointed investors, economists are generally upbeat about the 2015 housing market in most sections of the U.S. They point to improving economic and employment data.

"Housing is driven by the local job market, and job gains are accelerating," said Lawrence Yun, chief economist with the National Association of Realtors. "It's positive news for all parts of the country."
Cities That Work
The news is particularly positive for cities, many in the South, that have seen rapid job gains across several different industries. Yun points to Atlanta, Nashville, Charlotte and Charleston, S.C.
"We've seen many manufacturing and financial services companies moving operations into Southern states," he told IBD.

As an example, Yun cites the news last week that Daimler AG's (DDAIF) Mercedes-Benz will move its U.S. division headquarters from New Jersey to the Atlanta metro area. In the summer Boeing (BA) said that the largest of its 787 Dreamliners, the 787-10 launched in 2013, will be assembled in North Charleston, S.C.
Other metro areas with strong job markets are Seattle, San Francisco and San Jose, Yun says.
"The weak point will be the Northeast from New York to Maine," he said. "That region will be sluggish in terms of home price recovery, with the exception of Boston."

Trulia Chief Economist Jed Kolko has a more cautious take on housing in general. In a report emailed to IBD, Kolko said "barriers remain to homeownership." These include difficulty saving for a down payment and poor credit.
Not having a stable job "has become considerably less of an obstacle," Kolko said, but affordability "has become a bigger obstacle."

Kolko noted that certain markets have the right combination of fundamentals, for both buyers and renters, to enjoy strong housing growth in 2015. He cites Boston, Nashville, Salt Lake City, Seattle, Raleigh, Dallas, New York, San Diego, Fresno, Calif., and Middlesex County, Mass.
Two important demographic groups — baby boomers and millennials — will also drive housing gains in certain markets, experts say.

Cities poised to benefit from an influx of boomers include Denver, Raleigh, Orlando, Fla., and Tucson, Ariz., the NAR reports. Top markets for millennial homebuyers include Austin, Dallas, Denver, Minneapolis, New Orleans, Seattle and Salt Lake City.
Several homebuilders stand to gain from hot housing markets in these and other cities.
D.R. Horton (DHI), for example, lists 11 communities in the Seattle area and 13 in greater Salt Lake City. D.R. Horton also has a big stake in Dallas, along with PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN).

Beazer Homes USA (BZH) has several communities in Southeastern metro areas, such as Atlanta, Nashville and Raleigh-Durham. Builders with a big stake in California's Silicon Valley include Tri Pointe Homes (TPH) and Ryland Group (RYL).

Two metrics that economists look at to gauge an area's housing market strength are median home price growth and inventory. A rise in home prices indicates an increase in demand, while a drop in inventory shows that available homes are selling.
Sweet Spots For Growth

A Dec. 23 NAR report showed a handful of big U.S. metro areas seeing double-digit growth in median home prices as well as high single-digit to double-digit drops in inventory in November, the last month for which data are available. Cities on the list included Chicago, Houston, Dallas, Charlotte and Nashville.
These big metro areas saw double-digit price increases but also flat or growing inventory: San Jose, Denver, Atlanta and Austin, Texas.
While those metrics are a "good indicator of the current housing situation," Yun said they are not necessarily a forecast of future growth.
"One thing we do know is that these markets are not afraid of raising prices," he said. "But future growth will all be tied to job gains and whether local markets will sustain solid job gains."
The ability to sustain solid job gains has become a recent worry in Texas, where declining oil and gas prices are expected to have a negative impact on the state's job growth and housing markets.

In a recent report, Sterne Agee analyst Jay McCanless lowered his fourth-quarter EPS estimates forKB Home (KBH) given its exposure to states with large oil plays, including Texas, New Mexico and Colorado.
KB stock has plummeted 25% since the builder on Tuesday reported Q4 earnings well below consensus estimates and warned that softer demand will hurt its margins.
Thursday, Lennar stock fell 7% as that company also warned, in its Q4 report, that margins will soften.

In a recent report on Lennar, McCanless said he is "apprehensive about the Houston market based on recent oil price declines as well as recent economic commentary predicting slower job growth in that market." A similar concern was raised in a research note he issued on Beazer and "the potential effects lower oil prices might have on Texas buyer sentiment."

The NAR's Yun shares those concerns. Based on his analysis of the oil market, he expects oil prices to "remain low" the next two or three years. This will likely have an impact on Texas jobs and housing.

"I don't see job cuts necessarily, but we won't see the same level of job creation in Texas," Yun said.If location (location, location) is indeed the key to success in real estate, then homebuilders with operations in Seattle, Salt Lake City, Nashville, Tenn., Atlanta and Boston should see good times in 2015.Those are among cities cited by economists as having the best housing market gains this year based on job growth, housing demand, home price strength and other factors. Homebuilders rose Wednesday on reports that President Barack Obama is expected to announce changes to the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage-insurance premiums. But private insurers fell as competition for mortgage insurance will increase.Obama is seen as cutting annual fees to guarantee mortgages by 0.5 percentage point, according to multiple media reports. That's a turnaround from the premium hikes seen since 2011 to make up for defaults on mortgages after the housing bubble popped. Fees are now at 1.35% of the loan balance.Private insurers fell hard on the report of increased competition from the government in the sector.MGIC Investment (MTG) fell 5.1% to 8.51 on the stock market today. Essent Group (ESNT) plunged 9% to 23. Radian Group (RDN) shares were down 5.1% to 15.68.But homebuilders jumped on the news of more possible homebuyers as millenials look to move out of their parents' houses or away from roommates. KB Home (KBH) shares rose 4.9% to 16.31. D.R. Horton (DHI) shares jumped 5.7% to 35.48.In October, the Census Bureau reported that the homeownership rate in the U.S. fell to the lowest level since early 1995, in part due to entry-level buyers' inability to pass strict mortgage standards.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter: @IBD_GRich.

Yearly home price gains decelerated for the 11th straight month in the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Index for October. The yearly increase was 4.5%, as expected, though the monthly rise of 0.8% was more than expected and much greater than the 0.2% notched in September. Annual price gains aren't matching those seen during the housing bubble or the ones recorded after the…

Attracting first-time homebuyers might seem like courting a herd of underfed cats.Squeezed by tight credit, student debt and low wages, they're still the missing link to a robust housing recovery.But not for LGI Homes (NASDAQ:LGIH), a small homebuilder based near Houston. It sends 12,000 pieces of direct mail "every single week" to renters in complexes within 25 miles of one of its active communities, says CEO Eric Lipar.With homes selling for under $200,000 — the average in the past quarter was $166,000 — first-time buyers are the company's prime customers.They've been flocking to its communities, some 38 at last count, including markets in Texas, Arizona, Florida, Georgia and Colorado.About 95% of LGI buyers are renters. Their interest "is triggered by getting a rental-notice increase," Lipar told IBD. "Rising rents work to our advantage for sure."LGI, which went public a year ago, closed sale on 2,110 homes through the end of November compared with 1,617 for all of 2013."When a lot of builders were getting out of entry-level, we stuck with it, and we've always been profitable," Lipar said. "Our plan is to stick with first-time buyers."The company may see busier days, as could other builders aiming at first-timers, such as large-cap builder D.R. Horton (NYSE:DHI), with its low-priced Express Homes.At a little over 30% of the overall homebuying market, the share of first-time buyers in 2014 hit its lowest point in nearly 30 years, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).Homes Easier To Afford?Affordability is still an issue, but early signs are emerging of a better climate for first-time buyers, including an improving job market.For the three months ended in November, employment in America grew 2% year over year, the strongest rate since the first quarter of 2006. And the key first-time-buyer cohort — the missing 25- to 29-year-olds — showed a 3% gain.Though new jobs "are not as high-paying as in the past, it's still acceleration," said Sam Khater, deputy chief economist with property researcher CoreLogic (NYSE:CLGX). "So it should foreshadow an increase in demand for first-time buyers."A second reason may also help: Institutional investors are leaving the market. That means "less competition for starter homes," said Lawrence Yun, chief economist with the NAR.Investors paying all cash for starter homes had bid up prices, shutting out many first-time buyers. But price gains are decelerating.The latest S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices show a slight drop in the 10- and 20-city composites in October vs. September. They still were up 4.4% and 4.5%, respectively, from a year earlier."I call it a more organic market, less influenced by distressed sales and artificial support from quantitative easing" by the Feds, Khater said. He added that "2015 will really be the first year (in many) that both volumes and price movements will reflect fundamentals — meaning supply, demand and income."That shift is "beginning to be reflected in home prices," he said.Markets On The MoveKhater notes that many markets with the biggest price gains in 2014 had the strongest underlying economies, based especially on technology and energy industries.Pricey San Francisco, a leading tech center, showed the biggest monthly gain of all 20 cities in Case-Shiller's latest survey, at nearly 1% in October over September.Khater points out that lower-priced homes are seeing faster growth than higher-end homes in the top 25 U.S. housing markets, reflecting tight supply and a lack of new construction for single-family starter homes.Some markets, such as those in the Carolinas and Texas, are seeing robust construction and sales trends, he says.Falling oil prices may make energy-capital Houston — one of the country's hottest home markets recently — and other Texas markets "vulnerable" to a slowdown in new oil-related jobs in 2015, says the NAR's Yun.Still, the Lone Star State is diversified, "so it may be able to withstand the potential decline because other sectors of the economy continue to show strength," he said. Also, Texas has more affordable homes relative to many other housing markets around the nation.Jobs And Sun Belt MigrationYun sees housing demand growing in Rocky Mountain states such as Colorado and Utah, thanks to strong job growth.Meanwhile, Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas are benefiting from corporate relocations as well as retirees moving in."I see opportunities on two ends," said John Burns, CEO of John Burns Real Estate Consulting in Irvine, Calif."The entry-level buyer will come back, though more slowly than most people think," he said. "And the older buyer — the retiree — is already back and buying homes, a lot of them paying all cash."Today's generation of first-time buyers are older than their predecessors because they have delayed marriage and having children, Burns says."The ultimate impetus (for buying a first home) is when you need to put a child into a school. We're seeing more of those buyers," he said.Still waiting to make their move are many buyers who bought entry-level homes in the early 2000s and saw their homes plummet in value during the housing downturn. Now largely in their early 40s, they don't have enough equity to move, Burns says.He expects that older baby boomers will continue to support the housing market in 2015 and beyond as they sell their homes at a profit and then use the cash to buy other homes."We're seeing active-adult communities pop up all over the country," Burns said. "They're doing great."Especially active on that front is homebuilder PulteGroup (NYSE:PHM), with its Del Webb Communities.In a report this week, analyst Jay McCanless of Sterne Agee said he prefers builders "who concentrate on older, move-up buyers bringing equity from their previous home to the closing table."His top picks among that group are PulteGroup, WCI Communities (NYSE:WCIC) and Ryland Group (NYSE:RYL).New low-down-payment programs from Fannie Mae (OTCBB:FNMA) and Freddie Mac (OTCBB:FMCC) may spur healthy order growth for eligible first-time buyers in 2015, he noted, "if originators take the bait."He expects the lack of mortgage availability for first-time and subprime buyers to continue into 2015 "because we do not believe banks are being compensated for the tail risk on mortgages."Still, slower price appreciation opens up opportunities for potential new homebuyers after months and years of robust price gains "acted to squeeze out new buyers," noted Lindsey Piegza, chief economist with Sterne Agee, in a report this week."Slower price gains and still historically low interest rates (around 4%) may work to encourage new demand in 2015," she wrote.Housing watchers don't expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates much, if at all, in the near term, perhaps not until mid-2015 at the earliest.Meanwhile, CEO Lipar of LGI Homes is counting on more first-time buyers to come his way as they "save more and work on their credit scores.""Demand will always be there from people who rent," he said.

Major averages ended a five-session slide Wednesday, helped by strength in European markets overnight and Fed minutes that didn't contain any major surprises.The Nasdaq added 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each added 1.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in lower than Tuesday's levels.Gains were strong ahead of the release of the Fed minutes at 2 p.m. ET, and the market held gains after the minutes revealed that members think the U.S. economy could surprise to the upside. The Fed also said that low inflation would not be a deterrent to raising rates.In the stock market today, several retail-related groups and homebuilders outperformed.Department stores got a lift after laggard J.C. Penney (JCP) reported strong holiday sales data. Shares soared 20%. Meanwhile, top-rated names in the group like Macy's (M) and Dillard's (DDS) outperformed, rising 4% each.Among homebuilders, Lennar (LEN) reclaimed its 50-day moving average, rising 5% in fast trade. Volume was also heavy in D.R. Horton (DHI) as shares rose 5%. It closed just below a flat-base entry of 26.04.Elsewhere, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) snapped a seven-session losing streak, rising nearly 5%, on news of a partnership with Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS)And thinly traded WD-40 (WDFC) added 1.5% ahead of its earnings report after the close. It's been a solid performer after a base breakout over 78.24 in early December.In economic news, payroll processor ADP said private businesses added 241,000 jobs in December, mostly in line with expectations.

Existing-home sales fell 6.1% in November, the worst monthly decline since 2010, to an annualized 4.93 million units, the National Association of Realtors said Monday. The data suggest that the housing recovery continues to move in fits and starts. The home-resales report was much worse than expected. Bad weather in much of the U.S. may have been a factor in…

Stocks overcame early weakness to finish higher Monday, adding to last week's positive action. The Nasdaq rose 0.3% after bouncing back from an 0.5% loss. Monday marked the tech-heavy index's sixth straight gain — the longest winning streak since late November. But when it broke the streak, the Nasdaq went on a 5.5% pullback. The S&P 500 also rebounded from…

Housing starts fell in November, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, missing expectations. But prior months were revised higher and the building uptrend remains intact.Builders broke ground on an annualized 1.028 million units, down 1.6% decline vs. October and slightly less than expected. But prior months were revised higher, with October's level raised to 1.045 million from the initial 1.009 million.Single-family starts slid 5.4% vs. October's near-7-year high. Building permits retreated, but also from multiyear highs.Most homebuilder stocks rose in early afternoon trade as the general market rebounded. Lennar (LEN) rose 0.8% and KBHome (KBH) 1.3% intraday on the stock market today. Ryland (RYL) and Pulte Group (PHM) rose 0.4%. But D.R. Horton (DHI) fell 0.1%.
Toll Bros. (TOL) and Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV) will report quarterly earnings Wednesday as homebuilders look for renewed growth after the post-recession building boom cooled off early this year.
Their stocks and those of 25 other homebuilders in IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group collectively climbed 140% in the three years from March 7, 2011, to March 7, 2014.
They've traded in a fairly narrow range the past nine months, but recent housing reports have lifted hopes.

Existing-home sales rose in October to their best level since September 2013, the National Association of Realtors said Nov. 20, the latest good news for housing. Existing-home sales rose for the sixth time in the past seven months, climbing to an annualized pace of 5.26 million.

Toll Bros., which is slated to report fiscal fourth-quarter earnings Wednesday after the market closes, has posted strong results this year and its stock has a strong 82 IBD Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99.

Consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the luxury homebuilder to report a 35% hike in earnings to 73 cents per share on a 28% increase in revenue to $1.33 billion. However, the company's year-over-year EPS growth rate is projected to shrink for a fourth quarter in a row. In the prior three quarters it grew 633%, 289% and 104%.
Sterne Agee, which rates Toll Bros. underperform with a 26 price target, said in a Thursday report it sees its stock as fully valued at the current level.
"Toll's quarterly unit orders missed the FactSet consensus estimate by an average of 116 homes in the first three quarters" of this year, Sterne Agee analyst Jay McCanless said in the report.
McCanless said the question is, "Can Toll break the streak of unit order misses?"
Hovnanian is scheduled to announce fiscal Q4 earnings early Wednesday.

Analysts project Hovnanian's EPS will drop a penny to 20 cents per share from a year ago, but expect revenue to rise 9.3% to $646.8 million. Hovnanian posted losses the first two quarters of its fiscal year but reported an 11-cent profit last quarter, up from 6 cents a year earlier.

The nation's largest homebuilder, D.R. Horton (DHI), with nearly $20 billion in annual revenue, last Wednesday hit a nearly seven-year intraday high at 15.12 amid strong housing industry reports, giving the sector a lift.

Pulte Group (PHM) will hold an Investor's Day on Dec. 9, which it said will be its first in 10 years. The meeting could provide a deep dive into strategy and perhaps discussion of its recent purchase of privately held Dominion Homes.

Stocks stepped up to healthy gains in early trade Tuesday, as analyst upgrades and positive earnings reports appeared to trump another decline in oil prices.
The Nasdaq punched up 1.8%, the Dow Jones industrial average grabbed a 1.4% gain and the S&P 500 jumped 1.2%.

The stock market today showed a comparatively mild reaction to further declines in oil prices. Whereas energy sectors led much of Monday's selling, the S&P 500 was not showing particular weakness among energy stocks. On the Dow, bothExxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) were in positive territory. At the top of the Dow, Microsoft (MSFT), Merck (MRK) and United Technologies (UTX) were all up nearly 2%.

Economic news was light, dominated by the Labor Department's November Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. The JOLTS report showed employers reporting 4.973 positions unfilled, up from 4.83 million in October. Analyst consensus expected a slight increase, to 4.875 million.

On the earnings front, KB Homes (KBH) rose a fraction after reporting its Q4 revenue topped expectations. Earnings received a steep boost from a tax benefit, and new orders and average selling prices also rose. The stock has been looping through a deepening correction for 21 months.
Other homebuilders also climbed, with Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) each up 2%.

On the IBD 50 list, Celgene (CELG) swept up 4%. Drugmaker Agios Pharmaceuticals (AGIO) announced late Monday that Celgene would exercise its option to exclusive licensing rights outside the U.S. for AG-120, an oral cancer treatment. The gain sent Celgene to a new high, leaving it extended after a rebound from support at its 10-week moving average. Agios shares rose 2%.
Alaska Air Group (ALK) also hopped up 4% to take a new high. The heavy volume gain pushed shares 30% above a 48.35 buy point after an October breakout.

While U.S. housing officials discuss ways to give more Americans access to mortgage loans — including the hotly debated topic of loosening lending standards — little consensus exists over how these efforts might affect home sales. According to one estimate, yearly home sales in the U.S. could rise by double-digit percentages if mortgage lending standards reverted to what's termed normal…

The homebuilding comeback anticipated this year didn't happen.High expectations were built around views that demand would finally spike after years of post-recessionary lethargy among traditional buyers."2014 was a big disappointment," said Brad Hunter, chief economist at Metrostudy, a unit of Hanley Wood that studies the homebuilding sector."In the beginning of the year everyone thought single-family housing starts would be up 20%, and it turns out they will be up 4% (by Metrostudy's estimate)."But builders and other housing watchers are more confident about 2015, as building permits have recently increased.Even so, many housing watchers are not expecting a huge jump in new-home construction. "It is going to be very modest," said Lindsey Piegza, chief economist at Sterne Agee. "Arguably, it is what we want to see. It ensures a more sustainable recovery. I'd be concerned if we had seen another bubble run-up."Going Where The Buyers AreBuilders have learned to be patient and pace themselves. That means they are allocating resources to areas with the best demand, such as certain markets in Texas, California, Florida and Georgia — Forsyth County north of Atlanta, for example.Single-family housing starts in some markets were up as much as 45.8% over the 12 months ending Sept. 30, says Metrostudy. That high mark was in Naples/Fort Myers in Southwest Florida."It's a market that was badly beaten up during the downturn, but it's also a market with strong fundamentals," Hunter said.Besides being a retirement and second-home magnet for affluent buyers, the area has a university, growing middle class and job growth, he says."Wealthy people need estate planning, lawyers, accountants, bankers and medical care. There's a very large medical industry there," Hunter said.Top homebuilders in the Naples/Fort Myers market are PulteGroup's (PHM) active-adult division Del Webb, Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI), according to a survey by drive-by teams from Metrostudy.Existing-home prices in the region's Lee County are back to early 2004 levels and new homes are mostly in the $300,000 to $400,000 range, Hunter says.Home construction in Southern California is up 28.4% in the same recent 12-month period, Metrostudy says, with the greatest gains in another bruised area, the Inland Empire east of Los Angeles."All the excess supply is gone," Hunter said of the Inland Empire's Riverside-San Bernardino area near the I-15 corridor flanking L.A. "That area turned around from being massively overbuilt and with falling prices to coming back strong and prices moving up."The top two builders in that market are KB Home (KBH) and Lennar, according to Metrostudy.Lennar is also active in other parts of California and in Texas, including Houston, which is the No. 1 market for housing starts.Still, Stuart Miller, CEO of Lennar, believes the housing market is far from recovered. In remarks after the firm's latest quarterly results were released, he compared the "extremely low volume of dwellings" built over the past seven years to a housing depression."Before this downturn, anything below 1 million housing starts in a year was considered almost a housing depression," he said. "This recovery is just now getting us back to that level of starts."The recovery is still only at the "halfway" mark back to normal, says David Crowe, chief economist with the National Association of Home Builders. He was referring largely to single-family homes, which he said comprises the bulk of the home-building industry."This is a much slower recovery (than) from any of the recessions since the Great Depression," Crowe said.However, multifamily construction, mostly rental apartments, is back to normal as builders try to satisfy demand from millennials and others who can't afford or don't want to buy a home just yet."A normal market would be at least 1.5 million housing starts (annually)," said Piegza. "We were down to 500,000 (in 2009) and it took five years to make progress up to 1 million. Given that trajectory, it would be five-plus years to get to 1.5 million, when we can say it's a healthy market."Overall housing starts in October were pacing at an annualized rate of a little over 1 million units, 2.8% below the revised September estimate but 7.8% above October 2013, the Census Bureau said last week.Crowe of the builders' trade group thinks a back-to-normal builders' market will occur sooner, in 2017. There would have to be a lot of fast catching-up.Crowe thinks single-family home starts will increase next year to around 800,000, from an expected 640,000 this year. If that comes to fruition, it would be the best gain since the recession ended.New-Home Sales Rise SlowlyActual sales of new single-family homes tracked at an annualized pace of 458,000 in October, the Census Bureau said Wednesday. That is just 0.7% above September's revised rate and 1.8% above the 450,000 seen in October 2013."The low was about 350,000, so we haven't made much progress in terms of home sales," Piegza said.Like other housing watchers, she blames the usual suspects: strict lending, slow wage growth and low numbers of first-time homebuyers, due in part to millennials being dragged down by student debt and low wages."It comes back to the ability to finance, access to credit and being able to put 20% down," she said. "Credit is looser, but it is still tight."Toll Bros. (TOL), which targets the luxury market, is not as impacted by credit challenges as builders with lots of entry-level products. Its buyers typically put 30% down, and 20% pay all cash, Hunter says, "so they are somewhat insulated from these mortgage issues these days."October's median price of a new house rose to $305,000 in October from $264,300 a year earlier, the Census Bureau said. That gain "reinforces our view that move-up and luxury buyers remain the most eligible buyer in the U.S. market," noted analyst Jay McCanless of Sterne Agee.As for existing homes, pending sales fell modestly in October, according to the National Association of Realtors' Pending Home Sales Index, which is based on contract signings. The index fell 1.1% to 104.1 from 105.3 in September. Anything above 100 is viewed as an average level of contract activity.Lawrence Yun, NAR's chief economist, noted less competition from investors paying all cash.The median price for an existing home of any type in October rose 5.5% from a year earlier to $208,300. Last year through October the average month's year-over-year gain was 11.5%, the NAR says.Price gains, moderating though they are, give previously stuck homeowners with little or no equity "the ability to sell," Yun noted. And when an existing home sells, oftentimes the seller will move into a newly built home.

Japan's Abe delays tax hike, calls snap electionA day after Q3 GDP data showed that Japan's economy had slipped into another recession in the wake of the April sales tax hike, PM Shinzo Abe put on hold the next round of sales tax increases set for late 2015 and called a snap election to be held next month. He said that he is seeking a mandate for delaying the tax hike. But results could weaken his party's hold on the parliament, and a snap vote is widely unpopular. The Nikkei stock index rallied 2.2%.Homebuilder sentiment rises in NovemberThe National Association of Home Builders' Housing Market Index rose 4 points to 58, near September's 9-year high. Homebuilders are more confident about current and future sales, and less gloomy about buyer traffic. The index follows generally upbeat earnings and orders from builders D.R. Horton (DHI), Beazer Homes (BZH) and Toll Bros. (TOL) last week, but housing activity remains well off boom-era peaks.Producer costs rise, a surpriseThe producer price index (PPI) rose 0.2% in October, defying expectations for a 0.1% decline, the Labor Dept. said. Wholesale gasoline prices plunged 5.8%, but auto costs leapt on new 2015 model sticker prices. Beef and pork costs rose about 6%. Meanwhile, wholesale prices for services leapt 0.5%, the most since July 2013. The PPI ex food and energy advanced 0.4%. Still, with gas prices continuing to tumble this month, economists aren't worried about inflation. Wholesale inflation was just 1.6% last month. Same-store sales rose 0.2% in the week ended Nov. 15 after a 1.5% gain in the prior week, according to the ICSC-Goldman tally. The year-over-year change ticked up to 2.2% from 2.1%.German investors are upbeatThe ZEW institute's gauge of investors' economic sentiment leapt 15.1 points in November to 3.6, after October's negative reading, the first since 2012. It was the ZEW index's first monthly increase of 2014. Recent eurozone GDP data suggest that the economy is stabilizing, according to ZEW Pres. Clemens Fuest. "However, the economic environment remains fragile, not least due to ongoing geopolitical tensions." Europe's No. 1 economy has struggled amid eurozone woes and Western sanctions vs. Russia over Ukraine. U.K. inflation rose to 1.3% in October from September's 5-year-low of 1.2%. But the cost of food and non-alcoholic beverages sank 1.4% vs. a year ago, the 6th straight decline. U.K. retail grocery sales fell 0.2% in the 12 weeks to Nov. 9 vs. a year earlier, the first such decline in 20 years, research firm Kantar Worldpanel said, citing price competition.China home prices still fallingNew home prices fell 2.6% in October vs. a year earlier after September's 1.3% decline, according to Reuters calculations of official data released by the National Bureau of Statistics. Home prices fell 0.8% vs. September, the 6th straight monthly decline, but a smaller drop after Spitballer's 1% fall and August's 1.1% slide. After efforts to cool housing, China's gov't has taken several steps to ease credit to prevent a housing collapse.

From flat income growth to housing crash nightmares, potential first-time homebuyers possess plenty of reasons to shy from ownership, a trend that could aggravate weakening home price appreciation.The National Association of Realtors (NAR) early this month said that first-time homebuyers accounted for 33% of the market in its latest annual survey, a year-over-year drop of five percentage points and well below the long-term average of 40%.It's the lowest first-timer participation rate since 1987, and it coincides with the NAR's forecast that 4.9 million home sales in 2014 will fall 200,000 short of last year's total. Among impediments, the NAR and other observers say that student debt burdens and rising rents hinder the ability of young adults to save for a down payment.What's more, many young professionals are underemployed. Those who have landed jobs haven't enjoying the same wage growth as baby boomers and Generation X, says Stan Humphries, chief economist for Seattle-based online housing marketplace Zillow (Z).Those demand suppressors may require home sellers to dial back price expectations, particularly in the short term."Assuming that income growth returns to normal, it won't have any long-term impact," said Humphries, referring to the dearth of first-time homebuyers. "But right now we are having trouble getting income growth back to normal, and we can't have a functional economy or a functional housing market without it."Paycheck DoldrumsPrivate-sector average hourly wages haven't increased more than about 2% annually the past few years, and growth in 2014 is on pace to continue the trend, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.In addition to enduring miserly income expansion and other demand inhibitors, millennials are also avoiding marriage and baby rearing, which typically lead to home purchases, Humphries says.After increasing 19% from the trough in February 2012 to the end of 2013, home price appreciation across 20 major cities has been slowing for a large part of this year, according to the most recent S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices.Average year-over-year appreciation of 5.5% in August was 110 basis points lower than the annual gain in July, according to the report. Moreover, price growth in August was just 0.2%, compared with 0.6% in July."We've had a nice period of growth in home prices," said Daren Blomquist, a vice president of Irvine, Calif.-based RealtyTrac, a provider of housing data and analytics. "But I think we're going into a period of stagnant price appreciation, and the only thing that could change that is if incomes went up."Few ChoicesPart of the decelerating price increases can be traced to single-family home investors pulling back in the bellwether markets of Phoenix, Southern California and Atlanta, among others, Blomquist says.Aggressive investors primarily acquired entry-level homes and pushed up prices as much as 30% in some markets, he says. That in turn helped many "underwater" homeowners — those with more mortgage debt than the home is worth — return to positive equity.But ballooning price appreciation priced many entry-level buyers out of the market, adds Blomquist, who estimates that 8 million homeowners are still underwater, down from 13 million a couple of years ago.The still-large number of underwater homeowners is crimping supply, Humphries says, because a majority live in entry-level houses and can't sell them."Even if buyers have navigated the demand issues — they have a decent job with a decent wage, and are married and having kids and want to buy a home," Humphries said, "the number of homes available is dramatically less than it was pre-recession."Low Down PaymentsBlomquist is skeptical about the effectiveness of a plan that Federal Housing Finance Agency head Mel Watt has introduced, which would allow Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FMCC) to purchase home loans that are made to "lower-wealth borrowers" who make a 3% down payment.The Federal Housing Administration already has a 3% down payment program, and Fannie and Freddie can now buy mortgages with as little as a 5% down payment, he says.A recent RealtyTrac study also found that, even with a 3% down payment, would-be buyers with a median income and an average student or car loan would be able to afford a monthly mortgage payment in only 48% of U.S. counties. Without debt, 92% of the counties would be affordable."In my mind, the biggest thing weighing down first-time homebuyers right now is debt," Blomquist said.Homebuilders Stepping UpFederal agencies aren't alone in their efforts to stimulate home buying, however. Forth Worth, Texas-based D.R. Horton (DHI) is rolling out its Express Homes division in the Southwest, Texas and the Southeast, focusing on attracting entry-level purchasers for homes priced around $150,000.Meanwhile, LGI Homes (LGIH), based in The Woodlands, Texas, is solely focused on the entry-level homebuyer in virtually the same regions. It not only offers homes for around $165,000 but also provides credit counseling and no-down-payment financing for qualified homebuyers.Homebuilders of late have generally focused on building much pricier homes, particularly given that lots entitled for development have escalated in cost, says Jody Kahn, senior vice president of Irvine-based John Burns Real Estate Consulting, an independent housing industry researcher and consulting firm."But a lot of builders are anxious to see a return of the first-time homebuyer segment," said Kahn, who conducts monthly surveys of 225 homebuilding executives from the firm's Portsmouth, N.H., office. "Even builders that don't cater 100% to the entry-level buyer say that they're seeing an uptick in entry-level traffic, which is a step in the right direction."

Beazer Homes (BZH) reported a jump in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and revenue on Wednesday.
The homebuilder said EPS was $1.90 vs. 36 cents a year ago. Revenue from homebuilding climbed 14.8% to $500.6 million, while total revenue rose to $545.9 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting earnings of $1.08 per share.
Shares were up nearly 3% in premarket trading on the stock market today.
New home orders fell 1.6% to 1,173 vs. a year go. Total backlog fell to 1,690 homes with a sales value of $515.9 million vs. 1,893 homes with a sales value of $528.1 million a year ago.
On Tuesday, D.R. Horton (DHI) reported a 12.5% jump in fiscal Q4 EPS to 45 cents, falling short of analyst views by 3 cents. Revenue climbed 33% to $2.4 billion, above views.
Sterne Agee downgraded D.R. Horton to neutral from buy on Wednesday and slashed its price target to 23 from 25 on the homebuilder's weak 2015 guidance for closings.
On Monday Toll Bros. (TOL) pre-announced a 29.3% rise in Q4 revenue.

Stocks meandered and ended with small gains on this Veterans Day Tuesday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up a hair. Volume fell on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Among leading stocks, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2% in strong volume after reporting mixed quarterly results. Before the open, the homebuilder reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 45 cents a share, or 3 cents below views. But sales grew 33% to more than $2.4 billion, which topped expectations. The stock cleared a 23.41 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Monday.

Lennar (LEN) climbed 2% to its best levels since May 2007. It's now 10% past a 42.07 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. In September, the homebuilder beat views with a 44% increase in Q3 earnings and a 26% rise in sales.
Alibaba (BABA) fell 4%, ending a red hot, six-session win streak. Shares were weak Tuesday despite news that the Chinese e-commerce giant did a record $9.3 billion in transactions on Singles Day.

Alibaba was also on the receiving end of some positive actions by analysts. Oppenheimer started coverage with an outperform rating and 133 price target. And Bank of America/Merrill Lynch raised its price target to 132 from 122.

The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

Prices moderated in June, but remain above winter levels, and the number of people saying it's a good time to sell…
Stock futures were up, but had pulled back from early highs ahead of Thursday's open despite a surprise jump in mid-Atlantic region manufacturing.

Dow futures traded 19.8 points above fair market value, down from a 33-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures held a 16.3-point gain, sticking close to earlier highs. S&P 500 futures pulled back to a 5.3-point gain.

The stock market today carries a bit less weight on its shoulders after the S&P 500 decisively punched past its 50-day moving average and the Nasdaq gained more altitude above that important line of support on Wednesday.

Investors drew confidence after minutes from the Fed's Oct. 28 meeting showed a majority of the Federal Open Market Committee in favor of a rate hike in December. Apple (AAPL) also factored into the day's gains, gapping up to a better-than-3% gain after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs.

The current uptrend still bears a heavy load of distribution days: six on the Nasdaq, five on the S&P 500. That is good cause to keep a cautious stance toward new purchases or stocks flashing sell signals.

A relatively light economic calendar opened with the Labor Department reporting weekly jobless claims eased to 271,000 in the week ended Nov. 14, down from 276,000 in the prior week. Economist consensus had forecast a pullback to 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average continued higher, to 270,750, marking its third straight advance.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey firmed up for November, rising to 1.9. That beat consensus expectations for a flat outcome. The index fell to a minus 4.5 reading in October following a minus 6 tally in September.
The Conference Board is set to release its leading economic indicators index for October at 10 a.m. ET.

On the Dow, UnitedHealth (UNH) dropped 6% in premarket action. The Minnetonka, Minn.-based managed care provider trimmed its full-year EPS guidance to $6, down from $6.25 to $6.35 and below consensus views for $6.32. The company said claims activity deteriorated and individual participation in insurance exchanges lagged.

Sellers kept up the pressure on retail and apparel makers, sending Best Buy (BBY) down 9% and Perry Ellis (PERY) to a 4% loss after mixed quarterly reports. Buckle (BKE) and Bon-Ton Stores (BONT) reported Q3 earnings misses, although the stocks remained unchanged in premarket trade.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) swept ahead 17%, topping the S&P 500 in premarket action. The owner of the K-cup coffee franchise trounced analysts' Q4 earnings expectations. Revenue fell less than forecast, and management boosted the quarterly dividend by 13% to 32.5 cents. Keurig shares ended Wednesday down 75% from a November high.

Salesforce.com (CRM) jabbed up 5% before the bell. A 50% EPS leap and a 24% gain in Q3 revenue narrowly cleared analyst consensus projections. Revenue and earnings projections for Q4 were in line with analyst views, and management hoisted full-year EPS guidance to just above consensus. The software-as-a-service leader ended Wednesday in buying range, a bit more than 1% above a 76.31 cup-base buy point.
Some China-based plays chalked off strong premarket moves.
Ctrip.com International (CTRP) soared 13% higher after delivering its Q3 results. The online travel site ended Wednesday 18% above an 80.30 buy point in a double-bottom base.

China-based micro-blogging site Weibo (WB) shot up 8% in premarket trade. It reported EPS of 10 cents, up from a 1-cent, per-share loss a year ago and above views for 6 cents. Revenue surged a better-than-forecast 48%. Four top-rated stocks from disparate industries, including arts and crafts retail chain Michaels (MIK), were being heavily accumulated by investors Tuesday and made the IBD Stocks On The Move list. Michaels operates more than 1,100 Michaels and about 120 Aaron Bros. stores. Its stock gapped up to the highest point since the company launched its initial public offering in June.…
Stock futures remained positive, although gains narrowed ahead of Tuesday's Veterans Day holiday session.
Dow futures held 13.3 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5.6 points, and S&P 500 futures showed a 2.4-point gain.

Trade is likely to be quiet on the stock market today , with the schedule showing no significant economic releases and a fairly short list of company reports. But rumblings were afoot on a broader scale, with a potentially meaningful U.S.-China agreement to remove tariffs from technology such as medical devices and next-generation semiconductors.
In the U.S., stock markets will operate regular sessions during today's Veterans Day holiday, but bond markets will be closed.

In stocks, Vodafone Group (VOD) and Rackspace Hosting (RAX) each punched up 6% after reporting healthy third-quarter results. Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) was down a fraction after its quarterly report.

Qiwi (QIWI) — a Cyprus-based operator of a network of financial kiosks in Russia and neighboring countries — spiked 13% after trouncing analysts' Q3 earnings forecasts. Revenue rose 47%, also topping views. The company guided Q4 and full-year earnings and revenue in line with forecasts. The stock has been caught up in a deep consolidation since January.

Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) fell 6% after announcing late Monday a follow-on offering of 15 million shares, held by private investor Apollo Global Management. The company said it would issue no shares in the offering. Sprouts is working through a year-long consolidation, but still 75% above its IPO price.

Overseas markets were generally positive. The dollar climbed vs. the yen and was steady against the euro. Stocks were little changed Tuesday afternoon in light Veterans Day trading, with banks, government offices and the bond market taking the day off.In the stock market today, homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) reported earnings of 45 cents a share before the open. That was below expectations of 48 cents, but the stock rose 2% anyway. The stock has broken out of a double-bottom base with a handle and is 3% above the 23.41 buy point.Among IBD 50 stocks, 21 were higher and 29 were lower. Boise Cascade (BCC) was the best performer, up 3%. The stock has made a big move since finding support at its 200-day moving average and is trading at an all-time high, extended from its latest entry.The worst performers were chipmaker Ambarella (AMBA), down 6%, and Chinese automobile website Autohome (ATHM), down 5%.Sierra Wireless (SWIR) was up for the fourth straight day, rising nearly 2% Tuesday at midday. It's been rallying since reporting quarterly earnings Thursday that were 118% above a year ago. Shares are nearly 20% above a 30.65 buy point.Juniper Networks (JNPR) dropped 4%. The company announced late Monday that CEO Shaygan Kheradpir had resigned following a "review by the board of directors of his leadership and his conduct in connection with a particular negotiation with a customer."The stock has been in a downtrend for most of the year.

Michael Jay, a New England radiologist just retired at age 64, traded heating bills and Massachusetts state income taxes for a three-bedroom home on a Florida golf course. "If you don't need a big Northeast job, then there's nice living in other parts of the country," said Jay, who moved with his wife, Susan, to a 55-and-up community near Tampa.…
Stocks squeezed out small gains in a listless session Tuesday.
The Nasdaq edged up 0.2% and the S&P 500 rose 0.1%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a fractional gain.
Volume dropped off on both major exchanges in the stock market today due to Veterans Day. The bond market was closed.

After the close, shares of Fossil Group (FOSL) shot up 15% on better-than-expected Q3 results. The maker of watches and accessories posted earnings of $1.96 a share on sales on $894.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a profit of $1.82 a share on revenue of $879.05 million.

Better-than-expected quarterly results also boosted YY (YY). The Chinese social media firm reported earnings of 87 cents a share, up 85% from 47 cents in the year-ago period. Views were for 76 cents a share. Sales more than doubled to $163 million, beating views for $152.54 million. It rose 2% in extended trading.
Fellow leading stocks moved in Tuesday's regular session.

D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2% in heavy trading after reporting mixed quarterly results. Before the open, the homebuilder reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 45 cents a share, up 12% but 3 cents below views. Q3 profit had declined 24%. But sales grew 33% to more than $2.4 billion, which topped expectations. The stock cleared a 23.41 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Monday.

Lennar (LEN) climbed 2% and stretched its win streak to five sessions. It's now 10% past a 42.07 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. In September, the homebuilder beat views with a 44% increase in Q3 earnings and a 26% rise in sales.
Alibaba (BABA) fell 4%, ending a red hot, six-session win streak. Shares were weak Tuesday despite news that the Chinese e-commerce giant did a record $9.3 billion in transactions on Singles Day.

Alibaba was also on the receiving end of some positive actions by analysts. Oppenheimer started coverage with an outperform rating and a 133 price target. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch raised its price target to 132 from 122.

New-home sales set a new standard for volatility, as an August reading that was previously reported as an annualized 504,000 was revised down to 466,000. Other prior months were also revised down. So September's sales rose slightly, rather than declining, as had been expected. The 467,000 annual rate is now the highest of the recovery, though still a fraction of…
Better-than-expected results from the big banks may give listless financial-sector ETFs just the jolt they need.

Wells Fargo (WFC) announced on July 11 that its second-quarter earnings met expectations and that revenue beat analyst estimates. Later reports from its peers, such as Citigroup (C), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), continued the favorable trend.
The latter three gained 4% to 5% last week, helping improve their lagging IBD Relative Strength Ratings. Wells, already boasting the highest RS of the four, ended the week nearly flat.

"These recent earnings statements appear to have reignited a spark within this subsector, and asset flows into this space have increased," said Nathan Kubik, a principal of Carnick & Kubik, which manages $300 million in assets.
While investors are likely to reward the results in the short term, that could change, given concerns about "the exposure these big banks have to shifts in the yield curve," he added.

Compared with 2013 and the stock market, ETFs offering broad exposure to the U.S. financials sector have lagged this year. Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) has risen 5.6%, Vanguard Financials (VFH) climbed 5.6% and iShares US Financials (IYF) is up 5.2%.
By comparison, they gained 35.5%, 32.9% and 34%, respectively, last year.
Top holdings of the funds include banking heavyweights Wells Fargo, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America (BAC), U.S. Bancorp (USB), Goldman Sachs and BlackRock (BLK).

The cushion provided by those stocks is part of why broad-based financial ETFs have outperformed some more specialized ETFs, such as those tracking smaller banks, since earlier this year, according to Neena Mishra, director of ETF research at Zacks Investment Research. Investment banks have benefited from strong underwriting and M&A activities, she says. Rising equity markets have helped drive asset managers. But major subindustries within the sector, including smaller banks and insurance, are expected to show year-over-year earnings declines.
"One of the most important sources of income in recent years — the mortgage refinance boom — is now almost over," Mishra said.
This year, SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) is down 3.4% vs. a 47.5% gain in 2013.
IShares US Regional Banks (IAT) has climbed 2.3% vs. 37.7% last year.

And SPDR S&P Mortgage Finance (KME) is off 0.74% in 2014 after rising 32.5% the year before. Its top holdings include mortgage, homebuilding and insurance companies such as Ryland Group (RYL), D.R. Horton (DHI) and XL Group (XL).
The banking industry continues to face fallout from the 2008 financial crisis, including stricter regulations and a rise in legal costs.

Market analysts also worry about limited opportunities to lend profitably in a slow economy. Still, "banks are in much better health now with solid capital levels" because of closer oversight and cost-cutting measures, Mishra said. "Interest rates should start inching up in the months to come, which will benefit banks."

Meanwhile, insurers may offer medium-term opportunities for investors. Despite bland performance year to date, insurers are attractive based on valuation and expected returns, and "are well positioned for the next 12 months," Kubik said.Better-than-expected results from the big banks may give listless financial-sector ETFs just the jolt they need.Wells Fargo (WFC) announced on July 11 that its second-quarter earnings met expectations and that revenue beat analyst estimates. New-home construction is rising, but in fits and starts and not as fast as many had expected. Meanwhile, the repair and remodeling market, which lags new home starts, is in the early stages of recovery. Yet Stock Building Supply (STCK), which distributes lumber, doors, windows and other building products to homebuilders and contractors, is growing faster than its end markets.…

KB Home's  (KBH) fiscal third-quarter results fell well short of forecasts despite higher average selling prices as deliveries fell. Revenue rose 7.3% to $589.2 million, below analyst estimates for $646.8 million, and per-share earnings dipped 6.7% to 28 cents, 12 cents below views. Net orders increased 5% to 1,827, and West Coast orders jumped 24%. Shares of the homebuilder…

New-home sales surged to an annual rate of 504,000 in August, up 18% in the month. Even for a normally volatile report, that's the biggest monthly jump since 1992. Sales crushed expectations of a 430,000 rate, while July figures were revised up to 427,000 from 412,000. It was the highest monthly rate since May 2008. Months' supply of new homes…

Toll Bros. (TOL) pre-announced a 29.3% fourth-quarter revenue rise as the average price of homes delivered rose 6.3% year over year to $747,000 and homebuilding revenue grew especially in the Western region. By early afternoon, shares of the company, which builds luxury homes in 19 states, had jumped 3.4% to 33.31 in the stock market today, Monday. The company will…

Here is why shares of biotech Gilead Sciences (GILD) and three four other highly rated stocks are rallying in heavy volume today.Gilead began running up in premarket trading after drug giant Merck (MRK) said Sunday it would not move forward with development of a drug combination aimed at shortening treatment time for hepatitis C, citing disappointing clinical data. The treatment would have used Gilead's Sovaldi, but also would compete with the current, longer-term regimen based on Sovaldi.Gilead, whose stock tops the IBD Leaderboard list of best-performing stocks, was up 0.7% in above-average volume in Monday afternoon trading in the stock market today. Gilead shares had risen further. Merck pared losses for a 0.6% decline.General acute care hospital operator HCA Holdings (HCA) rebounded from Friday's selloff, which came after the Supreme Court said it will hear a case challenging the legality of ObamaCare's premium subsidies in 36 states.Shares of hospitals sold off heavily Friday on fears they could lose patients who pay if the court strikes down the subsidies. HCA sank nearly 5% on Friday, but was up 2% Monday afternoon. Community Health System (CYH), which operates 135 hospitals, fell 5.5% Friday and was up nearly 3%.Ambarella's (AMBA) stock climbed 3.5% intraday Monday. The chipmaker supplies chips to camera makers, including popular sports enthusiast on-body camera maker GoPro (GPRO). GoPro shares fell 3% after it said it will sell about $800 million worth of shares to raise funds, which will dilute its stock price.Until Monday, GoPro and on-body camera rivals Taser International (TASR) and Digital Ally (DGLY) had seen strong sales in the wake of the Ferguson shooting in August that led to a surge of orders from police departments for on-officer camera systemsYY (YY) climbed 4% ahead of its third-quarter earnings release Tuesday after the market closes. The Chinese social network lets users connect via voice, text and video real time to play games and interact in the world's largest consumer market.Consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for YY to report a 62% rise in earnings per share to 76 cents on a 92% hike in revenue to $152.5 million.Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) was up 2.6%, hitting a fresh seven-year high. The homebuilder group, which has been range-bound since early spring, on Monday was trading near the top of that range.Lennar also got a boost Tuesday from the Toll Bros. (TOL) preannouncement of a 29.3% rise in Q4 revenue as the average price of homes delivered rose 6.3% year over year to $747,000. Toll Bros., which will announce full earnings on Dec. 10, was up 3.4%. Toll shares rose nearly 4%.Meanwhile, builder D.R. Horton (DHI) rose more than 2%. Horton is slated to release fiscal Q4 earnings results Tuesday before the market opens. Wall Street expects a 20% increase in EPS to 48 cents on a 32% rise in revenue to $2.38 billion.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Housing starts plunged 14.4% in August to an annualized rate of 956,000, the Census Bureau reported Thursday, well below expectations for a 1.038 million rate. Permits were slightly better, at 998,000, but still shy of expectations for 1.055 million. Both are in positive territory for the year, however: starts are up 8.0%, and permits rose 0.8%.

Much of the volatility has been driven by multifamily starts, which surged 44.9% in July, and backed off 31.7% in Aug. Single-family starts have been smoother month-to-month and are up 4.2% for the year, vs. a 19.2% gain for multi-family units.
The starts data comes a day after NAHB said its homebuilder sentiment index jumped 4 points in September to its highest level since 2005.

Also Wednesday, Lennar (LEN) reported better-than-expected earnings, revenue and orders, sending shares of several homebuilders higher, including D.R. Horton (DHI), PulteGroup (PHM), Ryland (RYL) and Toll Bros. (TOL). Lennar, D.R. Investors will get a good read on the climate for homebuilding this week when three large builders report quarterly results Thursday and March new-home sales data are released Wednesday. If analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are on target, D.R. Horton (DHI) and Ryland Group (RYL) will each post a single-digit year-over-year earnings gain, while Pulte Group (PHM) will report a…
Stocks swaggered higher at the open, wiping out all or most of the previous session's losses.
The Nasdaq gained 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%.
Volume was running higher across the board.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) and IBM (IBM), two heavy weightings in the Nasdaq and Dow respectively, announced a partnership to develop applications for business users of wireless devices. Each rose about 1.5% after the open. Apple accounts for 6.7% of the Nasdaq's weighting. IBM's weighting in the Dow is 6.9%.

On the downside, Michael Kors (KORS) eased 0.3% as it struggled in the wake of Tuesday's 7% gap-down loss in heavy volume. On Wednesday, William Blair & Co. downgraded Kors from outperform to market perform. An article in today's IBD noted that some analysts say that Kors could be losing its "luxury halo" as it offers more products at a discount.

Intel (INTC) rushed almost 7% higher on the chipmaker's strong quarterly report late Tuesday. Nineteen investment analysts today raised their price targets for Intel. Drexel Hamilton offered the highest new price target, 50.
Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs initiated coverage of Palo Alto Networks (PANW) with a buy recommendation and a 97 price target. The stock jumped 4%.

In housing-related news, the Mortgage Bankers Association's purchase applications index, which is a leading indicator for home sales and housing construction, skidded 8% from the previous week. However, the National Association of Home Builders' housing market index for July came in at 53, above views for 51 and at the high end of the range of estimates. Toll Brothers (TOL) and DR Horton (DHI) were up about 1% each.
The producer price index for June rose 0.4% vs. the consensus target of 0.3%. The PPI measures inflation at the wholesale level before it gets passed on to consumers.
Industrial production for June edged up 0.2%, missing the Street's 0.4% estimate.
