Homebuilder stocks fell broadly Tuesday morning as a key housing-market index gauging builders' sentiment showed more of them view conditions as poor than good. National Association of Home Builders chief economist David Crowe said tight credit and limited availability of lots and labor "are holding up a more robust recovery." Builder confidence in new single-family homes was up one point…

Housing starts roared back in July, topping expectations and the 1 million mark for the first time since April. The 1.093 million annual rate was the strongest since last December's multi-year high. Permits were also up sharply, to 1.052 million. Prior months were revised upward, making the housing market's stumble a little less severe. Overall starts were up more than…

Signed contracts to buy existing homes slipped in June, the National Association of Realtors said. Consensus was for a 0.3% gain, but May's 6.0% jump, a 5-year high, proved too tough to match. NAR predicts a better second half to 2014 and forecasts a 2.8% decline versus 2013 as supply shortages persist and price appreciation cools. Nationally, the index is…

A sharp drop in new-home sales last month and mixed quarterly reports from a slew of homebuilders demolished hopes the housing market was working its way out of a recent slowdown. New-home sales in June dropped 8.1% from the prior month to an annualized rate of 406,000, said the Commerce Department, missing views for 475,000. Meanwhile, May was revised down…

The U.S. housing market got more good news Thursday as a pair of reports showed a continued decline in the number of distressed properties, potentially boosting the supply of homes on the market. RealtyTrac said that 9.3 million U.S. residential properties were deeply underwater in December, or 19% of all properties with a mortgage. That was down from 10.7 million…

Homebuilders, including D.R. Horton (DHI), are expected to cement decent earnings gains Thursday as the housing market builds back up and the Commerce Department releases new-home sales numbers. Analysts expect single-family new-home sales to dip to an annualized rate of 475,000 from the six-year high of 504,000 in May. But June housing starts fell 9.3% and building permits dipped 4.2%…

June new-home sales disappointed bitterly, plunging 8.1% to an annual rate of 406,000, the Commerce Department reported Thursday. It was the biggest drop in nearly a year, even as prior months were revised down sharply. Analysts had expected a 475,000 annualized pace. It was the lowest level since March, when winter weather likely played a role in depressing activity. In…

The Mortgage Bankers Association's composite index rose 2.4% in the July 18 week following a 3.6% decline the prior week. Purchase applications were up 0.3% after falling 8.0%. Refinances rose 4% after a 0.1% fall even though average rates remained steady at 4.33%. Refinance's share of all applications rose to 54.4%, the highest since March. Adjustable-rate mortgages as a share…

The U.S. housing market got more good news Thursday as a pair of reports showed a continued decline in the number of distressed properties, potentially boosting the supply of homes on the market. RealtyTrac said that 9.3 million U.S. residential properties were deeply underwater in December, or 19% of all properties with a mortgage. That was down from 10.7 million…
Homebuilders rallied Friday as weak payroll data sent 10-year bond yields down, potentially helping to keep mortgage rates low.
Mortgage applications for home purchases have fallen since the summer as interest rates inched up in anticipation of the Fed's gradual tapering of bond buybacks, pressuring builder stocks.

Pulte Group (PHM), Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Toll Bros. (TOL), the four largest homebuilders by market cap, rose more than 2% by early afternoon in the stock market today. KB Home (KBH) jumped more than 3%.

The overall stock market fell intraday Friday, before rising ahead of the closing bell, after the December jobs report came in much weaker than expected with only 74,000 workers hired vs. the 196,000 analysts had expected. Weather may have been a factor. It was the smallest gain since January 2011.
But the disappointing jobs report has "silver linings" for housing demand in 2014, said Jed Kolko, chief economist with real estate web site Trulia.com (TRLA), in an email.
He noted that more young adults were working and job growth in "clobbered" metro areas such as Tampa, Orlando and Fort Lauderale, Fla., Las Vegas, Nev., and Phoenix has picked up.
The "prime age" for housing demand is the 25- to 34-year-old group, Kolko said, and employment in that group rose to 75.4% in December, after dipping below 75% earlier this year.
"For the economy overall, the jobs report was disappointing, but better news for housing demand going into 2014," he said.
Still, young buyers have a long road ahead since the December rate was closer to the low point in the recession than to the pre-bubble level of 78% to 80%, Kolko added.

Not all builder stocks moved up. Buyers were back at it Tuesday, particularly in the Nasdaq, but a wave of selling hit the S&P 500 in the final minutes of trading resulting in a stalling day for the benchmark index. The Nasdaq added 0.6% and closed near its session high. The S&P 500 closed with a tiny gain after falling 0.3% in the final 30 minutes…
Mortgage applications rise

Applications to buy a home rose 0.3% in the July 18 week after tumbling 7.6% in the prior week to the lowest levels since late February, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported Wednesday. Refinances rose 4.1%, up from -0.1%, even as average rates remained unchanged, with the average 30-year fixed rate at 4.33%. Overall mortgage applications rose 2.4%.

Other housing data, including Tuesday's existing-home sales report, suggest a recent weakness in housing demand is ending as rates trend lower and price gains cool. On Thursday, the Commerce Department releases new-home sales for June. Meanwhile, D.R. Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM), Meritage Homes (MTH) and M/I Homes (MHO) report earnings that day.
 Contributions to IRA accounts rose 5.7% in 2013 to an average $4,150, an all-time high, Fidelity Investments said. Fidelity's analysis spanned over 7 million individual retirement accounts.
 Canadian retail sales rose 0.7% in May, more than the 0.5% expected but less than the 1.3% rise in April. For the year, sales are up 4.0%.
 French business climate sentiment was flat in July, at 97, INSEE said. Its long-run average is 100.
Spanish growth picks up

Spain's economy grew 0.5% in Q2 vs. Q1, the fastest quarter-to-quarter advance in 6 years, the Bank of Spain said. That follows 0.4% growth in Q1. That's good news for one of the eurozone's hardest-hit economies and a stark contrast with flagging growth or even contraction in other European countries.
 Lithuania will join the eurozone, becoming its 19th member on Jan. 1, EU officials confirmed. The Lithuanian lita will be converted to euros at 3.45280 lita to one euro.
Bank of England mulling rate rise

The central bank voted unanimously to leave its benchmark rate at 0.5% this month, but minutes released Wednesday revealed internal disagreement about when to start raising rates. The U.K. economy is strengthening, but some policymakers worry about the impact of higher borrowing costs on stagnant wages.
 U.K. retail sales accelerated in July, the Confederation of British Industry said. Its distributive trade survey rose to 21 from 4 and topped expectations. Forecasts for August hit 36.

 Japan plans to cut discretionary spending by 10% next fiscal year, according to a draft budget document, Reuters reported. Those funds would be allocated to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's long-term economic plans instead.
COMING UP THURSDAY

 New-home sales for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 475,000 annualized).

Stocks opened nose-down on Thursday but quickly trimmed losses after a strong reading on regional manufacturing.
The Dow Jones industrial average narrowed to a fractional loss. The S&P 500 was down 0.1% and the Nasdaq showed a 0.2% loss. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

The stock market today opened with homebuilders stocks taking some hard hits after June housing data showed weaker-than-expected starts and permits. D.R. Horton (DHI) dropped 3%. Ryland Group (RYL) shed 2% and Toll Bros. (TOL) and Pulte Group (PHM) dumped 2% each.

Manufacturing in the Philadelphia region surged this month, according to the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Business Outlook Survey, which jumped to 23.9 for July. That was far above June's 17.8 reading, counter to expectations for a decline to 16.9. It was also the highest reading since March 2011. The index has now been positive for five months.

In stocks, SanDisk (SNDK) deleted 10% of its share value at the open. The maker of memory chips and storage components on Wednesday reported second-quarter revenue and earnings just above expectations. Margins came in below analyst expectations, however, and management's Q3 revenue forecast undercut analyst estimates.
The drop pulled shares off a new high, but the stock remained extended above an April pullback to the 10-week moving average.

On the upside, United Rentals (URI) surged 5% in heavy trade. The company delivered its Q2 report after Wednesday's close, with EPS and revenue growth comfortably topping consensus forecasts. Management lifted its full-year revenue guidance to the high end of analysts' range. The stock is extended after a breakout from a flat base in May.

China-based maker of electric vehicles Kandi Technologies (KNDI) leapt 6% in large volume. New-home sales rose 6.4% to an annualized 433,000 in April, the Commerce Department said Friday, the biggest leap since October and a welcome sign for a housing market that has been stuck in neutral. Prices eased 2.1% vs. March and 1.3% vs. a year earlier. That's a positive sign because higher valuations and mortgage rates have deterred many potential homeowners.…

Housing-related stocks such as homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) have seen strong long-term earnings and sales growth from a stabilizing market.Government data show new residential construction hit the highest rate in nearly six years in April, with multifamily housing starts soaring 39.6%.Today's Screen of the Day is Top Fundamentals — companies with three-year per-share earnings and revenue growth rates of at least 25% — and includes four leaders in the housing sector.D.R. Horton builds and sells homes in 27 states across the U.S., in addition to offering mortgage financing and title services. The company's average EPS growth rate is 204% over the last three years.Sterne Agee boosted earnings estimates on the company in May, based on its $210 million acquisition of Atlanta-based Crown Communities, the country's 28th largest homebuilder.In early June, D.R. Horton launched Express Homes, a line of houses between $120,000 and $150,000 aimed at attracting first-time buyers.D.R. Horton shares fell nearly 2% on the stock markethttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Wednesday. But the stock is forming the right side of a base that started in late February. That base is part of a larger consolidation from May 2013.United Rentals (URI) is the world's biggest equipment-rental company whose inventory includes construction gear like forklifts, earth-moving equipment and power tools. The company's three-year EPS growth rate is 110%.The Stamford, Conn.-based firm bought specialty-pump rental company National Pump and rental business GulfCo in March for a combined $780 million. Higher rental rates and increased equipment rentals have contributed to growth in recent quarters.Eagle Materials (EXP), a building-materials manufacturer and distributor, deals in materials such as cement, concrete and recycled paperboard. The company's EPS growth rate is 108% over the last three years.The Dallas-based company is a 2004 spinoff of Centex Corp., and has benefited from higher sales prices of cement and wall board and the housing market's recovery. With a 97 IBD Composite Rating, the company holds the top spot in the IBD Building-Cement/Concrete/Aggregates group.Lennar (LEN) is a Miami-based homebuilder that operates in 18 states nationwide and also offers mortgage and title services. The company's EPS growth rate is 97% over the last three years.Despite a harsh winter that prompted a decline in new-home construction in the U.S., the homebuilder's Q1 earnings topped views, thanks to new orders and higher home prices.

The major averages pulled back from their earlier highs and were mixed in early-afternoon trading.The Nasdaq remained in the lead with a 0.4% advance, while the S&P 500 was flat and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2%. Volume was tracking slightly higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE in the stock market today.Economic data were mixed. S&P Case-Shiller's housing price index rose 1.1%, May new-home sales and the Conference Board's consumer confidence index for June topped views. But April housing prices, tracked by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, and the Richmond Fed's factory index for June, missed forecasts.Homebuilders were among the session's leading groups.William Lyon Homes (WLH) surged 6% in busy trade, extending the prior session's 5% gain. On Monday, the builder said it's buying a residential building business from Polygon Northwest for $520 million in cash. The purchase allows the Newport Beach, Calif.-based company to enter the housing market in Oregon and Washington state.Among other homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and Toll Bros. (TOL) were each up 3% in above-average volume.Advance Auto Parts (AAP) advanced 2% to a new high, firming up a breakout past a 130.09 buy point in active trading. It's now nearly 3% above the entry. Morgan Stanley began covering the auto parts retailer with an overweight rating and a 150 price target. Advance Auto was also featured in Monday's New America.Akorn (AKRX) rose 5% to a record high in above-average volume. It's 23% past a 25.19 cup-with-handle entry it cleared in early May. The drugmaker, which acquired VersaPharm last month for $440 million, said Friday it sold its ECR Pharmaceuticals unit to Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) for $41 million. Akorn shares surged 6% in heavy turnover that day.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

Median home prices in April jumped 11% from a year earlier to $172,000, the highest level since December 2008, said housing tracker RealtyTrac in a report on Thursday. The median rose as short sales and foreclosure sales accounted for a lower percent of the mix, or 15.6% of all sales in the month, down from 17.2% from a year ago…

Shares of Toll Bros. (TOL) moved higher in premarket trading on the stock market after the homebuilder topped quarterly profit views, helped by higher prices. Reporting before the open, the Horsham, Pa.-based company logged EPS of 35 cents for its fiscal second quarter, which ended in April. That was up from 9 cents the prior year and well above consensus…

Horton recently announced a new brand of bargain homes as a way to lure more first-time buyers, it underscored how important these buyers are to the overall housing market — and how difficult it has been to land them. D.R. Horton's  (DHI) Express Homes brand offers properties at $120,000 to $150,000. That's well below the national median…

Although the U.S housing market has run into recent headwinds involving rising prices and a lack of inventory in many cities, new home sales came in stronger than expected in April, and most homebuilders continue to produce decent financial results.
One of those builders, Toll Bros. (TOL), is expected to continue the streak when it reports fiscal second-quarter results before the open Wednesday.

The Horsham, Pa.-based company specializes in single-family homes in luxury communities for move-up and empty-nester buyers. It ranks No. 4 in market cap in IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group and has an IBD Composite Rating of 68 and EPS Rating of 99.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Toll to deliver earnings of 26 cents a share for its fiscal Q2, which ended in April. That's up from 9 cents the prior year. Revenue is seen rising 61% to $830.9 million.
During its fiscal first quarter, Toll's EPS grew more than eight-fold to 25 cents, while sales climbed 52% to $643.7 million.

Other leading lenders have had similarly strong results of late. In March, Miami-based Lennar (LEN), the No. 1 builder by market cap, logged earnings of 35 cents a share for its fiscal first quarter, which ended in February. That was up from 26 cents the prior year and 7 cents above consensus views. Revenue gained 37% to $1.36 billion, topping estimates for $1.28 billion.
Last month, No. 2 D.R. Horton (DHI) posted fiscal Q2 EPS of 38 cents, up 19% from a year earlier and above estimates for 34 cents. Revenue rose 21% to $1.7 billion, also above views.
One of the few outliers was No. 3 PulteGroup (PHM), which fell short of its Q1 sales and profit estimates.
These mostly positive results notwithstanding, homebuilder stocks have been trending lower since early March. The Building-Residential/Commercial group ranks No. 68 among 197 industries tracked.
One challenge in many markets is that rising home prices have turned off potential buyers for both new homes and existing ones.

Sales of new single-family homes rose 6.4% to an annual rate of 433,000, the Census Bureau reported Friday. The figure was higher than expected but still 4.2% below a year ago. The median sales price of new houses sold in April was $275,800.

Although new homes came in at a monthly supply of 5.3 months in the Census report, prices are expected to keep pushing higher as demand for homes in general continues to outpace supply — especially in markets marked by high incomes and robust job growth such as California's Silicon Valley, Texas energy centers like Houston, and East Coast cities including Boston and Washington, D.C.

Despite these issues, Toll Bros. is expected to produce strong gains in coming quarters. Analysts estimate that the company will grow annual earnings 73% this fiscal year and 36% in fiscal 2015.Although the U.S housing market has run into recent headwinds involving rising prices and a lack of inventory in many cities, new home sales came in stronger than expected in April, and most homebuilders continue to produce decent financial results.One of those builders, Toll Bros. Sterne Agee raised its earnings estimates on D.R. Horton (DHI) on optimism that a recent buyout will boost the homebuilder's results, and also offered a positive assessment of the mortgage lending environment over the next year.

In a report issued Monday afternoon, Sterne Agee analyst Jay McCanless said D.R. Horton's $210 million acquisition of Atlanta-based Crown Communities, announced on Friday, "expands DHI's Southeastern market share, which should be incrementally positive."

Crown Communities, the nation's 28th largest homebuilder, has operations in Georgia, South Carolina and eastern Alabama. It closed 1,540 homes in 2013 and logged revenue of around $375 million. Its homes average 3,500 square feet and sell for an average $244,000.

"DHI believes the acquisition will allow it to establish double-digit market share within the Atlanta region," McCanless noted. "The deal will also expand DHI's presence in the Greenville and Columbia, S.C. markets, as well as add Augusta, Ga. and Spartanburg, S.C."
The Atlanta market holds particular promise, McCanless said.

He cited data from the Atlanta Association of Realtors showing that the median sale price of existing homes in the city grew 16.9% year-over-year to $208,000 in March, the highest reported median price since July. Meanwhile, existing home sales in Atlanta fell 12.6% in March.
"We believe a lack of available inventory and a decline in investor sales vs. last year are behind the negative comparisons," McCanless noted.

In a separate report released Monday afternoon, McCanless discussed a recent conference call with PulteGroup (PHM) CEO Debra Still in which Still discussed the availability of mortgage loans to U.S. consumers.
Based on that conversation, McCanless said "mortgage lending conditions are more likely to loosen than tighten over the next 12 months."
According to Still, the federal government has been asking mortgage lenders why they're not lending more.
"The answer appears to be a combination of regulatory burden and a lack of creditworthy individuals at current standards," McCanless wrote.

Since the federal government is the primary purchaser of non-jumbo mortgages for securitization purposes, McCanless said, "we believe the impetus for lower underwriting standards must come from the ultimate buyer. Based on Ms. Still's commentary, we anticipate regulators and the Government Sponsored Entities (GSEs) are exploring ways to include more buyers."
If so, that bodes well for the nation's' homebuilders, which have run up against recent head winds such as higher home prices and a lack of inventory in many markets.

IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group is down about 10% since setting a multi-year high on March 4. The group ranks No. 62 among 197 industries tracked. Leaders include Lennar (LEN) and William Lyon Homes (WLH), which both have IBD Composite Ratings of 80.Sterne Agee raised its earnings estimates on D.R. The stock market closed with a flurry of buying, as most broad indexes added more than 1%. The Nasdaq led with a 1.5% gain as biotech, generic-drug and computer hardware stocks gave strong performances.
The S&P 500 rallied 1.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9%. All indexes closed near session highs.
Small caps outperformed: The Russell 2000 was up 2% at the closing bell.

Volume was lower on the NYSE and slightly higher on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Breadth was impressive, with winning stocks leading losers by nearly 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 9-to-2 on the NYSE.
Earnings reports continued to influence the stock market today.

Visa (V) gapped down in heavy volume, closing below the 77.02 buy point the stock had broken out from two weeks ago. The credit card company missed profit estimates and confirmed it is acquiring Visa Europe.
After the close, Fitbit (FIT) shares fell moderately after the company announced results for Q3.

Operating earnings per share of 13 cents were above the consensus estimate of 10 cents, and Fitbit also raised guidance. But it also announced a follow-on offering of 7 million shares from the company, and certain stockholders are seeking to sell 14 million shares.

In its earnings announcement, Fitbit said that lock-up restrictions for Fitbit's employees and consultants will be lifted Wednesday. Some 2.3 million shares, which represent up to 10% of Fitbit common stock, options, and restricted stock held by insiders, will hit the market. Other lock-up restrictions are set to end Dec. 14.
Among other leading stocks, LGI Homes (LGIH) rallied back above its 50-day moving average in average volume. The stock is now in a secondary buy area, thanks to the support that has emerged.
On Tuesday, earnings reports are due from Tesla Motors (TSLA), Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI).
At 10 a.m. ET Tuesday, the latest reading on factory orders is released. Automakers will announce sales for the month of October.

Stocks ended lower in light volume Monday on concerns that the Federal Reserve appears poised to raise interest rates as early as next month. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 1%. Volume fell 14% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.Traders increased their bets that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates following Friday's strong jobs report. That could saddle consumers with higher borrowing costs and boost the dollar, which could slow the U.S. economy.Leisure and discretionary consumer stocks were hit hardest in the stock market todayOnline travel broker Priceline.com (PCLN) plunged nearly 10% after a weak Q4 outlook overshadowed a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report.The stock sank below a 1394.10 buy point of a cup-type base and sliced through its 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, gambling stocks fell on expectations of weakness in the Chinese gambling enclave of Macau, the world's top gaming destination. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell more than 8%. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) sank 6% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slipped 2%.On the upside, IBD 50 stock LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 2% as it continues to climb the right side of a deep, cup-type base with a 276.28 buy point.D.R. Horton (DHI), Luxoft (LXFT), Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) and Amdocs (DOX) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data scheduled for Tuesday include import and export prices for October and wholesale inventories for September.

Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

A couple of months ago Tri Pointe Homes was a smallish homebuilder with a heavy concentration in California and little fanfare on Wall Street.Today the company is poised to become one of the nation's 10 biggest builders as it prepares to move into a handful of new, high-growth markets from one coast to the other.For that, Tri Pointe (TPH) can thank its proposed buyout of Weyerhaeuser Co.'s (WY) homebuilding division in a $2.7 billion deal announced Nov. 4.The acquisition brings Tri Pointe around 27,000 lots and five brands: Pardee Homes in Southern California and Nevada; Trendmaker Homes in Texas; Maracay Homes in Arizona; Winchester Homes in the Washington, D.C., metro area; and Quadrant Homes in the Puget Sound region of Washington.The deal is expected to close by the end of the second quarter of 2014. When it does, Tri Pointe would have a market cap of around $2.5 billion, going by current stock levels. That would move it into the top 10 among U.S. homebuilders. The company's current market cap is about $600 million.Good Supply Of LandOfficials involved in the deal said the Weyerhaeuser unit, known as Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Co., or Wreco, will give Tri Pointe nine years' worth of land and lot supply.According to industry reports, that compares favorably with the roughly 7.4 years of average supply for leading U.S. homebuilders like Pulte Group (PHM), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN).Part of Tri Pointe's new supply will be in and around large urban markets such as Las Vegas, Houston, Phoenix and Seattle.A majority of the lots — more than 16,000 — are in California, where available land in top markets is shrinking.On a conference call with analysts, Tri Pointe CEO Doug Bauer said the combined company will give Tri Pointe "a stronger and deeper California market position, a relatively high average-selling-price product line (and) land positions and brand recognition in the nation's most attractive markets."Wall Street reacted favorably to the news. Tri Pointe's stock, which touched a low of 13.43 on Oct. 9, has since rallied about 35% and currently trades near 18. The stock went public in late January at an IPO price of $17.Even before the deal was announced, Tri Pointe was seeing sales increase sharply. For the past five quarters, revenue has risen by at least triple-digit percentages from a year ago. The Wreco assets should kick growth into an even higher gear, analysts say."The acquisition of about 27,000 lots in several of the nation's best housing markets will permit Tri Pointe Homes to continue its robust growth pace," Brendan Lynch, analyst at Sidoti & Co., noted in a report."In addition to bolstering inventory, we think Wreco's land .. . will contribute to gross margin expansion to 23.5% in 2014 and 24% in 2015, vs. our call for 22% in 2013," Lynch added.Under the terms, Weyerhaeuser shareholders will get 130 million shares, or 80.5% of the combined company. Tri Pointe will get 19.5%.However, Tri Pointe's management will run the firm. Bauer will remain as CEO and Barry Sternlicht will continue as chairman. Sternlicht's Starwood Capital Group owns a large stake in Tri Pointe.The Tri Pointe-Weyerhaeuser deal is part of a recent trend that has seen homebuilders use acquisitions to gain quick entry into new markets.In July, Ryland Group (RYL) made its fourth acquisition in a year when it bought the operations and assets of Cornell Homes, a developer in Philadelphia, western New Jersey and Delaware.In September, Meritage Homes (MTH) announced its acquisition of Phillips Builders, a Nashville-based builder.Weyerhaeuser, a timberland owner that makes wood, container board and paper products, began exploring the idea of selling its homebuilding unit in June.In a statement at the time, Weyerhaeuser CEO Dan Fulton said that "given the improving fundamentals of the housing market, we believe now is a prudent time to explore strategic alternatives for this business."The Tri Pointe-Weyerhaeuser deal was structured as a tax-free Reverse Morris Trust, which allowed Tri Pointe to buy a larger firm while Weyerhaeuser shareholders would own the majority of shares.When the deal closes, Tri Pointe will have a chance to expand well beyond its current market, which mainly focuses on houses in California and Colorado that sell for $300,000 to $1.5 million."We have accelerated our long-term plan to be a leading regional homebuilder in some of the nation's fastest-growing markets," Bauer said on the conference call. "The combination of Wreco's local market knowledge and Tri Pointe's strong and established history of success should result in a powerful and focused homebuilding company."Prices And Revenue GrowingHe made those comments following Tri Pointe's third-quarter earnings release. The company posted earnings of 15 cents a share, topping estimates for 9 cents. Revenue rose more than 480% year over year to $58.5 million, above views for $44.9 million.The average selling price of homes delivered climbed 57% to $624,000 as Tri Pointe benefited from the opening of three communities in Southern California.New home orders nearly doubled to 135 from 74 a year earlier, while homebuilding gross margins improved to 23% from 11.7% the prior year.Tri Pointe said it will have nine active communities by the end of 2013. It expects to open 20 to 24 new communities in 2014, excluding the Wreco assets."We project that Tri Pointe will sell all of the remaining homes in a few of the nine communities that are open, resulting in an active community count of 27 at year-end 2014," analyst Lynch noted.Analysts expect Tri Pointe to post full-year EPS of 47 cents in 2013 and $1.09 in 2014.

After capping the year with double-digit gains in home prices and sales, the housing market is expected to stay on the recovery path in 2014. An economic growth spurt and brighter jobs picture will likely drive strong building demand. Here's how real estate experts size up the outlook for the year ahead: Home prices are expected to keep rising, but…

New to the stock market in November, LGI Homes (LGIH) is being regarded by investors and analysts as a housing market play with a unique twist. The homebuilder, based in the Woodlands, north of Houston, takes a sales-oriented approach to acquiring first-time homebuyers, contacting renters and other prospects with information on how they can afford a home. This helps it stand…
Homebuilders rallied Wednesday on strong Lennar (LEN) earnings, a spike in housing starts, and a positive market reaction to the Federal Reserve's decision to begin tapering bond purchases.

Housing starts rose 22.7% last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.09 million units, the highest since February 2008, the Commerce Department said. That was well above expectations and the best monthly percentage gain in nearly 24 years.

Meanwhile, Miami-based Lennar, the No. 2 U.S. homebuilder by market cap, said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 30% to 73 cents a share, easily topping views for 62 cents. Sales in the quarter ended in November gained 42% to $1.92 billion, above estimates for $1.88 billion. It was Lennar's eighth straight quarter of double-digit or better sales and EPS growth.
Lennar's home deliveries climbed 27% to 5,650 homes. New orders were up 13% to 4,498 homes, while the average sales price increased 18%.

"While the political and interest-rate environment and our previously initiated price increases tempered new sales orders in the fourth quarter, we were still pleased with our overall performance," Lennar CEO Stuart Miller said in a statement.
The Fed said it would finally begin tapering bond purchases starting in January. It will buy $75 billion in mortgage and Treasury securities each month, down from the current $85 billion.
Stocks, which have been fueled by the Fed's easy-money policies, rallied strongly on the news that policymakers would scale back stimulus.
Builders were among the big winners. Lennar shares rose 6% to a five-month closing high. Pulte Group (PHM), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Toll Bros. (TOL) also advanced.

Treasury yields, which had moved up in anticipation of the decision, were little changed. Still, rising market rates could chill demand further. The Mortgage Bankers Association said applications for home mortgages fell 5.5% last week to the lowest point in more than a dozen years. Applications for loans to buy a home tumbled 6.1% to a 2013 low.
The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose 1 basis point to 4.62%, the sixth straight weekly gain.

LGI Homes (LGIH), a Houston-area builder that had its initial public offering in November, reported earnings late Tuesday. Home sales revenue increased 58% to $68 million, while the average home sales price climbed 13% to $151,779.
LGI shares initially matched a record high, then reversed, but rallied to close less than 1% higher.
KB Home (KBH), which reports earnings Thursday, rose 3%.

Last week, Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV) delivered better-than-expected fiscal Q4 quarterly sales and earnings and gave an upbeat assessment of the U.S. housing market, saying that "household formations — the primary driver of housing demand — will ultimately lead to increased demand for new homes."

Also last week, Toll Bros. reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 54 cents a share, topping views for 43 cents. The luxury builder reported sales of $1.04 billion, also above estimates, as it benefited from volume growth and higher prices.

Housing starts rose 1.8% in October but fell 1.1% in September, Commerce said. Starts data for those two months were delayed by the 16-day shutdown of the federal government in October. Builders may have delayed breaking ground on homes amid the shutdown, then got to work in November.

Building permits, a sign of future demand, declined 3.1% in November to an annual rate of 1.01 million. However, permits for single-family homes increased 2.1% to a rate of 634,000, the highest since April 2008.Homebuilders rallied Wednesday on strong Lennar (LEN) earnings, a spike in housing starts, and a positive market reaction to the Federal Reserve's decision to begin tapering bond purchases.Housing starts rose 22.7% last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.09 million units, the highest since February 2008, the Commerce Department said. Hurricane Sandy property damage could reach $20 billion, much of it uninsured. But early estimates suggest REITs won't be hard hit, because of what they own and where — often big buildings in city centers.

The 1,000-mile-wide superstorm that barreled up the Eastern Seaboard this week demolished many homes near the Jersey Shore and other coastal areas around New York and nearby states. Only about half of that expected $20 billion in property damage is insured, says IHS Global Insight.
About 9,000 properties owned by real estate investment trusts were in the path of Sandy, according to real estate investment trust market tracker SNL Real Estate.
Jason Lail, real estate manager there, told IBD that although there's just a trickle of data available so far, "it looks like Sandy's impact was relatively tame" for REITS.

The hurricane — really termed an extratropical storm once north of the tropics — devastated housing in some areas, and it wasn't only the wind and water. Sandy sparked fires that leveled more than 100 homes in Breezy Point, Queens, and burned three mansions in Old Greenwich, Conn.
Meanwhile, a 13-foot storm surge swept a wall of water through Lower Manhattan, flooding the World Trade Center construction site and many underground structures in the Financial District.

Yet SL Green (SLG), New York City's biggest office landlord with 74 properties in the storm's path, is reporting minimal damage, Lail said. One property had flooding and four others were without power.
"And other early reports that have come in say the same thing — minimal damage. For some others there's been no word yet," Lail said. "Folks are still wading through the mess to get to properties."
REITs In Storm's Path

Among other REITs, Mack-Cali Realty (CLI) has 192 properties in the disaster area. Several REITs have their entire portfolios in the storm damage region, including Washington Real Estate Investment Trust (WRE) with 71 properties. Mack-Cali owns office and multifamily properties, while Washington owns office, medical office, retail and multifamily properties, as well as land for development.

SL Green and Mack-Cali Realty shares closed up more than 1% Thursday in the stock market. Smaller Washington Real Estate slid slightly. Shares of all three had slumped, with the S&P 500 index, during the latter half of October.

Although damage to New York commercial real estate owned by REITs may have been less than expected, the storm is expected to rank among the worst in its massive damage to homes and other structures, more than some anticipated.
Tropical cyclones, including hurricanes, caused $5.5 billion in insured losses nationwide last year, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Hurricane Irene accounted for most of that.

"Three of the costliest hurricanes to hit the U.S., based on insured property losses, caused damage in New York: Hurricane Ivan and Hurricane Frances, both in 2004, and Hurricane Irene in 2011," the III noted in a recent report.
Homebuilders of various sizes and home improvement suppliers, which were already growing at a rapid clip, stand to get business as the massive rebuilding and patching-up process begins.

Among the largest companies in the Building-Residential/Commercial group, ranked No. 4 on the list of 197 industry groups IBD tracks, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose more than 4% Thursday. Lennar (LEN) and PulteGroup (PHM) gained more than 2%, as Toll Bros. (TOL) and Standard Pacific (SPF) advanced almost 1%.

Among building suppliers, retail giant Home Depot (HD) and rival Lowes (LOW) were both up more than 1%.Hurricane Sandy property damage could reach $20 billion, much of it uninsured. Horton (DHI) rose more than 4% Thursday. Lennar (LEN) and PulteGroup (PHM) gained more than 2%, as Toll Bros. (TOL) and Standard Pacific (SPF) advanced almost 1%.Among building suppliers, retail giant Home Depot (HD) and rival Lowes (LOW) were both up more than 1%.
Lending standards for jumbo loans are loosening for the first time in four or five years, says the president of luxury builder Toll Bros.' (TOL) in-house mortgage division.

Don Salmon, president of Toll's TBI Mortgage Co., said in a post-earnings conference call Tuesday that lenders are lowering loan-to-value standards to a 10% down payment vs. 20% previously — policy that had been "dormant for four or five years."
"We are seeing (lenders) loosening some of their credit score boxes as well," he said. "So overall we're seeing a loosening, I think, in the market, especially in the jumbo market."

Analyst James McCanless of Sterne Agee noted that his commentary is an "encouraging" sign for the jumbo mortgage market. As the top luxury homebuilder in the country, Toll is looked at as a barometer of sorts for the high-end housing market. It is the fourth largest name in IBD's Building-Residential industry group, after Pulte Group (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI).

As the private mortgage market expands, the Department of Housing and Urban Development is lowering loan limits on FHA mortgages from $729,750 to $625,500, meaning that impacted homebuyers, mostly in expensive housing markets, would need to find private jumbo loans.

Interest rates on 30-year jumbo loans — those greater than $417,000 — increased to 4.59% for the week ending Dec. 6 from 4.49% the week before, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported Wednesday. It was the highest rate since September.
But the jumbo rate is actually lower than the rate for 30-year mortgages with loan balances of $417,000 or less. Those increased to 4.61% from 4.51%, the MBA said.
Despite the uptick in interest rates, mortgage applications increased 1% from one week earlier, including an adjustment for the Thanksgiving holiday.
Though Toll's sales jumped 65% in its fiscal fourth quarter on sharply higher selling prices, management noted a leveling of demand in the quarter.
And in the conference call, company officials noted that sales since Nov. 1 are 10% slower than a year ago.
Toll's shares were down more than 1.5% midday Wednesday. Builder Hovnanian (HOV) reports earnings Thursday.

D.R. Horton (DHI) reported a surge in quarterly revenue on high orders and strong pricing, and earnings per share were on target. The report was the first of four by homebuilders this week, as three newly public companies also announce quarterly results: WCI Communities (WCIC), Taylor Morrison Home (TMHC) and Tri Pointe Homes (TPH). D.R. Horton, the nation's largest homebuilder,…

Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report. Dow futures traded down 56 points and were falling. S&P 500 futures slipped 7.7 points.
Nasdaq futures, which had pared losses over the past hour, reversed and fell 11 points below fair market value.
The stock market today faces a busy session. The Federal Open Market Committee swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, with a policy announcement due out Wednesday afternoon.
A great many investors will be tuned to the aftermarket session, when Apple (AAPL) is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results.

Economic news opened with durable goods orders, which slipped 1.2% in September, according to the Commerce Department. That was a bit worse than projections for a 1% decline. The department also revised August's decline down to 3% from 2.3%. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.4%, down from August's flat performance and deeper than the projected 0.1% slip.

Case-Shiller reports its 20-City Composite Home Price Index for August at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit releases its preliminary purchasing managers index estimate for U.S. services at 9:45 a.m. The Conference Board plans to report its October Consumer Confidence index at 10 a.m.
Earnings action was thick and heavy rolling toward Tuesday's open.

Beleaguered German chip equipment maker Aixtron (AIXG) spiked 11%. U.K.-based big oil play BP (BP) added almost 2%. Big pharma names Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) rolled up 2% gains after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.

On the downside, frac sand quarrier Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP) imploded 26% after missing earnings forecasts and suspending its cash distribution. Rent-A-Center (RCII) posted a 20% premarket meltdown — it missed Q3 revenue expectations and lowered its Q4 and full-year earnings guidance. Ford (F) slipped 3%. United Parcel Service (UPS) dimmed 3%.

Alibaba (BABA) rumbled up 10% before the bell, launching a premarket rally among many China-based stocks. The China-based diversified Internet play reported a 27% EPS gain and a 32% rise in revenue in its fiscal Q2 — both easily topped consensus forecasts. Mobile revenue rose 183%. Cloud computing and Internet infrastructure revenues rose 128%.

The company also announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice that it concluded its inquiry and no enforcement action would be recommended. Alibaba shares ended Monday about 6% below their 200-day moving average. The stock has climbed 33% from a late-September low, leaving it still 36% below its Nov. 2014 high and 12% above its Sept. 2014 IPO price.
Yahoo (YHOO) swept ahead 6% early Tuesday as investors accounted for the increased value of Yahoo's 15% stake in Alibaba. Yahoo remains deep in an 11-month consolidation.
Other China-based Internet plays caught some of Alibaba's premarket heat. JD.com (JD) and 500.com (WBAI) popped 5% each. Jumei International (JMEI) and Vipshop (VIPS) jumped up 3% apiece.

Chip developer Marvell Technology (MRVL) tanked 18% after announcing late Monday that PricewaterhouseCoopers had resigned as the company's accounting firm. Marvell in September announced an internal investigation into whether some revenue was recognized earlier than it should have been. Marvell shares have been in a steep correction since February.

Cummins (CMI) dived 9% after missing expectations on both its earnings and revenue lines in Q3. Management lowered its full-year revenue outlook to flat to down 2% vs. prior guidance for a 2% to 4% gain. The Columbus, Ind.-based diesel engine maker also announced it would lay off up to 2,000 workers. Shares have been in a deepening decline since June 2014.
Among leaders, IBD 50 stocks were relatively quiet, with more than 80% of the group unmoved in premarket trade.

Among gainers, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) rose 2% after toppling 13% in heavy trade on Monday. No stock posted a decline of more than 0.3%.Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report. Mike Imgarten witnessed a frenzy of demand and dearth of inventory during a two-month house hunt in Sacramento, Calif. Fearing he would pay too much after a surge in prices, he took a break in June. Sales in Sacramento now are off more than 25% from a year ago and, while inventory remains tight, the supply of homes on the…
Stocks added to early gains in quiet trade, as the market moved toward its early 1 p.m. ET close.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.6%, with the Dow Jones industrial average hauling a 0.4% gain and the S&P 500 up 0.3%.
Some three in every five S&P 500 stocks advanced in the stock market today, with volume hovering well below levels at the same time Wednesday.
Homebuilders were giving up some gains from a strong week. D.R. Horton  (DHI) and KB Homes  (KBH) fell 2% each.

Agricultural commodities leader Archer Daniels Midland  (ADM) dumped 3% in modest trade after Australia's treasurer blocked the company's acquisition of Grain Corp., the largest grain handler on Australia's east coast. Archer Daniels shares have been consolidating just below a Nov. 5 high.

Drugmakers posted some of the morning's best moves. Vertex Pharmaceuticals  (VRTX) popped 3% in weak trade, moving to test resistance at its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages. The stock has been correcting since July.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals  (ALXN) tacked 2% higher in weak trade. It is finishing the fifth week of a flat base with a 126.49 buy point.

Top homebuilders like D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar Corp. (LEN) and PulteGroup (PHM) were rallying Tuesday as housing permits reached a five-year high on a rise in demand for apartments. The Commerce Department said October permits to build new homes jumped 6.2% from the prior month to an annualized rate of 1.03 million, the most since June 2008. D.R. Horton shares…

Homebuilder stocks including top builder D.R. Horton (DHI), along with Pulte Group (PHM) and Lennar (LEN), mostly ignored a consumer confidence report out Monday that was weaker than expected. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo builder market index was 54 in November, below the 55 reading analysts were looking for. The 54 figure matched a downwardly revised figure for…

Tri Pointe Homes (TPH) reported earnings and revenue that beat analysts' third-quarter estimates, pushing the high-end homebuilder's shares up to the highest point since late May in more than 10 times usual trading volume.
The report came days after it announced a $2.7 billion agreement to buy Weyerhaeuser's (WY) homebuilding unit. That pairing is expected to make Tri Pointe one of the nation's 10 largest homebuilders.
Irvine, Calif.-based Tri Pointe swung to a profit of 15 cents per share, beating consensus for 9 cents a share, from a year-ago loss of 10 cents.

Revenue more than quintupled to $56.8 million, exceeding forecasts for $44.9 million. The average selling price of homes delivered surged 57% to $624,000, helped by the opening of three new communities in Southern California.
New home orders nearly doubled to 135 from 74 a year ago, and homebuilding gross margins widened to 23% from 11.7%.
Tri Pointe raised full-year EPS guidance, excluding the Weyerhaeuser acquisition, to 46-48 cents from 40-42 cents, ahead of projections for 41 cents.

Shares were up 10% in Wednesday morning trading on the stock market today. The company began trading on Feb. 1 at $17 a share. After the housing market cooled during the summer on rising interest rates, the stock has recovered and is trading about 6% above the IPO price.
On Tuesday, D.R. Horton (DHI), the nation's largest builder, recorded a 39% hike in revenue and 33% advance in EPS on strong pricing and orders.
Recent IPO WCI Communities (WCIC) booked mixed results early Tuesday. Shares were up 5% Wednesday.

Fellow new issue Taylor Morrison's (TMHC) Q3 earnings and revenue, released late Wednesday, topped analyst projections. But after Sterne Agee and Susquehanna cut their ratings on Taylor Morrison to neutral, citing lower-than-expected new home orders, shares fell 1% Wednesday.

FORT WORTH, Texas — D.R. Horton lost money in its fiscal first quarter, reversing a year-ago profit, as the housing market kept struggling.

The builder closed on fewer homes — 3,637 vs. 5,529 a year earlier — and revenue fell almost a third. D.R. Horton (DHI) said Thursday it lost $20.4 million, or 6 cents per share, in the December quarter. That's vs. a profit of $192 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ago when the firm got a one-time tax benefit of $149.2 million.
Revenue fell 31% to $767 million from $1.11 billion. Analysts expected a 3-cents-a-share loss on revenue of $777.2 million, according to FactSet.

Chairman Donald Horton said despite more affordable housing and low rates, the market is still plagued by foreclosures, a glut of homes for sale and tight mortgage-lending.FORT WORTH, Texas — D.R. Affordability is declining nationwide as home prices rise faster than median incomes and mortgage rates, according to a study released Thursday by Trulia.
For example, a year ago more than half of homes for sale in Ventura County, Calif., and Boston were affordable compared with 32% and 41%, respectively, this October.
The real estate research website looked at middle-class home affordability by combing through the 100 top metro areas based on what consumers can afford to buy in their area.
It determined affordability based on whether the total monthly payment for a home was less than 31% of the metro area's median household income.

Forget San Francisco, L.A., New York and San Diego. If you are middle class and looking to buy a home in one of those markets, you'll have a tough time. Only a small percent of homes for sale are affordable.
The most affordable homes for middle-class buyers are in the Midwest and South, according to the study. Ohio markets Akron, Dayton and Toledo are at the top of Trulia's most-affordable list.

"The most affordable places have slow job growth but it is fairly easy to build new homes if there were demand," Trulia's chief economist Jed Kolko said in an interview. "The least affordable metros typically have strong demand but limited supply."

Take San Francisco, where new supply is limited by geography and regulations. It's the most expensive market, with only 14% of homes for sale within grasp of the city's middle class, according to Trulia.

Other land-constricted coastal metro markets in California are also high on the list of "least affordable" for the middle class, including Orange County and L.A., where 23% to 24% of homes for sale are affordable for middle-classes buyers. In New York, it's 25%.

Drilling down to submarkets, Manhattan "stands alone" for its lack of affordability, Trulia said. Only 2.5% of homes for sale in the Big Apple are affordable for the middle class and those homes are typically just 500 square feet.

On the other hand, if you're living in rust-belt markets such as Akron, Dayton and Toledo, 86% to 88% of homes for sale are affordable if you're in the middle class. And they are a lot bigger, with the average size more than 1,300 square feet.
Even though incomes in the Midwest and South are lower than on the coasts, housing costs are lower even relative to income, Trulia says.

San Franciscans can afford more expensive homes than people in Akron: The median household income is 60% higher in San Francisco than in Akron, Trulia says. But the median price per square foot in San Francisco is close to seven times higher than in Akron.

The fastest-growing markets are in the Sun Belt and many are still relatively affordable, Kolko says, citing Las Vegas, Atlanta and parts of Florida. This is no surprise to homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM) and KB Home (KBH), which build lots of homes in Sun Belt markets.
The most affordable market in Florida for the middle class is Palm Bay/Melbourne/Titusville, where 78% of homes for sale are within middle-class grasp.
In Texas, Fort Worth is the most affordable, at 66%. In fast-growing tech hub Austin, where demand for housing is strong, the figure falls to 50%.

"It's about demand and supply," Kolko said. "Many of the most affordable places have seen longer term economic challenges, slower job growth or even job losses, which reduces demand for homes."Affordability is declining nationwide as home prices rise faster than median incomes and mortgage rates, according to a study released Thursday by Trulia.For example, a year ago more than half of homes for sale in Ventura County, Calif., and Boston were affordable compared with 32% and 41%, respectively, this October.The real estate research website looked at middle-class home affordability by combing through the 100 top metro areas based on what consumers can afford to buy in their area.It determined affordability based on whether the total monthly payment for a home was less than 31% of the metro area's median household income.Forget San Francisco, L.A., New York and San Diego. Lennar Corporation’s (LEN  -  Free Report) shares have been rallying since the second-quarter fiscal 2018 release on Jun 26, 2018. In fact, the nation’s largest homebuilder has outperformed the homebuilding industry so far this year. Although Lennar deteriorated 17% year to date, it fared better than the broader industry’s 19.7% decline.Recently, Lennar posted stellar second-quarter results, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate on both counts. Notably, second-quarter fiscal 2018 was the first full quarter with CalAtlantic. Its top and bottom lines grew considerably, primarily on higher orders, along with improved gross margins and SG&A expenses. Revenues grew 67% as the Homebuilding (up 75.5%), Financial Services and Multifamily segments performed significantly well. Lennar witnessed robust market improvement, aided by 57% increase in deliveries and 62% rise in new home orders (up 79% in dollars).U.S. homebuilding was quite a rage in 2017, giving investors ample scope to rake in handsome gains. The industry is equally attractive this year, courtesy of solid economic growth and job market. Consistent job growth, growing interest from first-time homebuyers as well as high homebuilders’ confidence are the main factors driving the momentum.Lennar is one such company that continues to display strength in several areas. Hence, adding the stock to your portfolio should not be a disappointment. Earnings estimates for Lennar have exhibited an uptrend, reflecting optimism in the stock’s prospects. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the company’s 2018 and 2019 earnings has also been revised upward by 12.2% and 2.5%, respectively, over the past seven days. Let’s delve deeper into the other factors that make this Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) stock a profitable pick. You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here. What Makes Lennar a Solid Pick?Solid Growth Prospects: Presently, the problem of adequate supply of land is taking its worst shape, as demand continues to scale up in the homebuilding industry. Given significant pent-up housing demand, Lennar has secured a decent backlog. In the quarter under review, backlog grew 92% from the year-ago quarter to 19,622 homes. Potential housing revenues from backlog increased 114% year over year to $8.6 billion.Meanwhile, rising land and labor costs are threatening margins of major homebuilders. In this respect, the company has managed to control costs prudently, as is evident from gross margin expansion. The company’s home sales gross margin expanded 10 basis points in the fiscal second quarter.Lennar has solid growth prospects, as is evident from the Zacks Consensus Estimate for current-year earnings of $5.24 per share, which is expected to grow 37.5% year over year. Meanwhile, the company’s sales are expected to increase by a stellar 64.9% in fiscal 2018. Overall, Lennar constitutes a great pick in terms of growth investment, supported by a Growth Score of B.Leading Homebuilder: Lennar is considered as one of the leading homebuilders in the United States. The company offers a diversified line of homes for first-time, move-up and active adult homebuyers.The acquisition of CalAtlantic Group Inc. in February 2018 made Lennar one of the country’s top three homebuilders in 24 of the top 30 U.S. markets. Lennar remains confident that the company will exceed its prior $100 million synergy-savings expectations for 2018 and is on track to meet $365 million synergies for 2019 as well. The latest earnings result also speaks of the synergies that the company is experiencing.Valuation Looks Rational: Because of homebuilders’ asset-driven nature, it makes sense to value them based on the price-to-book (P/B) ratio. The company currently has a trailing 12-month P/B ratio of 1.3. This is lower compared with the current P/B for the industry and S&P 500 that are pegged at 1.4 and 3.9, respectively. Its lower-than-market positioning indicates that there is room for an upside in the quarters ahead, substantiating its Value Score of B.Solid VGM Score: The company has an impressive VGM Score of B. Our VGM Score identifies stocks that have the most attractive value, growth and momentum characteristics. In fact, our research shows that stocks with VGM Scores of A or B when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 or 2 make solid investment choices.Superior ROE: Lennar’s return on equity (ROE) supports its growth potential. Strong housing demand and lack of competition in the luxury new home market are favoring Toll Brothers Inc (TOL  -  Free Report). Overall fundamentals of the housing market were strong in 2017 and are expected to improve further in the rest of 2018. Steady job and wage growth, recovering economy, moderate home price gains, rising rentals, rapidly increasing household formation and a limited supply of inventory indicate consistent strong demand through 2018.Again, less competition in the luxury new home market is beneficial for Toll Brothers. The company mostly caters to luxury move up buyers, who own a residence and are planning to shift to larger homes. These homebuyers are less sensitive to price changes. Thus, the company enjoys an edge over other homebuilding companies, resulting in increased home deliveries, earnings and revenue backlog growth.In fiscal 2017, total revenues of $5.82 billion rose 12% and deliveries of 7,151 units increased 17% from the prior-year period. The company delivered double-digit growth in earnings, revenues, contracts and backlog in fiscal 2017. The trend continued in the first six months of fiscal 2018, with the company registering double-digit growth in revenues (up 21%), contracts (up 25% in dollars) and backlog (up 27% in value). This reflects the health of the luxury new home market.Moreover, considering the pent-up housing demand, the company secured some of the most sought-after urban locations in the country, where land is scarce and approvals are not easy to obtain. The company’s solid land position places it well to cater to growing demand in these regions and provide it a competitive edge over peers who are facing land-availability constraints.ConstraintsRising building materials and labor costs are growing concerns for the company’s margin. Land prices are inflating due to limited availability. This can dent homebuilders’ margins in the forthcoming quarters. Moreover, the recently imposed tariff on imported steel and aluminum raises concern. An increase in import tariff will escalate raw material cost for home builders, who are already grappling with higher cost, thanks to the recent imposition of lumber tariff.Again, a shortage of buildable lots and skilled labor is exerting pressure on the margins of Toll Brothers and other homebuilders like PulteGroup (PHM  -  Free Report), KB Home (KBH  -  Free Report) and D.R. Horton Inc. (DHI  -  Free Report). In fact, the company’s adjusted gross margin declined 80 basis points in fiscal 2017 and 180 basis points in the last quarter.Notably, shares of the company have lost 5.6% in the past year compared with the industry’s 4.8% rally.Bottom LineUnhindered by the persistent issues, analysts are optimistic about Toll Brothers. Earnings estimates for this Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) company have moved up 3 cents for 2018 and 11 cents for 2019 over the past 60 days. This indicates analysts’ optimism surrounding the company’s future earnings potential.You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1(Strong Buy) Rank stocks here.The Hottest Tech Mega-Trend of AllLast year, it generated $8 billion in global revenues. By 2020, it's predicted to blast through the roof to $47 billion. Famed investor Mark Cuban says it will produce "the world's first trillionaires," but that should still leave plenty of money for regular investors who make the right trades early.See Zacks' 3 Best Stocks to Play This Trend >>

The confidence level among the nation's homebuilders slipped in June to the lowest level this year and below its six-month average of 70 as tariffs on lumber and other imported materials are coming in the way of buyers’ affordability, according to the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index.Shares of homebuilders like KB Home (KBH  -  Free Report), D.R. Horton (DHI  -  Free Report), Toll Brothers (TOL  -  Free Report) and Lennar (LEN  -  Free Report) fell 1.6%, 2.1%, 2.4% and 1.6%, respectively, on Monday. Apart from builders’ perception, looming trade war concerns after China's retaliation to U.S. tariffs pulled Wall Street down modestly yesterday.Nonetheless, homebuilders remain confident about the upcoming period, given the robust consumer demand.Key TakeawaysHomebuilder sentiment fell two points in June to 68 and all three indices — present sales, future sales and buyer traffic — declined one point. In the words of NAHB Chairman Randy Noel, a custom homebuilder from LaPlace, LA, "builders are increasingly concerned that tariffs placed on Canadian lumber and other imported products are hurting housing affordability. Record-high lumber prices have added nearly $9,000 to the price of a new single-family home since January 2017."Notably, all three Housing Market Index components fell one point in June. Current sales conditions decreased to 75. Buyer traffic decreased to 50 and sales prediction over the next six months slipped to 76.Meanwhile, challenges like inventory shortage are still prevailing in the U.S. real estate market and creating upward pressure on prices in several parts of the country, thereby affecting affordability. Additionally, mortgage rates are surging in proportion to U.S. government bond yields, in anticipation of higher rates of inflation and further monetary tightening by the Fed. Rising mortgage rates may dilute demand for new homes.Construction Prices Are SoaringApart from tariffs on lumber, the U.S. Government’s recent move of imposing tariff on imported steel and aluminum has also stirred concerns among investors about the construction sector. According to an Associated Builders and Contractors (“ABC”) analysis of information provided by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, May construction material prices increased 2.2% month over month, representing the largest monthly increase in 10 years (since May 2008). On a year-over-year basis, the price of construction materials increased 8.8%.ABC Chief Economist Anirban Basu is concerned about rapidly rising construction materials prices and stated that current solid economic expansion may eventually disappear as inflationary pressures become increasingly apparent. He added that real estate and construction cycles are particularly vulnerable to increases in borrowing costs.Myriad problems have been decelerating the homebuilding industry of late, as evident from the 17.1% year-to-date decline against a 4.1% rise of the S&P 500 Composite. Even big names like Lennar, D.R. Horton, PulteGroup (PHM  -  Free Report), KB Home and NVR Inc. (NVR  -  Free Report) have plunged 17.9%, 17.9%, 10.9%, 19.6% and 11.5%, respectively, so far this year.Robust Demand Raises HopeDespite June’s drop, NAHB chief economist Robert Dietz remains optimistic about the industry given solid housing demand (mainly for single-family construction), improved economic growth and continued job creation.Regionally, on a three-month moving average, builder sentiment in the Northeast rose 2 points to 57, while the West and Midwest remained unchanged at 76 and 65, respectively. Sentiment in the South fell 1 point to 71.It is to be noted that any reading above 50 indicates that more builders expect sales conditions as good rather than poor. The index has remained above 60 since September 2016. Growth is expected to accelerate in the coming period as the industry starts to feel the impact of bigger after-tax paychecks along with a strong job market.Looking for Stocks with Skyrocketing Upside?Zacks has just released a Special Report on the booming investment opportunities of legal marijuana.Ignited by new referendums and legislation, this industry is expected to blast from an already robust $6.7 billion to $20.2 billion in 2021. Early investors stand to make a killing, but you have to be ready to act and know just where to look.   See the pot trades we're targeting>>

D.R. Horton Inc.’s (DHI  -  Free Report) shares have returned 26.6% in the past year, outperforming the industry’s 8.9% growth. Earnings estimates for the current and next year moved north in the past 60 days by 3.9% and 2.3%, respectively. This signifies that analysts are optimistic of the company’s future earnings growth, despite much apprehension about the impact of a rising interest rate scenario.In the last reported quarter, D.R. Horton delivered yet another solid performance. Earnings and revenues surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate, courtesy of a solid housing market scenario. Homebuilding revenues increased 16% year over year on a 15% rise in home closings in the quarter. New orders rose 13% in units as well as value, increasing across all the operating regions.Gross and pre-tax margins improved 100 basis points (bps) and 80 bps, respectively, in the quarter. The company reported earnings of 91 cents per share, higher than the year-ago profit level of 60 cents. Meanwhile, the company’s raised guidance on revenues, pre-tax margin and cash flow from operations for the year is equally encouraging. Growth DriversWith accretive acquisitions, robust backlog and cost-saving initiatives, D.R. Horton is expected to perform well in fiscal 2018. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings for the current fiscal stands at $3.71 per share, which is expected to grow 35.4% year over year on 14.7% revenue growth.Acquisitions have been an important growth driver for the company. The $558-million buyout of 75% shares of Forestar Group will help D.R. Horton expand its operations in Texas, which is currently witnessing positive housing momentum. It is also expected to contribute around $1 billion in annual revenues over the next five years.This homebuilder’s quarter-end sales order backlog (under contract) increased 8.4% to 15,841 homes. Backlog value increased 9% to $4.8 billion. Meanwhile, the company has plans to boost investments for replenishing its land and lot supply in 2018 to support revenue growth. The company expects its homebuilding operations to invest approximately $4 billion in lots, land and development in fiscal 2018. This will surely give a major boost to its top line.Separately, management has been making consistent efforts to reduce both construction and selling, as well as general and administrative (SG&A) expenses. It controls construction costs by designing homes efficiently, and also obtaining construction materials and labor at competitive prices. In the first six months of fiscal 2018, SG&A expenses improved 30 bps year over year to 9.1% and are expected to be around 8.7% for fiscal 2018.Proficient cost management is expected to give a boost to the company’s margins. For fiscal 2018, D.R. Horton expects consolidated pre-tax margin to improve 70-90 bps to 12.1-12.3%.The company believes that a consistent sales pace through inventory turnover is the best way to maximize profits and returns. In the trailing 12 months (as of Mar 31, 2018), D. R. Horton’s homebuilding return on inventory was 17.6%, depicting an improvement of 160 bps from 16% a year ago.HeadwindsRising material and labor costs, as well as competitive pricing pressure are major causes of concern.Moreover, recently, the Federal Reserve hiked funds rate for the second time this year by a quarter percentage point to a range of 1.75-2%. Chances of two more rate hikes this year are also high. The rate hike was imminent, given stable economic scenario backed by low unemployment and solid wage growth. That said, the rise in interest rates comes at a time when home prices are increasing, owing to supply constraints and increased raw material costs.Mortgage rates are surging in proportion to U.S. government bond yields, in anticipation of higher rates of inflation and further monetary tightening by the Fed. Rising mortgage rates may dilute the demand for new homes.Though myriad problems have been decelerating the homebuilding industry of late, the larger picture is convincingly strong.
